Status Epilepticus.title: Status Epilepticus
Status Epilepticus.scope: ** Management of convulsive status epilepticus (CSE) and non-convulsive status epilepticus (NCSE) in adults. Covers staged treatment protocol from emergent benzodiazepines through refractory and super-refractory phases. Includes diagnostic workup to identify underlying etiology and specific protocols for NORSE/FIRES. Excludes pediatric status epilepticus, neonatal seizures, and psychogenic non-epileptic status.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypoglycemia is immediately reversible cause
Infection screen, baseline before ASMs
Electrolyte abnormalities, renal/hepatic function for ASM dosing
Hypomagnesemia lowers seizure threshold
Hypocalcemia can cause seizures
Hypophosphatemia lowers seizure threshold
Acidosis, oxygenation, ventilation status
Elevated in prolonged seizure; marker of severity
Illicit drugs, withdrawal states
Alcohol withdrawal common cause
Subtherapeutic levels as precipitant
Eclampsia; affects ASM choice

Extended Workup.rationale: Hepatic encephalopathy, valproate toxicity, urea cycle disorders

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Anti-NMDAR, LGI1, CASPR2 in NORSE
Subacute onset, smoking history, weight loss
HIV-associated CNS disease
Neurosyphilis
Wilson disease (young patients)
Acute intermittent porphyria
MELAS, other mitochondrial disorders
Pyridoxine-dependent seizures (rare, usually pediatric)

New Onset Seizure.title: New Onset Seizure
New Onset Seizure.scope: ** Initial evaluation and management of first-time unprovoked seizure or first presentation of seizure activity in adults. Covers immediate stabilization, diagnostic workup to identify etiology, acute treatment, and framework for anti-seizure medication (ASM) initiation. Excludes status epilepticus (see "Status Epilepticus" template), pediatric seizures, febrile seizures, and known epilepsy with breakthrough seizures.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypoglycemia is immediately reversible cause
Infection screen, baseline before ASMs
Electrolyte abnormalities (Na, Ca, Mg, glucose), renal/hepatic function for ASM dosing
Hypomagnesemia lowers seizure threshold
Hypocalcemia can cause seizures
Illicit drugs (cocaine, amphetamines) and withdrawal states
Alcohol intoxication or withdrawal
UTI can provoke seizures (especially elderly)
Elevated if drawn within 10-20 min of event; helps distinguish seizure from non-epileptic event
Hypophosphatemia lowers seizure threshold (especially alcohol withdrawal)

Extended Workup.rationale: Thyroid dysfunction can affect seizure threshold
Cardiac ischemia as cause or consequence
Eclampsia; affects imaging and ASM choice
Deficiency can lower threshold; important for women of childbearing potential

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Synthetic drugs, medications not on standard screen
Occupational exposure, pica
Wilson disease (young patients)
HIV-associated CNS disease
Neurosyphilis
Anti-NMDAR, LGI1, CASPR2, GABA-B if clinical suspicion
Subacute onset, smoking, weight loss
Acute intermittent porphyria
Young onset, family history, refractory

Patient Instructions.item: **Return to ED immediately if:** recurrent seizure, prolonged seizure >5 minutes, head injury, persistent confusion, difficulty breathing, or status epilepticus
Do NOT drive until cleared by neurology (driving restrictions per state guidelines; typically require seizure-free interval)
Avoid operating heavy machinery, working at heights, or swimming alone
Do not bathe alone; showers preferred over baths; keep bathroom door unlocked
Inform employer if job involves safety-sensitive duties
Take ASM exactly as prescribed; do NOT stop abruptly (risk of breakthrough seizures or status epilepticus)
Avoid common seizure triggers: sleep deprivation, alcohol, illicit drugs, missed medications
Keep a seizure diary: date, time, duration, description, triggers, post-ictal symptoms
Wear medical identification (bracelet or necklace)
Educate family/coworkers on seizure first aid: stay with person, protect head, do NOT put anything in mouth, time the seizure, call 911 if >5 minutes
Follow up with neurology within 1-2 weeks of discharge
Bring list of all medications (including OTC and supplements) to all appointments - many interact with ASMs
Women: discuss contraception with provider; some ASMs reduce efficacy of hormonal contraception
Report side effects (mood changes, rash, dizziness, cognitive issues) promptly; do NOT stop medication without calling
Avoid flashing/strobe lights if photosensitive seizures suspected

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Sleep hygiene: aim for 7-9 hours nightly; maintain regular sleep schedule
Avoid alcohol (lowers seizure threshold; interacts with ASMs)
Avoid illicit drugs (especially stimulants: cocaine, amphetamines)
Stress management techniques
Regular moderate exercise (not extreme sleep deprivation from overtraining)
Medication adherence: use pill organizers, phone alarms, refill reminders
Folic acid supplementation 1-4 mg daily for women of childbearing potential (especially if on enzyme-inducing ASMs)
Bone health: vitamin D 1000-2000 IU daily; calcium as needed (enzyme-inducing ASMs affect bone density)
Avoid known personal triggers (flashing lights, certain foods, stress, if identified)
Home safety modifications: pad sharp furniture corners, avoid glass shower doors, use microwave instead of stovetop when alone
Seizure alert devices or apps for those living alone (optional)
Smoking cessation (increases ASM metabolism; general health)

Multiple Sclerosis - New Diagnosis.title: Multiple Sclerosis - New Diagnosis
Multiple Sclerosis - New Diagnosis.scope: ** Initial diagnostic workup and management of suspected or newly confirmed MS. Covers diagnostic criteria evaluation, mimics exclusion, acute symptom treatment, and DMT initiation framework. For established MS with acute relapse, use "MS - Exacerbation" template. For ongoing DMT management and monitoring, use "MS - Maintenance" template.

Insurance navigation, disability questions, support resources
Significant functional impairment, comprehensive rehab needs

Baseline macular exam before S1P modulator initiation
If atypical features, family history concerns

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED if rapid vision loss, sudden weakness, difficulty breathing, or urinary retention
Avoid driving until cleared by neurology
Heat may temporarily worsen symptoms (Uhthoff phenomenon) - this is not a new attack
Expect temporary steroid side effects: insomnia, mood changes, increased appetite, metallic taste
Keep symptom diary noting new or worsening symptoms
Do not stop steroids abruptly if on oral taper
Do not stop baclofen or tizanidine abruptly - risk of withdrawal/rebound spasticity
Monitor blood sugars if diabetic - steroids elevate glucose
Avoid sick contacts while on high-dose steroids
Contact MS specialist before starting any new medications (drug interactions with DMTs)
Vaccinations should be completed before DMT initiation (especially live vaccines)
Pregnancy planning requires DMT discussion (some DMTs teratogenic, washout periods vary)
Report any signs of infection (fever, cough, dysuria) promptly
Post-void residual check if difficulty emptying bladder or recurrent UTIs

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Smoking cessation (smoking accelerates MS progression and disability)
Vitamin D supplementation 2000-5000 IU daily (target serum 25-OH vitamin D >40 ng/mL)
Regular aerobic exercise 150 min/week as tolerated (improves fatigue, mood, function)
Resistance training 2-3Ã—/week
Stress management and adequate sleep (7-8 hours nightly)
Avoid excessive heat exposure (hot tubs, saunas, prolonged direct sun, exercising in heat)
Cooling vest for outdoor activities in warm weather
Maintain healthy weight (obesity associated with worse outcomes)
Limit alcohol intake (can worsen balance, cognition, bladder symptoms)
Ensure vaccinations up to date before DMT initiation (live vaccines contraindicated on many DMTs)
Fall prevention: remove loose rugs, ensure adequate lighting, use assistive devices if needed
Energy conservation techniques for fatigue management (pacing, prioritization, positioning)

disposition.criteria: Mild symptoms; able to ambulate safely; reliable follow-up within 1-2 weeks; no IV steroids needed OR completing outpatient infusion; stable baseline function; understands return precautions
Moderate-severe symptoms; needs IV steroids; functional decline requiring therapy; diagnostic uncertainty requiring expedited workup; unable to care for self at home
Severe myelitis with respiratory compromise (NIF >-30 declining toward -20); brainstem involvement with airway risk or autonomic instability; severe encephalopathy
PLEX needed but unavailable; MS specialist not available for complex decision-making; MRI unavailable for urgent imaging

Peripheral Neuropathy - New Diagnosis/Ev.title: Peripheral Neuropathy - New Diagnosis/Evaluation
Peripheral Neuropathy - New Diagnosis/Ev.scope: ** Initial diagnostic workup and symptomatic management of suspected or newly diagnosed peripheral neuropathy. Covers etiologic evaluation, electrodiagnostic testing, pain management, and lifestyle modifications. For acute inflammatory neuropathies (GBS, CIDP), use dedicated templates. For diabetic neuropathy-specific management, this template applies but see also diabetes care protocols for glycemic optimization.

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED if sudden severe weakness, difficulty breathing, or rapid symptom progression
Inspect feet daily for cuts, blisters, or wounds (use mirror for soles)
Wear well-fitting, protective footwear at all times (never barefoot)
Test bath water temperature with elbow or thermometer before entering (avoid burns)
Avoid prolonged hot or cold exposure to affected extremities (impaired sensation increases injury risk)
Use night lights and handrails to prevent falls
Report new numbness, weakness, or autonomic symptoms (dizziness, bladder changes)
Keep pain medication diary to track effectiveness and side effects
Do not stop gabapentin/pregabalin abruptly - taper under medical guidance
Neuropathic pain medications take 2-4 weeks to reach full effect
Avoid alcohol (worsens neuropathy, interacts with pain medications)
Rise slowly from sitting/lying position if orthostatic hypotension present
Increase salt and fluid intake if orthostatic (unless contraindicated by cardiac/renal disease)
Wear compression stockings for orthostatic hypotension
Do not drive until cleared if significant sensory loss or weakness affects pedal control
B12 injections: if self-administering, use proper technique and rotate injection sites

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Strict glycemic control (HbA1c <7% or individualized target) - most important modifiable factor
Complete alcohol cessation (alcoholic neuropathy is reversible if early)
Smoking cessation (microvascular disease worsens neuropathy)
Regular exercise as tolerated (improves circulation, glycemic control, reduces pain)
Balance exercises and strength training (PT-guided) to prevent falls
Pool therapy/aquatic exercise (reduces fall risk while exercising)
Vitamin B12 supplementation if vegan/vegetarian or on metformin
Review medications for neurotoxic agents (metronidazole, nitrofurantoin, chemotherapy, amiodarone, statins)
Avoid excessive vitamin B6 supplementation (>100 mg/day can cause neuropathy)
Blood pressure control (target <130/80 for diabetic patients)
Weight loss if obese (reduces pressure on nerves, improves metabolic syndrome)
Fall prevention: remove throw rugs, ensure adequate lighting, use assistive devices
Annual foot exams by podiatry or primary care for diabetic patients
Regular ophthalmology exams if diabetic (concurrent retinopathy common)

differential.features: Symmetric, length-dependent, sensory-predominant, feet before hands, burning/tingling
differential.tests: HbA1c >6.5% (or 2-hour OGTT >200); NCS shows axonal sensorimotor polyneuropathy

differential.features: History of chronic alcohol use, nutritional deficiency, burning feet
differential.tests: History, thiamine level, liver function tests

differential.features: Subacute combined degeneration, myelopathy features (ataxia, Romberg), macrocytic anemia
differential.tests: B12 <200 pg/mL or MMA elevated; may have cord signal changes on MRI

differential.features: Progressive or relapsing weakness >8 weeks, proximal and distal, areflexia
differential.tests: NCS shows demyelination; CSF protein elevated; nerve enlargement on ultrasound

differential.features: Acute ascending weakness <4 weeks, areflexia, post-infectious
differential.tests: NCS early may be normal then demyelinating; CSF albuminocytologic dissociation

differential.features: Family history, pes cavus, hammertoes, childhood onset, slowly progressive
differential.tests: Genetic testing; NCS shows uniform slowing in CMT1

differential.features: Autonomic dysfunction, carpal tunnel, cardiac involvement, family history
differential.tests: TTR gene mutation; tissue biopsy with amyloid

differential.features: Distal sensory-predominant, ataxia (IgM anti-MAG), older patient
differential.tests: SPEP/UPEP; anti-MAG antibody; may need bone marrow biopsy

differential.features: Mononeuritis multiplex pattern (asymmetric, stepwise), pain, systemic symptoms
differential.tests: Elevated ESR/CRP; ANCA; nerve/muscle biopsy shows necrotizing vasculitis

differential.features: Subacute onset, asymmetric, dorsal root ganglia involvement, weight loss
differential.tests: Anti-Hu antibody; CT chest for small cell lung cancer

differential.features: Dermatomal distribution, unilateral, neck/back pain, preserved reflexes outside affected root
differential.tests: MRI spine; NCS/EMG shows radicular pattern

differential.features: Acute/subacute proximal weakness, thigh pain, unilateral then contralateral
differential.tests: NCS/EMG; MRI lumbosacral plexus; diagnosis of exclusion

differential.features: Pain/autonomic symptoms with normal NCS, preserved reflexes
differential.tests: Skin biopsy for IENFD; autonomic testing

differential.features: Childhood/adolescent onset, pes cavus, distal atrophy, family history
differential.tests: Genetic testing (PMP22 duplication most common)

differential.features: Temporal relationship to neurotoxic chemotherapy (platinum, taxanes, vincristine)
differential.tests: History; dose-dependent; may improve after discontinuation

differential.features: HIV+ patient, distal symmetric painful neuropathy
differential.tests: HIV testing; CD4 count

differential.features: Endemic area, prior tick bite, radiculopathy, cranial neuropathy, polyradiculopathy
differential.tests: Lyme serology; may need CSF analysis

differential.features: Multifocal neuropathy, cranial neuropathy (especially VII), pulmonary symptoms
differential.tests: ACE level; chest imaging; biopsy (non-caseating granulomas)

differential.features: Endemic areas, skin lesions, enlarged palpable nerves, anesthetic patches
differential.tests: Skin smear/biopsy for AFB; nerve biopsy

evidence.recommendation: Diabetes is most common cause of polyneuropathy in developed countries
HbA1c <7% reduces neuropathy incidence in Type 1 DM
Gabapentin, pregabalin, duloxetine first-line for painful diabetic neuropathy
Tricyclic antidepressants effective for neuropathic pain
NCS/EMG for characterization of peripheral neuropathy
SPEP indicated in idiopathic neuropathy workup
OGTT detects IGT in 34-62% of idiopathic neuropathy patients
evidence.source: [Singleton et al. Diabetes Care 2001](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11473085/); [Hoffman-Snyder et al. Arch Neurol 2006](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16769858/)

evidence.recommendation: Skin biopsy (IENFD) for small fiber neuropathy
evidence.source: [Lauria G et al. Eur J Neurol 2010](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20642627/)

evidence.recommendation: Foot care reduces amputations in diabetic neuropathy
Capsaicin 8% patch effective for localized neuropathic pain
Combination therapy for neuropathic pain improves outcomes

disposition.criteria: Stable symptoms; chronic/slowly progressive course; ambulatory; reliable follow-up with neurology within 2-4 weeks; pain controlled; able to perform ADLs; no fall risk requiring inpatient therapy

Acute/subacute progression concerning for GBS or CIDP; significant functional decline; falls requiring therapy evaluation; severe uncontrolled pain; new autonomic instability; workup requiring inpatient procedures (nerve biopsy, LP)
GBS with respiratory compromise (FVC <20 mL/kg, NIF >-30, or declining trajectory); autonomic instability with cardiac arrhythmia or BP lability; aspiration risk
EMG/NCS not available urgently; neuromuscular specialist not available; PLEX/IVIG needed but not available; rehabilitation services not available

Acute Ischemic Stroke.title: Acute Ischemic Stroke
icd10: I63.50 (Cerebral infarction due to unspecified occlusion or stenosis of unspecified cerebral artery)
I63.3 (Cerebral infarction due to thrombosis of cerebral arteries)
I63.4 (Cerebral infarction due to embolism of cerebral arteries)
Acute Ischemic Stroke.scope: ** Acute ischemic stroke in adults — covers initial stabilization, thrombolytic therapy (IV alteplase/tenecteplase), endovascular thrombectomy criteria, blood pressure management, stroke etiology workup, secondary prevention initiation, and early rehabilitation. Excludes hemorrhagic stroke (see Intracerebral Hemorrhage template), transient ischemic attack (see TIA template), pediatric stroke, and chronic post-stroke management.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypoglycemia mimics stroke; must rule out before tPA
Baseline; thrombocytopenia contraindicates tPA if <100K
Electrolyte abnormalities, renal function for contrast/medication dosing
Anticoagulant use; INR >1.7 contraindicates tPA
Heparin use; elevated aPTT contraindicates tPA
Acute MI can cause cardioembolic stroke; stress cardiomyopathy
Potential need for blood products, surgical intervention
Baseline for statin therapy; cardiovascular risk assessment
Diabetes screening/management; cardiovascular risk factor

Extended Workup.rationale: Liver disease affects anticoagulation, medication metabolism
Thyroid dysfunction as cardiovascular risk factor; atrial fibrillation workup
Affects treatment decisions (tPA risk-benefit), imaging choices
Intoxication as stroke mimic; affects exam reliability
Hypomagnesemia associated with arrhythmia, vascular risk
Refeeding risk if malnourished; metabolic panel

Essential/First-line.target: Acute ischemic infarct (restricted diffusion); stroke location and extent; ASPECTS scoring

Referrals & Consults.indication: All acute stroke presentations; tPA decision; stroke workup
Large vessel occlusion on CTA for thrombectomy
Malignant MCA edema, posterior fossa stroke with hydrocephalus, hemorrhagic transformation requiring intervention
Newly detected atrial fibrillation, acute MI, cardiomyopathy, PFO evaluation
Symptomatic carotid stenosis ≥50% (NASCET) for endarterectomy; ideally within 2 weeks
Dysphagia screening before any PO intake; aphasia evaluation; cognitive-communication assessment
Early mobilization within 24-48h (AVERT trial: avoid very early aggressive mobilization <24h); gait and balance training
ADL assessment, upper extremity function, adaptive equipment, cognitive rehabilitation
Determine rehabilitation disposition (inpatient rehab, SNF, home health, outpatient)
Discharge planning, insurance, DME, caregiver support, advance directives
Dysphagia diet recommendations, cardiovascular risk diet (Mediterranean, DASH)
Large territory stroke with poor prognosis, goals of care discussion
Active smokers
Rehabilitation placement, follow-up coordination

Patient Instructions.item: Call 911 immediately if new symptoms: sudden weakness, numbness, vision changes, speech difficulty, severe headache, loss of balance
Do NOT drive until cleared by neurology (minimum 2 weeks; state-specific laws apply)
Take all medications as prescribed; do NOT stop antiplatelet or anticoagulant without medical advice
Swallowing precautions per SLP recommendations (sit upright 90° for meals, specific diet texture)
Fall prevention: clear pathways, use assistive devices, adequate lighting, non-slip surfaces
Blood pressure monitoring at home (target <130/80 per physician guidance)
Stroke signs education for patient and family: F.A.S.T. (Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call 911)
Medication list: carry updated list including all prescriptions, OTC, and supplements
Follow-up appointment with neurology in 1-2 weeks; primary care in 2-4 weeks
Report any bleeding (bruising, blood in stool/urine, gum bleeding) if on anticoagulation

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Smoking cessation (absolute)
Blood pressure target <130/80 mmHg
Mediterranean or DASH diet
Sodium restriction <2.3 g/day (ideally <1.5 g if hypertensive)
Regular aerobic exercise: 40 min moderate intensity, 3-4 days/week (after medical clearance)
Weight management (BMI 18.5-24.9)
Alcohol limitation: ≤1 drink/day women, ≤2 drinks/day men; cessation if heavy use
Glycemic control target HbA1c <7% (individualized)
LDL target <70 mg/dL (high-intensity statin)
Obstructive sleep apnea screening (Berlin questionnaire or STOP-BANG); CPAP if diagnosed
Stress management and emotional support (depression common post-stroke)
Influenza and pneumococcal vaccination

differential.features: Glucose <60; symptoms resolve with dextrose; diaphoresis, tremor

differential.features: Witnessed seizure, post-ictal confusion, resolves within 24h; may have known epilepsy

differential.features: Headache history, aura preceding deficit, gradual onset ("marching"), younger patient, family history
differential.tests: MRI DWI (negative), clinical history

differential.features: CT shows hemorrhage; more severe headache, rapid progression, vomiting
differential.tests: CT head without contrast

differential.features: Subacute onset over days-weeks, progressive symptoms, headache worse in morning
differential.tests: MRI with contrast (enhancing mass)

differential.features: History of trauma or anticoagulation; subacute confusion, headache, fluctuating symptoms
differential.tests: CT head (crescent-shaped extra-axial collection)

differential.features: Severely elevated BP, headache, confusion, visual changes, seizures; typically posterior involvement
differential.tests: MRI FLAIR (posterior white matter edema), BP >220/120

differential.features: Fever, meningismus, subacute course, immunocompromise
differential.tests: MRI with contrast, LP, blood cultures

Guillain-Barré Syndrome.title: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
Guillain-Barré Syndrome.scope: ** Evaluation and management of acute Guillain-Barré Syndrome in adults, including all major variants (AIDP, AMAN, AMSAN, Miller Fisher). Covers respiratory monitoring protocols, immunotherapy (IVIg and plasmapheresis), autonomic dysfunction management, and ICU care. Excludes CIDP (chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy) and pediatric GBS.

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consult for diagnosis confirmation, immunotherapy initiation, and prognosis discussion
Pulmonology consult for respiratory function monitoring and ventilator management if FVC declining
Critical care consult for ICU admission given FVC <30 mL/kg or rapidly declining respiratory function
Physical therapy for mobility assessment, fall prevention, and early mobilization when stable
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment and adaptive equipment to maintain independence
Speech therapy for swallow evaluation given bulbar weakness and aspiration risk
Respiratory therapy for airway clearance techniques and ventilator management if intubated
Pain management consult for refractory neuropathic pain not responding to gabapentin/pregabalin
Physiatry/PM&R for rehabilitation planning and discharge disposition to optimize functional recovery
Social work for discharge planning, caregiver support, and GBS Foundation resources

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately if worsening weakness or breathing difficulty develops (may indicate disease progression requiring intubation)
Use fall precautions including walker and assistance due to proximal weakness and areflexia
Do not drive until cleared by neurology due to unpredictable weakness and impaired reflexes
Perform physical therapy exercises as prescribed to maintain range of motion and prevent contractures
Expect gradual recovery over weeks to months; most patients recover but pace varies by severity
Report fevers, severe headache, or new symptoms immediately as these may indicate infection or relapse
Contact GBS-CIDP Foundation (www.gbs-cidp.org) for patient support and educational resources

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Aspiration precautions including thickened liquids and upright positioning given bulbar weakness
Early mobilization when medically stable to prevent DVT and deconditioning (with PT guidance)
Frequent repositioning every 2 hours to prevent pressure ulcers during immobility
Monitor for urinary retention and catheterize if needed due to autonomic dysfunction
Use energy conservation techniques including scheduled rest periods to manage post-GBS fatigue
Gradual return to activities as strength permits; avoid overexertion which may worsen fatigue
Discuss future vaccination timing with neurologist; avoid live vaccines if on immunotherapy

Myasthenia Gravis - Exacerbation/Crisis.title: Myasthenia Gravis - Exacerbation/Crisis
Myasthenia Gravis - Exacerbation/Crisis.scope: ** Acute exacerbation and myasthenic crisis in adults with known or suspected myasthenia gravis. Covers respiratory monitoring, emergent immunotherapy (IVIG/PLEX), cholinesterase inhibitor management, distinguishing myasthenic from cholinergic crisis, and medications to avoid. Excludes new diagnosis workup (see MG - New Diagnosis template), Lambert-Eaton syndrome, and chronic stable management.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; infection screen (common trigger); leukocytosis suggests infection
Electrolytes, renal/hepatic function for medication dosing; hypokalemia worsens weakness
Hypomagnesemia worsens NMJ transmission; CONTRAINDICATED to give IV Mg in MG crisis
Essential/Core Labs.target: Confirm normal BEFORE any magnesium replacement

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Thyroid disease coexists in 10-15% of MG; thyrotoxicosis precipitates crisis
Steroid-induced hyperglycemia management
UTI as precipitant for exacerbation
If febrile; infection is #1 trigger for crisis
Affects treatment choices; MG can fluctuate in pregnancy
Coagulation before procedures; PLEX circuit anticoagulation
Respiratory failure assessment; hypercapnia is LATE finding — do not wait for this

Extended Workup.rationale: Confirm diagnosis if not previously tested; positive in 85% generalized MG
Additional sensitivity when binding Ab equivocal
If AChR negative; MuSK-positive MG has different treatment implications (poor response to pyridostigmine, PLEX preferred over IVIG)
Associated with thymoma; especially in young patients
Differentiate bacterial infection trigger from other causes of decompensation
Aspiration pneumonia, atelectasis; baseline for ventilator
Check azathioprine metabolites (6-TGN), mycophenolate levels, tacrolimus levels if on these agents

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Triple-seronegative MG (AChR-/MuSK-/LRP4+)
Emerging biomarker in seronegative MG
Associated with myocarditis in MG; cardiac risk stratification
Complement-mediated MG pathophysiology; pre-eculizumab evaluation
Hypogammaglobulinemia from rituximab or chronic IVIG; IgA deficiency before IVIG

Referrals & Consults.indication: All myasthenic crisis; treatment decisions; medication management
Declining respiratory function; ventilator management
Thymoma evaluation; thymectomy planning (if not previously done)
Bedside FVC/NIF monitoring; pulmonary toilet
Dysphagia evaluation; aspiration prevention (bulbar weakness common in crisis)
Prevent deconditioning; safe mobilization; fall prevention
ADL assessment; energy conservation techniques; adaptive equipment
Medication reconciliation — review ALL medications for MG-unsafe drugs
Discharge planning; support resources; insurance for IVIG/PLEX
Goals of care discussion for refractory or elderly patients
If infection trigger unclear or complex; immunosuppressed patient management
If concurrent thyroid disease; steroid-induced diabetes management

Patient Instructions.item: Call 911 / Return to ED if: increasing difficulty breathing, trouble swallowing, choking on food or saliva, unable to hold head up, rapidly worsening weakness
Carry MG crisis card / MedicAlert bracelet at all times
Bring complete medication list to every medical visit; alert ALL providers about MG diagnosis
NEVER take antibiotics, pain medications, or new prescriptions without checking with neurology
Take pyridostigmine 30-60 minutes before meals for best swallowing function
Avoid extreme heat (worsens weakness), overexertion, and sleep deprivation
Report any new medication prescribed by other providers to your neurologist
Infection prevention: hand hygiene, avoid sick contacts, up-to-date vaccinations (inactivated only if immunosuppressed; NO live vaccines)
Follow-up with neurology 1-2 weeks post-discharge; sooner if symptoms worsen

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Infection avoidance (number one trigger for crisis)
Influenza vaccination annually (inactivated)
Pneumococcal vaccination
COVID-19 vaccination (inactivated/mRNA; coordinate timing with immunosuppression cycle)
NO live vaccines if on immunosuppression (MMR, varicella, live zoster, yellow fever)
Adequate sleep (fatigue worsens MG)
Stress management (emotional stress triggers exacerbation)
Moderate exercise as tolerated; avoid overexertion; rest periods during activity
Heat avoidance (hot weather, hot tubs, saunas worsen NMJ transmission)
Smoking cessation
Alcohol limitation (alcohol worsens weakness)
Eye protection (sunglasses, patching for diplopia; artificial tears for incomplete lid closure)

differential.tests: NCS/EMG (denervation); no response to IVIG/PLEX; no AChR antibodies

differential.features: Acute onset; cranial nerve findings; crossed findings (ipsilateral cranial nerve + contralateral limb); no fatigability
differential.tests: MRI DWI (restricted diffusion); CTA

differential.features: CNS symptoms (optic neuritis, sensory level, cerebellar ataxia); dissemination in space and time; no NMJ findings
differential.tests: MRI brain/spine; LP (oligoclonal bands); no AChR antibodies

differential.features: Severe weakness, tachycardia, fever, agitation, lid lag; thyroid hormone excess

Bacterial Meningitis.title: Bacterial Meningitis
Bacterial Meningitis.scope: ** Acute community-acquired bacterial meningitis in adults. Covers emergency empiric antibiotics, dexamethasone adjunctive therapy, LP and CSF analysis, targeted therapy by organism, and complications management. Excludes viral meningitis, fungal meningitis, TB meningitis, healthcare-associated/post-surgical meningitis, and pediatric meningitis.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: MUST be drawn BEFORE antibiotics but do NOT delay antibiotics to obtain; positive in 50-70% of bacterial meningitis

disposition.criteria: Never discharge directly from ED with suspected bacterial meningitis. Need for neurosurgery (abscess, empyema, EVD); need for neuro-ICU expertise not available

HSV Encephalitis.title: HSV Encephalitis
HSV Encephalitis.scope: ** Acute HSV-1 encephalitis in adults — the most common cause of sporadic fatal encephalitis. Covers emergent empiric acyclovir, LP with HSV PCR, MRI findings, seizure management, and monitoring for complications (cerebral edema, SIADH, refractory status epilepticus). Excludes neonatal HSV, HSV-2 meningitis (Mollaret), CMV/EBV/VZV encephalitis, and autoimmune encephalitis (though post-HSV autoimmune encephalitis is addressed).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; infection markers; lymphopenia may be present
Renal function for acyclovir dosing (nephrotoxic); electrolytes (SIADH); hepatic function
Exclude bacterial meningitis; concurrent bacteremia
Before LP; coagulopathy workup if DIC suspected
CSF:serum glucose ratio interpretation
Low procalcitonin argues against bacterial meningitis
Inflammatory marker; lower in viral than bacterial
SIADH is common complication of HSV encephalitis
SIADH evaluation
Potential surgical intervention for mass effect

SIADH confirmation (urine osm >100, urine Na >40 with low serum Na)

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED if: new confusion, seizure, fever recurrence, worsening headache, personality change, speech difficulty, new weakness
HSV encephalitis can cause long-term memory and cognitive deficits; rehabilitation is important
Seizures may develop weeks to months after infection; report any episodic symptoms (staring, jerking, déjà vu, loss of awareness)
Post-HSV autoimmune encephalitis can occur 2-6 weeks later with new psychiatric/neurologic symptoms — report immediately
Take all medications as prescribed; do NOT stop antiepileptic drugs without neurologist guidance
Follow-up with neurology in 2-4 weeks; neuropsychology testing at 3-6 months
Cognitive rehabilitation and therapy are critical for recovery
Driving restrictions until seizure-free per state law (typically 3-12 months)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: HSV encephalitis is NOT contagious in the traditional sense; no isolation needed
Long-term suppressive antiviral therapy is NOT standard after encephalitis (unlike genital HSV)
Cognitive rehabilitation: memory strategies, organizational tools, speech therapy
Seizure safety: avoid heights, swimming alone, operating heavy machinery until seizure-free
Mental health support (depression, anxiety, PTSD common after encephalitis)
Adequate sleep and stress management
Gradual return to work/school with accommodations as needed

evidence.source: [Whitley et al. (NEJM 1986)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/3001520/) — acyclovir vs placebo landmark trial; reduced mortality from 70% to 20%

evidence.recommendation: Start acyclovir empirically; do NOT delay for diagnostics

evidence.recommendation: CSF HSV PCR as gold standard (sensitivity 96-98%)

evidence.recommendation: MRI with DWI is most sensitive imaging

evidence.source: Periodic lateralizing discharges in ~80% of HSV encephalitis

evidence.recommendation: Dexamethasone for HSV encephalitis: NOT standard of care
evidence.source: DexEnceph trial (ongoing); animal data supportive; no clear human mortality benefit

evidence.recommendation: Aggressive hydration to prevent acyclovir nephrotoxicity

evidence.source: Standard practice; cannot clinically distinguish bacterial meningitis from encephalitis at presentation

evidence.recommendation: Repeat LP at end of treatment to confirm PCR negativity

evidence.source: IDSA Guidelines; relapse rate higher with <14 days

monitoring.frequency: q1h x 24h, then q2h x 48h, then q4h

Acetaminophen; cooling measures; reassess if persistent fever >72h on acyclovir
If <130: SIADH → fluid restriction (balance with acyclovir hydration); if <120: 3% saline
If rising: increase hydration; consider dose adjustment; hold if severe (rare); monitor urine output

monitoring.frequency: q1h in ICU; q4h shift on floor
monitoring.action: Increase IV fluids; if oliguria: renal assessment

monitoring.frequency: cEEG 24-72h if altered consciousness; routine EEG daily if improving
monitoring.action: If seizures: load/adjust AEDs; if NCSE: aggressive treatment per SE protocol

monitoring.frequency: Continuous in ICU; q4h on floor
monitoring.action: Supplemental O2; intubation if respiratory failure

monitoring.frequency: At 48-72h (evolution); day 7-14 (extent of damage); 3-6 months (chronic changes)
monitoring.action: If worsening edema: ICP management; neurosurgery consult

monitoring.frequency: At end of treatment (day 14-21) to confirm PCR negativity; earlier if clinical suspicion of treatment failure
monitoring.action: If still positive: extend acyclovir 7+ more days; consider resistance

monitoring.frequency: Recheck at 2-4 weeks if relapse or new psychiatric/neurologic symptoms

disposition.criteria: NOT appropriate directly from ED for suspected HSV encephalitis — always admit. Discharge from hospital when: completing IV acyclovir course (or transitioned to monitoring); improved consciousness (GCS 15); no active seizures; stable neurologic exam; safe swallowing; rehabilitation arranged; follow-up confirmed
Mild encephalitis (GCS 13-15); stable; low seizure burden; able to cooperate with neuro checks
GCS <13; active seizures or status epilepticus; need for continuous EEG; respiratory compromise; signs of elevated ICP; hemodynamic instability
Need for neuro-ICU not available; need for neurosurgery (decompressive craniectomy); continuous EEG not available
Moderate-severe cognitive deficits (memory impairment, aphasia); motor deficits; able to participate in 3h/day therapy
Unable to tolerate intensive rehabilitation; requires ongoing nursing care

Autoimmune Encephalitis.title: Autoimmune Encephalitis
Autoimmune Encephalitis.scope: ** Diagnostic workup, acute treatment, and long-term management of suspected or confirmed autoimmune encephalitis. Covers antibody-mediated encephalitis (anti-NMDAR, LGI1, CASPR2, GABA-B, AMPA, DPPX, IgLON5, GABA-A, GAD65), first-line immunotherapy, second-line escalation, seizure management, psychiatric symptom management, ICU considerations, tumor screening, and long-term immunosuppression. For infectious encephalitis, use "HSV Encephalitis" template. For paraneoplastic syndromes without encephalitis, use "Paraneoplastic Syndrome" template. For status epilepticus management, use "Status Epilepticus" template.

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately for new seizures, sudden behavioral changes, fever, difficulty breathing, or loss of consciousness
Autoimmune encephalitis is a treatable condition -- recovery may be slow (months to years) but significant improvement is expected with appropriate immunotherapy
Do NOT drive until seizure-free for state-mandated period AND cleared by neurology
Keep seizure diary (date, time, type, duration, triggers)
Behavioral and psychiatric symptoms are part of the disease, not a primary psychiatric disorder -- immunotherapy is the treatment
Report any signs of infection (fever >100.4F, cough, dysuria, rash) immediately while on immunotherapy
Avoid live vaccines while on immunosuppressive therapy (inform all physicians of immunosuppression status)
Do not stop anti-seizure medications abruptly
Avoid alcohol and recreational drugs (lower seizure threshold, interact with medications)
Pregnancy must be avoided during immunotherapy; discuss contraception with neurology and OB/GYN
Expect gradual improvement -- anti-NMDAR recovery typically occurs in reverse order of symptom onset (psychiatric symptoms resolve last)
Cognitive rehabilitation exercises as directed by speech and occupational therapy
Safety modifications at home (remove sharp objects, secure stairways, fall prevention)
Medical alert bracelet recommended (autoimmune encephalitis, seizure risk, immunosuppressed)
Follow-up appointments are critical -- relapse monitoring requires regular visits

disposition.criteria: Mild symptoms; stable or improving on established immunotherapy; no active seizures; able to perform basic ADLs; reliable follow-up within 1-2 weeks; no significant autonomic instability; family/caregiver education completed; outpatient infusion arranged if needed

Refractory status epilepticus; altered consciousness (GCS <12); severe autonomic instability (hemodynamic swings, arrhythmias, central hypoventilation); need for continuous EEG monitoring; requirement for mechanical ventilation; severe catatonia unresponsive to lorazepam; frequent or prolonged seizures requiring IV anesthetic infusions

PLEX or continuous EEG not available; neurology/neuroimmunology specialist not available; need for tumor resection (gynecologic oncology for teratoma); requires ICU care not available at current facility
Medically stable; significant functional deficits requiring intensive therapy (cognitive, motor, speech); unable to safely return home; expected to benefit from structured rehabilitation program
Prolonged ventilator dependence (common in severe anti-NMDAR); medically complex care needs; ongoing immunotherapy requirements; unable to participate in intensive rehab
Stable but unable to perform ADLs independently; requires ongoing nursing care; awaiting rehabilitation bed; chronic disability
All discharged patients: neurology follow-up within 1-2 weeks; infusion center for ongoing immunotherapy; neuropsychology referral; rehab services; tumor surveillance per protocol
New seizures after period of control; behavioral/cognitive regression; fever or signs of infection on immunotherapy; suspected relapse (any new neurologic/psychiatric symptoms)

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology/Cognitive neurology for MCI subtype characterization, biomarker interpretation, and treatment planning
Neuropsychology for comprehensive cognitive testing to establish baseline, characterize affected domains, and distinguish MCI subtypes
Geriatrics for comprehensive geriatric assessment, polypharmacy review, and functional optimization
Occupational therapy for cognitive strategies, compensatory techniques, and home safety evaluation
Occupational therapy driving evaluation to assess fitness to drive given cognitive impairment
Social work for community resources, support services, and early care planning guidance
Speech therapy for communication strategies if language domain affected (non-amnestic MCI)
Sleep medicine for sleep apnea evaluation if symptoms present (snoring, daytime sleepiness, witnessed apneas)
Psychiatry for depression evaluation if significant mood symptoms confounding cognitive assessment
Genetics counseling if early-onset (<65), family history of early-onset dementia, or considering genetic testing
Clinical trial referral for eligible patients interested in research studies targeting MCI and early AD
Elder law attorney for advance directives, healthcare proxy, and financial planning while patient has full capacity
PCP follow-up for cardiovascular risk factor management and coordination of vascular prevention

Patient Instructions.item: Return if sudden confusion worsens or new neurological symptoms develop which may indicate stroke or other acute process
Complete advance directives and establish healthcare proxy NOW while you have full capacity to make decisions
Consider long-term care preferences, financial planning, and legal arrangements with family while fully competent
Discuss driving safety with physician; formal driving evaluation recommended as MCI may affect reaction time and judgment
Use memory aids (calendars, smartphone reminders, pill organizers, written lists) to compensate for memory difficulties
Keep a consistent daily routine which helps with memory and reduces confusion
Take all medications as prescribed; bring medication list to all appointments
Return for follow-up cognitive testing every 6-12 months to monitor for progression
Report new memory concerns, personality changes, or functional difficulties to physician promptly
Avoid anticholinergic medications (diphenhydramine, PM sleep aids) as they can worsen cognition

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Engage in regular aerobic exercise (150 minutes/week moderate intensity) which may slow cognitive decline and improve brain health
Follow Mediterranean or MIND diet emphasizing vegetables, berries, fish, nuts, whole grains, and olive oil to reduce dementia risk
Participate in cognitively stimulating activities (reading, puzzles, learning new skills, social engagement) to build cognitive reserve
Maintain active social connections and relationships as social isolation is a modifiable dementia risk factor
Achieve adequate sleep (7-8 hours nightly) and treat sleep disorders (CPAP for sleep apnea) as poor sleep accelerates cognitive decline
Cardiovascular risk factor control with target BP <130/80, HbA1c <7%, LDL <100 to reduce vascular contribution to cognitive decline
Address hearing loss with hearing aids as untreated hearing loss is a modifiable risk factor for cognitive decline
Limit alcohol to maximum 1 drink daily as excess alcohol accelerates brain atrophy and cognitive decline
Smoking cessation to reduce vascular risk and improve overall brain health
Manage stress through relaxation techniques, mindfulness, or counseling as chronic stress impairs cognition
Review all medications with physician to identify and discontinue drugs that impair cognition (anticholinergics, benzodiazepines, opioids)

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology/Headache specialist referral for chronic TTH (≥15 days/month) not responding to first-line preventives
Physical therapy for cervicogenic component, postural dysfunction, and pericranial muscle tension
Behavioral medicine/Psychology for stress management, biofeedback, and cognitive behavioral therapy
Sleep medicine evaluation if underlying sleep disorder (insomnia, apnea) contributing to chronic headache
Ophthalmology evaluation to rule out refractive error or eye strain as contributing factor
Dentistry/TMJ specialist if temporomandibular joint dysfunction contributing to headache
Psychiatry referral for comorbid depression or anxiety requiring pharmacologic management beyond preventive therapy

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately for sudden severe headache ("worst headache of life") which may indicate hemorrhage or other serious cause
Return immediately for headache with fever, stiff neck, or altered mental status which may indicate infection
Return if new neurological symptoms develop (weakness, numbness, vision changes, speech difficulty)
Maintain headache diary tracking frequency, triggers, medication use, and response to guide treatment optimization
Limit acute pain medication use to no more than 10 days per month to prevent medication overuse headache
Take acute medications early at headache onset for best efficacy rather than waiting for severe pain
Identify and modify personal triggers (stress, poor posture, inadequate sleep, screen time, skipped meals)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular sleep schedule (7-8 hours, consistent bedtime and wake time) as sleep disturbance is a common trigger
Stress management through relaxation techniques, mindfulness meditation, or progressive muscle relaxation
Regular aerobic exercise (30 minutes moderate activity 5 times/week) shown to reduce chronic headache frequency
Ergonomic workplace assessment to optimize posture and reduce neck/shoulder strain during computer work
Limit screen time and take regular breaks (20-20-20 rule: every 20 minutes, look 20 feet away for 20 seconds)
Adequate hydration (at least 64 oz water daily) as dehydration can trigger headache
Regular meals to avoid fasting-triggered headache; do not skip meals
Limit caffeine to moderate consistent intake (≤200 mg/day or ~2 cups coffee) to prevent withdrawal headaches
Stretching exercises for neck and shoulders daily, especially if sedentary work

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology/Headache specialist referral for aura characterization, preventive optimization, and differentiation from other neurological conditions
OB/GYN consultation for contraceptive counseling - **estrogen-containing contraceptives contraindicated** in migraine with aura due to elevated ischemic stroke risk
Cardiology referral if TTE shows PFO for discussion of closure in select cases (recurrent cryptogenic stroke or debilitating aura despite medical therapy)
Genetics consultation if hemiplegic migraine suspected for CACNA1A, ATP1A2, SCN1A testing and family counseling
Physical therapy for cervicogenic component and trigger point management
Psychology/Behavioral medicine for CBT addressing aura anxiety, attack anticipation, and comorbid mood disorders
Ophthalmology if visual aura atypical or concern for retinal pathology
Sleep medicine if sleep disorder contributing to migraine frequency (OSA, insomnia)

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately for new/different headache, "worst headache of life," or thunderclap onset which may indicate subarachnoid hemorrhage
Return immediately if aura persists >60 minutes or if new weakness on one side of body develops (need to rule out stroke)
Return immediately for headache with fever, stiff neck, or altered mental status which may indicate CNS infection
**AVOID estrogen-containing contraceptives** (combined birth control pills, patch, ring) - use progestin-only methods (mini-pill, Depo-Provera, Mirena IUD, Nexplanon) or non-hormonal methods
Triptans ARE safe for your typical visual/sensory aura - take at headache onset or when aura ends; do NOT take if you experience weakness (motor aura)
Maintain headache/aura diary tracking aura type, duration, triggers, and medication use to guide treatment optimization
Limit acute medication use to ≤10 days/month to prevent medication overuse headache which worsens both headache and aura
Learn your personal aura warning signs and take acute medication promptly when headache begins
Do not drive or operate machinery during visual or motor aura as vision and coordination may be impaired

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular sleep schedule (7-8 hours, consistent bedtime) as sleep changes are a major aura trigger
Avoid known aura triggers (bright/flashing lights, high altitude, significant sleep deprivation, extreme stress)
Regular aerobic exercise (30 min moderate activity 5x/week) reduces migraine frequency; avoid if currently in aura
Magnesium-rich diet (leafy greens, nuts, whole grains) or supplementation as magnesium specifically helps aura
Stress management techniques (mindfulness, biofeedback, relaxation training) as stress is a major trigger
Adequate hydration (at least 64 oz water daily) as dehydration can trigger attacks
Smoking cessation to reduce vascular risk, particularly important given aura-associated stroke risk
Caffeine moderation (≤200 mg/day) and consistent daily intake to avoid withdrawal triggers
Blood pressure control (target <130/80) given elevated vascular risk with aura
Avoid high altitude or rapid altitude changes if altitude is a known aura trigger

ACOG: Combined hormonal contraceptives contraindicated in migraine with aura
Triptans safe and effective in migraine with typical aura
Triptans contraindicated in hemiplegic migraine (expert consensus)

Vertigo Evaluation.title: Vertigo Evaluation
Vertigo Evaluation.scope: ** Evaluation of acute and chronic vertigo including differentiation of peripheral vs central causes. Covers BPPV, vestibular neuritis, labyrinthitis, and Meniere's disease workup. Includes red flag identification for posterior circulation stroke. Excludes presyncope, orthostatic hypotension, and cardiac causes of dizziness.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypoglycemia can cause dizziness/lightheadedness mimicking vertigo

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consultation for central vertigo evaluation when HINTS exam suggests central lesion or stroke suspected
ENT/Otology referral for refractory BPPV, Meniere's disease management, or hearing loss evaluation
Vestibular physical therapy for vestibular rehabilitation and balance retraining after acute vertigo resolves
Audiology for formal hearing assessment and vestibular function testing (VNG, VEMP)
Neuro-ophthalmology if ocular motor abnormalities persist or skew deviation concerning for brainstem lesion
Stroke neurology for urgent evaluation if HINTS-plus exam suggests posterior circulation stroke
Cardiology if presyncope suspected or arrhythmia contributing to dizziness

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately if vertigo associated with new headache, diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia, or weakness (signs of stroke)
Return immediately if sudden hearing loss occurs which requires urgent treatment within 72 hours
Avoid driving, operating machinery, or working at heights until vertigo resolves completely due to fall and accident risk
Use assistive devices (cane, walker) if balance impaired to prevent falls
Perform Brandt-Daroff exercises twice daily as instructed if diagnosed with BPPV
Keep head elevated 30-45 degrees when sleeping for 24-48 hours after Epley maneuver (controversial but commonly recommended)
Avoid sudden head movements and rapid position changes which may trigger vertigo
Maintain hydration and avoid skipping meals as dehydration and hypoglycemia can worsen symptoms

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Sodium restriction (<2000 mg/day) if Meniere's disease diagnosed to reduce attack frequency
Caffeine reduction or elimination as caffeine can exacerbate vestibular symptoms
Alcohol avoidance as alcohol directly affects vestibular function and can trigger episodes
Stress management through relaxation techniques as stress can trigger vestibular migraine and Meniere's attacks
Regular sleep schedule as sleep deprivation can worsen vestibular symptoms
Fall prevention measures including removing throw rugs, installing grab bars, adequate lighting at home
Smoking cessation to reduce vascular risk factors that contribute to central vertigo

Carpal Tunnel Syndrome.title: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome
Carpal Tunnel Syndrome.scope: ** Evaluation and management of carpal tunnel syndrome from initial presentation through conservative treatment, injection therapy, and surgical referral. Covers clinical diagnosis, electrodiagnostic testing, severity grading, and treatment options. For acute median nerve injury or severe CTS with thenar atrophy, early surgical referral is indicated.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Screen for diabetes (common CTS risk factor)
Diabetes/prediabetes screening (diabetic neuropathy overlap)
Hypothyroidism causes CTS (myxedematous tissue infiltration)

Extended Workup.rationale: More specific for RA if RF negative
Renal disease (dialysis-associated CTS from amyloid deposition)
Amyloidosis, myeloma (bilateral CTS may be presenting sign of AL amyloid)

Rare/Specialized.rationale: AL amyloidosis if bilateral CTS with cardiac/renal involvement
Hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis if young onset bilateral CTS
Confirm amyloidosis if strongly suspected
Bilateral CTS in patient with acromegalic features

Essential/First-line.timing: Recommended for diagnosis confirmation and severity grading; optimal before surgery
Essential/First-line.target: Prolonged median sensory and/or motor distal latency; reduced SNAP amplitude; denervation in thenar muscles (severe)

Essential/First-line.timing: If fracture, arthritis, or bony abnormality suspected
Essential/First-line.target: Normal or degenerative changes; exclude fracture

Extended.timing: Alternative to MRI; can measure median nerve CSA; operator-dependent
Extended.target: Median nerve CSA >10-12 mm² at pisiform level; flattening at tunnel

Extended.timing: Mass lesion, ganglion cyst, tenosynovitis, anatomic variant
Extended.target: No mass, normal median nerve signal

Extended.timing: Rule out cervical radiculopathy if double crush suspected or atypical presentation

Suspected tumor or inflammatory mass in carpal tunnel
Distinguish CTS from polyneuropathy or brachial plexopathy

Referrals & Consults.item: Hand surgery or orthopedic surgery referral for carpal tunnel release evaluation when conservative therapy fails or severe CTS present
Electrodiagnostic medicine/neurology for NCS/EMG to confirm diagnosis and grade severity before surgical intervention
Occupational medicine for workplace ergonomic assessment and work restrictions if occupational risk factors present
Physical/occupational therapy for nerve gliding exercises, ergonomic training, and activity modification
Rheumatology referral if inflammatory arthritis suspected as underlying cause (RA, gout)
Endocrinology for diabetes optimization or hypothyroidism management if contributing to CTS
Primary care for management of modifiable risk factors (diabetes, obesity, hypothyroidism)
Pain management if refractory neuropathic symptoms despite treatment

Patient Instructions.item: Wear wrist splint nightly in neutral position for minimum 4-6 weeks; may wear during day if symptoms persist with activities
Avoid prolonged wrist flexion or extension (typing, gripping tools, driving) as this increases carpal tunnel pressure
Take frequent breaks during repetitive hand activities (every 30-60 minutes) to rest wrists
Perform nerve gliding exercises as instructed by therapist to improve median nerve mobility
Apply ice for 10-15 minutes if wrist swelling present; avoid direct ice contact with skin
Report worsening numbness, weakness in thumb, or dropping objects (may indicate progression requiring surgery)
Avoid sleeping with wrists curled under pillow; maintain neutral wrist position during sleep
If pregnant, symptoms often improve after delivery; conservative management preferred during pregnancy
After corticosteroid injection, temporary increase in symptoms may occur first 24-48 hours before improvement
Post-surgical: Keep incision clean and dry; elevate hand; start motion as directed; full grip strength recovery may take 3-6 months

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Optimize glycemic control (HbA1c <7%) as diabetes worsens nerve function and CTS outcomes
Weight loss if overweight/obese as obesity is modifiable risk factor for CTS
Ergonomic workstation setup: keyboard at elbow height, wrists neutral, avoid resting wrists on hard surfaces
Use ergonomic keyboard, mouse, and tools if occupation involves repetitive hand use
Smoking cessation to improve microvascular circulation and nerve healing
Avoid prolonged use of vibrating tools or take breaks every 15-30 minutes when using such equipment
Reduce caffeine and alcohol intake as these may worsen paresthesias in some patients
Treat underlying thyroid disease as hypothyroidism contributes to CTS through tissue edema
Stretch and warm up hands before repetitive activities
Vitamin B6 supplementation not recommended (evidence does not support benefit; high doses cause neuropathy)

Radiculopathy - Cervical and Lumbar.scope: ** Evaluation and management of cervical (C5-T1) and lumbar (L2-S1) radiculopathy in adults. Covers red flag identification, diagnostic workup including imaging and electrodiagnostic testing, conservative management, interventional treatments, and surgical indications. Excludes spinal cord compression (myelopathy), cauda equina syndrome (requires emergent surgical evaluation), thoracic radiculopathy, and post-surgical radiculopathy.

Referrals & Consults.item: Spine surgery (neurosurgery or orthopedic spine) consult STAT for cauda equina syndrome, progressive motor deficit, or myelopathic signs
Spine surgery consult URGENT for significant weakness (<4/5) or radiculopathy refractory to 6+ weeks conservative treatment
Physical therapy for core strengthening, McKenzie exercises, nerve gliding, and posture training
Pain management/Interventional spine for epidural steroid injections if conservative treatment fails after 4-6 weeks
PM&R (Physical Medicine & Rehabilitation) for comprehensive spine rehabilitation program
EMG/NCS referral to confirm radiculopathy level and exclude peripheral neuropathy or plexopathy (optimal timing 3-4 weeks after symptom onset)
Oncology consult for suspected spinal metastases or pathologic fracture
Infectious disease consult for suspected epidural abscess, discitis, or vertebral osteomyelitis
Rheumatology for suspected inflammatory spondyloarthropathy (ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis)
Occupational therapy for ergonomic assessment, workplace modifications, and ADL training
Psychology/Pain psychology for chronic pain management, CBT for pain, catastrophizing assessment
Neurology for atypical presentation, polyradiculopathy, or suspected inflammatory/infectious etiology
Social work for disability assistance, return-to-work planning, and insurance navigation

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED IMMEDIATELY if bladder or bowel incontinence, inability to urinate, saddle area numbness, or bilateral leg weakness (may indicate cauda equina syndrome)
Return to ED if fever develops with back/neck pain (may indicate infection)
Return if weakness is progressing or you are unable to lift foot/hand (progressive motor deficit requires urgent evaluation)
Most radiculopathy improves with conservative treatment over 4-6 weeks; surgery is rarely needed
Stay active within pain limits; prolonged bed rest (>1-2 days) is not recommended and may delay recovery
Apply ice for first 48-72 hours (20 min on/off), then switch to heat for muscle relaxation
Avoid heavy lifting, twisting, and prolonged sitting; use proper body mechanics
Sleep with pillow between knees (side) or under knees (back) to reduce spine stress
For cervical radiculopathy: avoid prolonged neck flexion (looking down at phone); use cervical pillow
Do not stop gabapentin/pregabalin abruptly - taper under medical guidance to avoid withdrawal
Neuropathic pain medications (gabapentin, pregabalin) take 2-4 weeks to reach full effect
Physical therapy exercises should be continued daily at home for best outcomes
Do not drive while taking opioids or sedating muscle relaxants
Follow up with primary care or neurology in 2-4 weeks to assess treatment response

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Smoking cessation to improve disc nutrition and surgical outcomes (smoking accelerates disc degeneration)
Weight loss if BMI >25 to reduce spinal load and improve symptoms
Core strengthening exercises to support spine (plank, bird-dog, bridges)
Proper lifting technique: bend at knees, keep load close, avoid twisting
Ergonomic workstation setup: monitor at eye level, lumbar support, feet flat
Take breaks every 30-60 minutes if seated for prolonged periods
Maintain good posture: shoulders back, chin tucked, avoid forward head position
Regular low-impact exercise (walking, swimming, stationary bike) to maintain fitness
Avoid high-impact activities (running, jumping) during acute phase
Yoga or Pilates (modified) for flexibility and core strength after acute phase resolves
Use supportive mattress; avoid sleeping on stomach
Manage stress as tension can worsen muscle spasm and pain perception
Glycemic control if diabetic (HbA1c <7%) to reduce neuropathic component and improve surgical outcomes

Small Fiber Neuropathy.title: Small Fiber Neuropathy
Small Fiber Neuropathy.scope: ** Diagnosis and management of small fiber neuropathy presenting with painful sensory and/or autonomic symptoms with normal or near-normal nerve conduction studies. Includes length-dependent and non-length-dependent (ganglionopathy) patterns. Covers etiologic workup for treatable causes, symptomatic pain management, and autonomic symptom treatment.

Current glycemic status; impaired fasting glucose
Impaired glucose tolerance causes SFN even with normal HbA1c
Renal function; medication dosing; uremic neuropathy
Baseline; anemia evaluation
B12 deficiency causes SFN; common and treatable
Hypothyroidism causes neuropathy
Inflammatory markers; vasculitis screen
Autoimmune etiology; Sjogren's screen
Sjogren syndrome is common cause of SFN (up to 40% of SFN)
HCV-associated neuropathy; cryoglobulinemia

Extended Workup.rationale: More sensitive for B12 deficiency if B12 borderline (200-400)
Celiac disease causes SFN even without GI symptoms
Both deficiency and excess cause neuropathy
Sjogren syndrome if clinical suspicion high and serology negative

Confirm Fabry disease if enzyme low or high clinical suspicion
Hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis; early SFN with autonomic symptoms

AL amyloidosis screen

Referrals & Consults.item: Neuromuscular specialist for skin biopsy interpretation and complex SFN management
Rheumatology if Sjogren's, lupus, or other connective tissue disease suspected
Endocrinology if diabetes/prediabetes for glycemic optimization and metabolic management
Genetics counselor if hereditary etiology suspected (Fabry, TTR amyloidosis, SCN9A channelopathies)
Gastroenterology for celiac confirmation, gastroparesis management, or liver biopsy if amyloid suspected
Cardiology if TTR amyloidosis suspected or autonomic symptoms with cardiac involvement
Pain management for refractory neuropathic pain and interventional options (spinal cord stimulation)
Physical therapy for balance training, strengthening, and fall prevention
Autonomic disorders specialist if complex autonomic symptoms (POTS, orthostatic hypotension)
Psychiatry/psychology for chronic pain coping and comorbid depression/anxiety management
Hematology/oncology if amyloidosis confirmed for staging and treatment

Patient Instructions.item: Report any new weakness, gait difficulty, or falls as these may indicate progression to large fiber involvement
Monitor for signs of infection in feet (redness, warmth, drainage) if sensation is impaired
Keep a pain diary to track triggers, severity, and medication response
Rise slowly from sitting or lying to prevent falls from orthostatic hypotension
Increase salt and fluid intake (2-3L/day, 6-10g sodium) if orthostatic hypotension present (unless contraindicated)
Wear compression stockings before rising in the morning if orthostatic hypotension diagnosed
Take all prescribed pain medications as directed; do not stop gabapentinoids or SNRIs abruptly
Avoid excessive heat exposure which can worsen symptoms; stay hydrated in warm weather
Return if severe headache, vision changes, or syncope develop (may indicate medication side effects or disease progression)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Strict glycemic control (HbA1c <7% or <5.7% if prediabetes) to prevent progression; lifestyle modifications first
Alcohol cessation as alcohol independently causes and worsens small fiber neuropathy
Smoking cessation as smoking impairs nerve regeneration and worsens outcomes
Regular low-impact exercise (swimming, stationary bike, walking) to improve pain and maintain function
Healthy diet (Mediterranean or DASH) to optimize metabolic health and reduce inflammation
Weight management as metabolic syndrome is associated with SFN
Sleep hygiene to improve sleep quality; chronic pain worsens with poor sleep
Stress reduction techniques (mindfulness, meditation) as stress can amplify pain perception
Fall prevention with home safety evaluation given proprioceptive deficits and orthostatic hypotension
Avoid B6 (pyridoxine) supplementation above RDA (1.3-2 mg/day) as excess causes neuropathy

Myasthenia Gravis - Outpatient Managemen.title: Myasthenia Gravis - Outpatient Management
Myasthenia Gravis - Outpatient Managemen.scope: ** Outpatient diagnosis, management, and monitoring of myasthenia gravis in adults. Covers antibody-positive (AChR, MuSK, LRP4) and seronegative MG, ocular and generalized subtypes, pyridostigmine optimization, immunotherapy initiation and monitoring, thymectomy evaluation, and crisis prevention. Excludes myasthenic crisis (see "Myasthenia Gravis - Exacerbation/Crisis"), Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS), congenital myasthenic syndromes, and drug-induced myasthenia.

Increases sensitivity when combined with binding antibody
Additional AChR antibody; may be positive when binding negative
Order if AChR negative; positive in ~40% of AChR-negative patients

Thymoma association; if positive, high likelihood of thymoma
Autoimmune thyroid disease common comorbidity (10-15%)
Baseline before immunotherapy; infection assessment
Baseline renal/hepatic function; electrolytes

Before rituximab or other B-cell depleting therapy

Referrals & Consults.item: Neuromuscular specialist/MG center for diagnosis confirmation, treatment optimization, and clinical trial consideration
Thoracic surgery consult for thymectomy evaluation in AChR+ generalized MG age 18-65 years without thymoma, or any patient with thymoma
Pulmonology consult for baseline pulmonary function testing and ongoing respiratory monitoring in patients with respiratory symptoms
Neuro-ophthalmology for diplopia management, prism prescription, or ptosis surgery evaluation in stable ocular MG
Speech therapy for swallow evaluation given bulbar symptoms and aspiration risk assessment
Physical therapy for generalized weakness to maintain function and prevent deconditioning
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment and energy conservation strategies given fatigable weakness
Rheumatology if concurrent autoimmune disease suspected (thyroid, lupus, rheumatoid arthritis)
Infusion center for IVIg, rituximab, eculizumab, or other IV immunotherapy administration
High-risk OB for pregnancy planning in women with MG given medication adjustments and delivery planning
Endocrinology for steroid-induced diabetes, osteoporosis, or adrenal insufficiency management
Social work for disability planning, MG Foundation resources, and insurance navigation for expensive biologics
Psychiatry for depression or anxiety related to chronic illness or steroid side effects

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately if worsening weakness, breathing difficulty, or difficulty swallowing develops (may indicate crisis requiring hospitalization)
Carry MG medical alert card or bracelet listing diagnosis and medications to avoid (aminoglycosides, fluoroquinolones, beta-blockers, magnesium)
Do not stop prednisone or immunosuppressants abruptly; sudden discontinuation may trigger exacerbation or adrenal crisis
Take pyridostigmine 30-60 minutes before meals to improve swallowing and reduce choking risk during eating
Report fever or signs of infection promptly as immunosuppression increases infection risk and infection can trigger MG exacerbation
Avoid extreme heat as high temperatures worsen neuromuscular transmission and increase weakness
Do not drive if diplopia or ptosis impairs vision; symptoms may fluctuate throughout the day
Avoid overexertion; pace activities throughout the day with rest periods to manage fatigable weakness
Report new medications (including over-the-counter) to neurologist before taking, as many common drugs worsen MG
Women: Discuss pregnancy plans with MG specialist in advance as medication adjustments are needed before conception
Contact Myasthenia Gravis Foundation of America (www.myasthenia.org) for patient support, educational resources, and community
Report symptoms of cholinergic overdose: excessive secretions, diarrhea, cramping, muscle twitching, bradycardia (reduce pyridostigmine dose)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Medication reconciliation before any new prescription to avoid MG-exacerbating drugs; bring medication list to all appointments
Avoid live vaccines while on immunosuppression (azathioprine, mycophenolate, rituximab, high-dose steroids); inactivated vaccines are safe
Annual influenza vaccine (inactivated) to prevent respiratory infections that can trigger exacerbation
Pneumococcal vaccination (PCV15 or PCV20 + PPSV23) before starting immunosuppression
Aspiration precautions including upright positioning during and after meals, small bites, and avoiding mixed textures if bulbar symptoms present
Energy conservation techniques including pacing activities, scheduled rest periods, and prioritizing important tasks for morning
Avoid smoking as respiratory infections worsen MG and smoking reduces treatment efficacy
Limit alcohol intake as it can worsen weakness and interact with medications
Stress management as psychological stress can trigger MG exacerbations
Good sleep hygiene as fatigue and sleep deprivation worsen MG symptoms
Wear medical alert identification listing MG diagnosis and medications to avoid in emergencies
Weight management to reduce respiratory load and minimize steroid side effects

differential.features: Proximal weakness improves with exercise; autonomic symptoms (dry mouth); SCLC association; areflexia
differential.tests: VGCC antibody; EMG with incremental response; CT chest for malignancy

differential.features: Descending paralysis; fixed dilated pupils; GI symptoms; recent wound or food exposure

differential.tests: Genetic testing (GCN repeat in PABPN1); muscle biopsy

differential.features: Proptosis; lid retraction (not ptosis); restrictive ophthalmopathy; thyroid dysfunction
differential.tests: TSH, free T4; orbital CT/MRI (extraocular muscle enlargement)

Acute worsening of weakness; new respiratory symptoms (dyspnea, orthopnea); difficulty swallowing or speaking; recent infection or medication change with weakness; FVC declining on outpatient checks
Refractory MG not responding to standard therapy; thymectomy evaluation; clinical trial consideration; complex immunotherapy decisions

Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) / Mo.title: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) / Motor Neuron Disease
Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) / Mo.scope: ** Comprehensive outpatient-focused management of ALS including diagnostic workup, El Escorial/Awaji criteria application, disease-modifying therapy (riluzole, edaravone, AMX0035), symptomatic management (sialorrhea, spasticity, pseudobulbar affect, pain, dyspnea), respiratory monitoring with BiPAP timing, nutritional support with PEG timing, multidisciplinary clinic model, and palliative care integration. Excludes primary lateral sclerosis (PLS), progressive muscular atrophy (PMA), and pediatric motor neuron disease.

Thyroid disease can mimic weakness
B12 deficiency causes myelopathy

Exclude monoclonal gammopathy
Baseline; UTI assessment

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology (ALS specialist/multidisciplinary clinic) for diagnosis confirmation, disease-modifying therapy, and comprehensive management coordination
Pulmonology for respiratory function monitoring, BiPAP initiation, and ventilator management decisions
Physical therapy for mobility assessment, strengthening (submaximal), range of motion, and assistive device prescription
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, adaptive equipment, energy conservation, and home modification
Speech-language pathology for swallow evaluation, communication strategies, and AAC device assessment
Respiratory therapy for BiPAP setup and titration, cough assist training, and secretion management
Nutrition/dietitian for caloric needs assessment, weight optimization, and tube feeding management
Palliative care for symptom management, goals of care discussions, and quality of life optimization
Social work for financial resources (SSDI, Medicaid), caregiver support, and ALS Association resources
Psychiatry/psychology for depression, anxiety, and adjustment disorder common in ALS
Gastroenterology for PEG placement when FVC declining toward 50% or significant dysphagia
Hospice care for end-of-life care when prognosis <6 months and/or patient declines aggressive interventions
Genetic counseling for familial ALS, gene testing interpretation, and family planning implications

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately for increased shortness of breath, choking episodes, or inability to clear secretions (may indicate respiratory failure requiring urgent intervention)
Return for fever, worsening cough, or change in sputum color (may indicate aspiration pneumonia)
Do not drive if experiencing significant weakness or fatigue that could impair vehicle control
Continue eating foods that are safe to swallow; use thickened liquids if recommended by speech therapy
Use BiPAP as prescribed, even if initially uncomfortable; adherence improves symptoms and survival
Perform prescribed exercises but avoid exhaustion; rest before becoming overly fatigued
Complete advance directives including healthcare proxy, living will, and decisions about mechanical ventilation and feeding tubes
Contact ALS Association (www.als.org) for educational resources, support groups, and equipment loan programs
Attend multidisciplinary ALS clinic visits every 2-3 months for comprehensive care coordination
Consider joining ALS research registries and clinical trials (www.clinicaltrials.gov)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Aspiration precautions including upright positioning during meals, small bites, and chin-tuck swallowing technique
Energy conservation with scheduled rest periods and prioritization of activities to reduce fatigue
Home safety evaluation to remove fall hazards, install grab bars, and ensure wheelchair accessibility
Maintain optimal nutrition with high-calorie, high-protein diet; weight loss accelerates decline
Sleep with head of bed elevated 30 degrees if using BiPAP or experiencing orthopnea
Smoking cessation is essential to optimize respiratory function and reduce aspiration risk
Limit alcohol as it may worsen weakness, sedation, and respiratory depression
Frequent repositioning if immobile to prevent pressure ulcers
Emotional and spiritual support for patient and caregivers; caregiver burnout is common
Consider assistive technology early (voice banking, eye-tracking devices) before speech becomes unintelligible

Dystonia.title: Dystonia
Dystonia.scope: ** Diagnosis, classification, workup for secondary causes, and symptomatic management of dystonia. Covers focal (cervical, blepharospasm, writer's cramp), segmental, and generalized forms. Includes evaluation for Wilson's disease, dopa-responsive dystonia, and drug-induced dystonia.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; exclude systemic illness
Electrolyte abnormalities can exacerbate movement disorders

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Screen for hepatic dysfunction suggesting Wilson's disease
Wilson's disease screen; essential for age <50 with dystonia
Hyperthyroidism can cause movement disorders

Extended Workup.rationale: Wilson's disease confirmation if ceruloplasmin low/borderline
Interpret with ceruloplasmin (low free copper ratio in Wilson's)
Deficiency causes myelopathy and movement disorders
Hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia can cause movement disorders
Elevated in dystonia crises, NMS, prolonged dystonic posturing

Dopa-responsive dystonia; neurotransmitter disorders
Chorea-acanthocytosis, McLeod syndrome
Lysosomal storage disorders (GM1, GM2 gangliosidosis)
Autoimmune dystonia (rare)
Paraneoplastic dystonia
