Referrals & Consults.item: Movement disorders neurology for diagnosis confirmation, classification, and treatment planning
Ophthalmology for slit lamp examination to evaluate for Kayser-Fleischer rings (Wilson's disease workup)
Hepatology if Wilson's disease diagnosed for hepatic management and transplant evaluation if severe
Genetic counseling if genetic dystonia confirmed or suspected (DYT1, DYT6, GCH1)
Neurosurgery consultation for DBS evaluation if medication-refractory
Physical therapy for posture correction, stretching, and range of motion exercises
Occupational therapy for adaptive techniques and assistive devices for ADLs
Speech therapy if oromandibular dystonia, laryngeal dystonia, or cervical dystonia affecting swallowing
Pain management if chronic pain from dystonic posturing not controlled with primary treatment
Psychology/psychiatry for coping strategies, depression/anxiety management related to chronic dystonia

Patient Instructions.item: After botulinum toxin injection: avoid rubbing injection sites; effects develop over 3-14 days and last 10-12 weeks
Report any swallowing difficulty or breathing problems after botulinum toxin injection (may indicate spread)
Use sensory tricks (geste antagoniste) such as touching chin or face which may temporarily reduce cervical dystonia
Return to ED if severe muscle spasms with fever, confusion, or dark urine (possible dystonic storm or rhabdomyolysis)
Continue physical therapy exercises at home to maintain range of motion and prevent contractures
Avoid medications that worsen dystonia: metoclopramide, prochlorperazine, haloperidol, and other dopamine blockers
For Wilson's disease: strict adherence to copper chelation is lifelong; follow dietary copper restrictions
Keep a symptom diary noting triggers, sensory tricks that help, and response to medications

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Stress management with relaxation techniques as stress can exacerbate dystonia
Adequate sleep as fatigue worsens dystonia symptoms
Limit caffeine and stimulants which may worsen tremor/dystonia
Regular gentle exercise (swimming, yoga) to maintain flexibility without overexertion
Ergonomic workstation modifications for task-specific dystonia (writer's cramp, musician's dystonia)
For Wilson's disease: avoid high-copper foods (liver, shellfish, chocolate, nuts, mushrooms) especially during initial treatment
Avoid alcohol especially if on benzodiazepines or with hepatic involvement (Wilson's)
Heat application to affected muscles may provide temporary relief
Support groups for dystonia provide coping strategies and community connection

Referrals & Consults.item: Huntington Disease Society of America (HDSA) Center of Excellence for comprehensive multidisciplinary care
Genetic counselor for pre-test counseling, results disclosure, and family testing discussion
Psychiatry for depression, suicidality assessment, irritability, and psychosis management
Neuropsychology for baseline and serial cognitive assessment to guide care planning
Speech-language pathology for swallowing evaluation and communication strategies
Physical therapy for gait training, fall prevention, and adaptive exercise program
Occupational therapy for ADL adaptation, home safety evaluation, and energy conservation
Dietitian/nutritionist for weight maintenance strategies and caloric supplementation
Social work for caregiver support, disability planning, and community resources
Palliative care for symptom management, advance care planning, and goals of care discussions
Pulmonology for respiratory assessment in advanced disease and ventilation decisions
Gastroenterology for PEG tube placement consideration in advanced dysphagia

Patient Instructions.item: CRITICAL: Report suicidal thoughts immediately as depression is common and treatable in HD
Do not drive if experiencing significant chorea, cognitive impairment, or sedating medication effects
Maintain high caloric intake (3000-4000 kcal/day may be needed) due to hypermetabolic state
Eat slowly, take small bites, and remain upright 30 minutes after meals to reduce aspiration risk
Complete advance directive and healthcare power of attorney while capacity is preserved
Inform all healthcare providers about HD as many common medications can worsen symptoms
First-degree relatives have 50% risk; genetic counseling available but genetic testing is a personal choice
Avoid alcohol which worsens balance, cognition, and interacts with medications

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular aerobic exercise (walking, swimming, stationary bike) improves motor function and mood
Fall prevention: remove home hazards, adequate lighting, grab bars, non-slip surfaces
Maintain social engagement and meaningful activities to reduce depression and apathy
Cognitive engagement through puzzles, reading, and structured activities may help maintain function
Structure daily routine with consistent timing for medications, meals, and activities
Caregiver respite and support groups essential to prevent caregiver burnout
Smoking cessation to reduce aspiration pneumonia risk and cardiovascular disease
Limit caffeine if insomnia or anxiety are problematic

Referrals & Consults.item: Psychiatry consultation for antipsychotic management, dose reduction, or switch to lower-risk agent (ESSENTIAL - requires collaborative decision-making)
Movement disorders neurology for diagnosis confirmation, AIMS scoring, and VMAT2 inhibitor initiation
Neurosurgery consultation for DBS evaluation if medication-refractory disabling TD
Speech therapy for dysphagia evaluation if oropharyngeal involvement
Occupational therapy for adaptive strategies if hand involvement affects function
Social work for disability evaluation and resources if TD causes functional impairment
Dentistry for oral health evaluation with orofacial TD (tooth damage, denture issues)

Patient Instructions.item: Report any worsening movements, difficulty swallowing, or breathing problems immediately (may indicate progression)
Do not stop antipsychotic medications without psychiatry guidance as this can worsen psychosis or cause withdrawal dyskinesia
Report any new or worsening depression, suicidal thoughts, or mood changes on VMAT2 inhibitors (boxed warning)
Movements may temporarily worsen after stopping causative drug before improving (withdrawal dyskinesia)
VMAT2 inhibitors may take 2-6 weeks to show maximum benefit; continue as prescribed
Avoid caffeine and stimulants which may worsen involuntary movements
Maintain regular dental visits for oral health if orofacial TD present (prevents tooth damage, ulceration)
Consider support groups and counseling for coping with visible movement disorder

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Use lowest effective antipsychotic dose for shortest duration needed (primary prevention)
Perform AIMS examination at baseline, 3 months, 6 months, then q6-12 months on dopamine-blocking agents
Prefer second-generation antipsychotics over first-generation when clinically appropriate (lower TD risk)
Avoid metoclopramide for >12 weeks; use domperidone or other alternatives when possible (not available in US)

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology/Cognitive neurology for diagnosis confirmation, biomarker interpretation, and treatment planning
Neuropsychology for formal cognitive testing (MoCA insufficient) to establish baseline and track progression
Geriatric psychiatry for BPSD management and capacity evaluation when decision-making ability questioned
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, cognitive strategies, and home safety evaluation
Speech therapy for communication strategies and swallowing evaluation if dysphagia develops
Social work for caregiver support resources, community services, and long-term care planning
Palliative care for advanced AD symptom management and goals of care discussions
Elder law attorney for advance directives, healthcare proxy, and financial planning while capacity exists
Genetics counseling for early-onset AD (<65) families or those considering predictive testing
Driving rehabilitation specialist for formal on-road driving evaluation when ability is questioned
Infusion center coordination for anti-amyloid therapy administration and ARIA monitoring

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately if sudden worsening of confusion which may indicate stroke, infection, or medication toxicity
If on anti-amyloid therapy (lecanemab, donanemab): return immediately for new headache, visual changes, confusion, or unsteadiness (possible ARIA)
Complete advance directives (living will, healthcare proxy, POLST) while patient has capacity to document preferences for future care
Designate financial power of attorney and consider trust arrangements early while patient can participate
Do not drive until cleared by physician or formal driving evaluation; report diagnosis to DMV per state requirements
Use pill organizers, alarms, or caregiver supervision to ensure medication adherence
Wear medical alert bracelet with diagnosis and emergency contact in case of wandering
Keep environment safe: remove throw rugs, install grab bars, secure stove knobs, lock away dangerous items
Maintain consistent daily routines which help with orientation and reduce anxiety

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular aerobic exercise (150 min/week moderate intensity) may slow cognitive decline and improve mood
Mediterranean or MIND diet emphasizing vegetables, berries, fish, whole grains, nuts, and olive oil
Cognitive stimulation through reading, puzzles, music, social activities to support cognitive reserve
Adequate sleep (7-8 hours); treat sleep apnea aggressively as it worsens cognition
Social engagement and meaningful activities to reduce isolation and support emotional well-being
Cardiovascular risk factor control: BP <130/80, A1c <7%, LDL <100 to reduce vascular contribution
Hearing aids for hearing loss which is a modifiable dementia risk factor (Lancet Commission)
Limit alcohol to ≤1 drink daily; excess alcohol accelerates cognitive decline
Smoking cessation to reduce vascular damage and improve overall brain health
Caregiver respite services to prevent burnout; Alzheimer's Association support groups

Referrals & Consults.item: Cognitive/behavioral neurology for diagnosis confirmation using McKeith criteria and treatment planning
Movement disorders specialist if motor symptoms prominent or considering dopaminergic therapy
Neuropsychology for comprehensive cognitive testing to establish baseline and differentiate from AD
Geriatric psychiatry for behavioral symptoms, medication management, and capacity evaluation
Sleep medicine for polysomnography to confirm REM sleep behavior disorder (indicative biomarker)
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, cognitive strategies, and home safety evaluation
Physical therapy for gait training, balance exercises, and fall prevention
Speech therapy for communication strategies and swallowing evaluation if dysphagia present
Social work for caregiver support, community resources, and long-term care planning
Palliative care for advanced dementia symptom management and goals of care discussions
Cardiology if orthostatic hypotension refractory to first-line treatment

Patient Instructions.item: CRITICAL: Avoid all typical antipsychotics and most atypical antipsychotics - severe sensitivity can cause parkinsonism, rigidity, and death
Carry a medication alert card listing "Lewy Body Dementia - Neuroleptic Sensitivity" for all healthcare encounters
Report visual hallucinations immediately as these may indicate disease progression or medication effect
Rise slowly from sitting or lying to prevent falls from orthostatic hypotension
Implement safety measures for REM sleep behavior disorder: padded bed rails, mattress on floor, remove sharp objects from bedside
Complete advance directives while patient has capacity to document wishes for future care
Do not drive due to fluctuating attention, visual-spatial deficits, and hallucinations
Return immediately if sudden worsening of confusion, falls, or inability to walk (may indicate medication effect or infection)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Fall prevention: remove home hazards, adequate lighting, grab bars, non-slip surfaces due to high fall risk
AVOID medications that worsen symptoms: anticholinergics, antihistamines (diphenhydramine), sleep aids (Benadryl, Tylenol PM)
AVOID antiemetics: metoclopramide, prochlorperazine, promethazine (D2 blocking worsens parkinsonism)
Regular physical exercise as tolerated to maintain mobility and reduce fall risk
Structured daily routine with consistent sleep-wake times helps with fluctuating cognition
Adequate lighting and avoid overstimulation which may trigger hallucinations
Simplify environment and reduce visual clutter to minimize misperceptions
Caregiver education about fluctuating cognition, which is characteristic and not willful
Treat sleep apnea if present as it worsens cognition and autonomic dysfunction

Vascular Dementia.title: Vascular Dementia
Vascular Dementia.scope: ** Diagnosis using NINDS-AIREN and DSM-5 criteria, neuroimaging evaluation for strategic infarcts and white matter disease, vascular risk factor modification, secondary stroke prevention, cholinesterase inhibitors for cognitive symptoms, and management of post-stroke depression, apathy, and behavioral symptoms. Primarily outpatient-focused with coverage for ED and hospital presentations.

UTI common cause of acute confusion in elderly

Inflammatory marker; elevated predicts vascular events
Deficiency associated with cognitive decline and vascular disease

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology/Cognitive neurology for diagnosis confirmation, differentiation from AD, and treatment planning
Neuropsychology for formal cognitive testing to characterize executive dysfunction and memory profile
Cardiology for atrial fibrillation management, anticoagulation decisions, and heart failure optimization
Vascular surgery consultation for symptomatic carotid stenosis ≥50% to evaluate for endarterectomy
Physical therapy for gait training, balance assessment, and fall prevention given motor involvement
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, cognitive strategies, and home safety evaluation
Speech therapy for communication strategies, cognitive-linguistic exercises, and swallowing evaluation if dysphagia
Social work for caregiver support resources, community services, and long-term care planning
Geriatric psychiatry for behavioral symptoms, depression management, and capacity evaluation
Registered dietitian for Mediterranean/DASH diet counseling and sodium restriction education
Smoking cessation program with pharmacotherapy for current smokers
Sleep medicine for obstructive sleep apnea evaluation and CPAP initiation if indicated
Palliative care for advanced vascular dementia symptom management and goals of care discussions

Patient Instructions.item: Call 911 immediately if new stroke symptoms develop (sudden weakness, speech difficulty, vision changes)
Return immediately if sudden worsening of confusion which may indicate new stroke, infection, or delirium
Take all medications as prescribed especially antiplatelet/anticoagulant and statin which prevent further strokes
Complete advance directives (living will, healthcare proxy, POLST) while patient has capacity
Do not drive if cognitive impairment affects judgment or reaction time; formal driving evaluation may be needed
Use pill organizers, alarms, or caregiver supervision to ensure medication adherence
Check blood pressure at home regularly; notify provider if consistently >140/90 or <90/60
Wear medical alert bracelet with diagnosis and emergency contact in case of wandering or emergency
Keep environment safe: remove throw rugs, install grab bars, ensure adequate lighting, secure stove knobs

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Blood pressure target <130/80 mmHg to reduce progression and prevent further strokes (SPRINT-MIND data)
LDL target <70 mg/dL with high-intensity statin for secondary vascular prevention
Smoking cessation immediately; reduces stroke risk by 50% within 1 year of quitting
Mediterranean or MIND diet emphasizing vegetables, berries, fish, whole grains, nuts, and olive oil
Limit sodium to <2300 mg/day (ideally <1500 mg if hypertensive) to improve blood pressure control
Limit alcohol to ≤1 drink daily as excess alcohol increases stroke risk and worsens cognition
Regular aerobic exercise (150 min/week moderate intensity) to improve cardiovascular health and cognition
Treat obstructive sleep apnea with CPAP as OSA worsens vascular risk and cognitive function
Strict glycemic control (HbA1c <7% or individualized 7-8% in frail elderly) to reduce microvascular damage
Social engagement and cognitive stimulation to support cognitive reserve
Weight management with target BMI 18.5-27 kg/m² (less stringent in elderly)
Fall prevention with home safety modifications and assistive devices as needed
CPAP compliance for sleep apnea patients to reduce nocturnal hypoxia and vascular events

differential.features: Insidious onset; gradual decline; memory predominant; no focal signs; no stepwise progression
differential.tests: MRI: hippocampal atrophy without significant WM disease; CSF Aβ42 low, p-tau elevated; amyloid PET positive

differential.features: Features of both; memory impairment with vascular burden
differential.tests: Amyloid PET positive with significant WM disease; CSF biomarkers show AD pattern

differential.features: Visual hallucinations; parkinsonism; REM sleep behavior disorder; fluctuating cognition

differential.features: Personality/behavior changes; disinhibition; apathy; hyperorality; often age <65
differential.tests: FDG-PET frontal hypometabolism; less vascular disease on MRI

differential.features: Triad: gait disturbance (prominent), urinary incontinence, dementia; ventriculomegaly disproportionate to atrophy
differential.tests: MRI: ventriculomegaly with effaced sulci; high-volume LP with gait improvement

differential.features: History of repetitive head trauma; mood and behavioral changes; no diagnostic test in life
differential.tests: History; clinical pattern; cavum septum pellucidum on MRI (suggestive)

differential.features: Migraine with aura; early WM disease; family history; temporal pole and external capsule involvement
differential.tests: NOTCH3 genetic testing; skin biopsy showing GOM deposits

differential.features: Younger age; headache; encephalopathy; multifocal strokes; elevated inflammatory markers
differential.tests: Vessel wall MRI; DSA; brain/leptomeningeal biopsy

differential.features: Rapid progression (weeks-months); myoclonus; periodic sharp waves on EEG; MRI DWI ribboning
differential.tests: CSF RT-QuIC; 14-3-3; EEG

differential.features: Acute change; fluctuating attention; identifiable precipitant (infection, medication, metabolic)
differential.tests: Treat cause; reassess cognition when clear

Frontotemporal Dementia.title: Frontotemporal Dementia

Frontotemporal Dementia.scope: ** Diagnosis and management of frontotemporal lobar degeneration syndromes including behavioral variant FTD (bvFTD), semantic variant primary progressive aphasia (svPPA), nonfluent/agrammatic variant PPA (nfvPPA), FTD with motor neuron disease (FTD-ALS), and genetic forms (C9orf72, MAPT, GRN). Covers diagnostic evaluation, symptomatic treatment, behavioral management, genetic counseling, safety planning, and caregiver support. Primarily outpatient-focused with coverage for ED and hospital presentations of behavioral crises.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Rule out infection, anemia, malignancy contributing to behavioral changes
Metabolic causes of behavioral disturbance (hyponatremia, uremia, hypoglycemia)
Hypothyroidism can cause apathy; hyperthyroidism can cause behavioral changes
B12 deficiency causes neuropsychiatric symptoms and cognitive decline
Deficiency contributes to cognitive impairment
Hepatic encephalopathy; nutritional status; liver function for medications
Hypercalcemia causes neuropsychiatric symptoms
UTI common cause of acute behavioral changes in elderly

HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder if risk factors
Inflammatory or autoimmune causes; baseline before immunotherapy
Elevated in FTD-ALS; baseline for motor neuron involvement
If motor symptoms present; evaluate for ALS overlap
Low levels suggest GRN mutation (screening test)

Referrals & Consults.item: Behavioral/cognitive neurology for diagnosis confirmation, FTD subtype classification, and treatment guidance
Neuropsychology for comprehensive cognitive testing to establish baseline, characterize deficits, and track progression
Genetic counseling for all patients with suspected FTD given high heritability (30-50% familial); discuss testing implications
Speech-language pathology for language variant PPA evaluation, communication strategies, and swallowing assessment
Geriatric psychiatry for complex behavioral management and psychotropic medication optimization
Social work for caregiver support resources, community services, respite care, and long-term care planning
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, cognitive strategies, home safety evaluation, and activity structuring
Physical therapy for fall prevention, mobility assessment, and exercise program particularly if motor features present
Palliative care for symptom management and goals of care discussions, especially with advanced disease or ALS overlap
Neuromuscular specialist if motor neuron disease features (weakness, fasciculations, bulbar symptoms) present
Elder law attorney for advance directives, healthcare proxy, conservatorship, and financial planning while capacity exists

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately if sudden worsening of behavior, new weakness, difficulty breathing, or inability to swallow safely
Complete advance directives (living will, healthcare proxy, POLST) while patient retains capacity; FTD can progress rapidly
Designate durable power of attorney for healthcare AND finances early as judgment may be impaired before memory
Do not drive; FTD impairs judgment, impulse control, and decision-making even if memory appears intact
Remove access to weapons, power tools, and dangerous equipment due to impaired judgment and safety awareness
Supervise financial decisions; patients with FTD are vulnerable to fraud, impulsive spending, and poor judgment
Secure medications to prevent accidental or intentional overdose; use locked medication storage
Monitor for wandering; consider GPS tracking devices and door alarms as disease progresses
Report diagnosis to DMV per state requirements; most states require physician reporting for unsafe drivers
Genetic testing results have implications for family members; discuss with genetic counselor before testing

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Structured daily routine with consistent schedule reduces anxiety and behavioral symptoms
Regular physical activity (walking, supervised exercise) improves mood and maintains function
Simplified communication using short sentences, yes/no questions, and visual cues for PPA variants
Avoid overstimulation; reduce noise, crowds, and complex environments that trigger agitation
Caregiver education through AFTD (Association for Frontotemporal Degeneration) resources and support groups
Respite care for caregivers to prevent burnout; FTD caregiving is particularly demanding due to behavioral symptoms
Address hyperorality and dietary changes with portion control, healthy snack availability, and locked food storage if needed
Safe environment modifications: remove fall hazards, lock cabinets with dangerous items, install stove knob covers
One-to-one supervision may be needed for safety; consider adult day programs or in-home care
Smoking cessation and alcohol avoidance to prevent additional brain injury and drug interactions

Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus.title: Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus
Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus.scope: ** Comprehensive evaluation of suspected NPH, diagnostic workup including high-volume lumbar puncture (tap test), prediction of shunt responsiveness, neurosurgical referral, and post-shunt monitoring. Covers idiopathic NPH (most common) and secondary NPH. Does not cover acute obstructive hydrocephalus or pediatric hydrocephalus.

Electrolyte assessment; pre-surgical renal function
Pre-procedural assessment for LP and surgery
Hypothyroidism can cause cognitive impairment
B12 deficiency causes reversible dementia and gait ataxia
Rule out UTI as cause of incontinence or confusion
Diabetes contributes to small vessel disease and neuropathy

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately if sudden severe headache, new weakness, or altered consciousness develops (may indicate shunt malfunction or complication)

Keep scheduled follow-up appointments for shunt valve pressure adjustments and monitoring
Use assistive devices (walker, cane) as recommended by physical therapy to prevent falls

Adequate hydration to maintain optimal CSF dynamics; avoid dehydration
Bladder training program in conjunction with physical therapy for urinary symptoms

Patient Instructions.item: Vision typically improves over 2-4 weeks; 90%+ recover to 20/40 or better within 1 year
Return immediately if vision worsening after initial improvement (may indicate new attack or alternate diagnosis)
Return if new symptoms: weakness, numbness, imbalance, bladder problems (may indicate MS)
Do not drive if vision in affected eye prevents safe driving; check with state DMV regarding vision requirements
Heat may temporarily worsen symptoms (Uhthoff phenomenon) - this is not a new attack or permanent worsening
Expect temporary steroid side effects: insomnia, mood changes, increased appetite, metallic taste during IV infusion
Do not stop oral prednisone abruptly if on taper (adrenal suppression risk)
Monitor blood sugars if diabetic - steroids elevate glucose
Avoid sick contacts while on high-dose steroids (immunosuppression)
Keep follow-up appointments - important to monitor for MS development
Contact physician if fever, new headache, or worsening vision on steroids

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Smoking cessation - smoking increases MS conversion risk and worsens outcomes
Vitamin D supplementation 2000-5000 IU daily (target serum 25-OH vitamin D >40 ng/mL) - low levels associated with MS risk
Avoid prolonged heat exposure (hot tubs, saunas, exercising in heat) which can temporarily worsen vision (Uhthoff)
Use sunglasses if photophobia present
Regular aerobic exercise as tolerated once acute symptoms resolve
Adequate sleep (7-8 hours nightly) and stress management
Eye protection during activities if monocular vision (loss of depth perception)

Acute Myelopathy Evaluation.title: Acute Myelopathy Evaluation
icd10: G95.89 (Other specified diseases of spinal cord)

Acute Myelopathy Evaluation.scope: ** Acute or subacute spinal cord dysfunction — broad differential approach. Covers urgent MRI, LP, and comprehensive workup to differentiate compressive (epidural abscess, tumor, disc herniation, hematoma) from non-compressive causes (inflammatory/demyelinating, vascular, infectious). Compressive myelopathy is a surgical emergency. Excludes chronic cervical spondylotic myelopathy, cauda equina syndrome (separate template), and isolated radiculopathy.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Infection screen (epidural abscess); baseline; leukocytosis
Renal/hepatic function for contrast and medication dosing; electrolytes
Markedly elevated in epidural abscess (>20 in ~95%); elevated in inflammatory/autoimmune
Elevated in infection, inflammation; useful for monitoring treatment response
If epidural abscess or infection suspected; S. aureus most common
Coagulopathy causing epidural hematoma; pre-LP; pre-surgical assessment
Diabetic risk factor for epidural abscess; baseline
UTI as source for epidural abscess; baseline bladder function
Potential surgical intervention
Bacterial infection differentiation

MOGAD — often presents as myelitis; treatment implications differ from MS and NMOSD

Copper deficiency myelopathy (mimics B12 deficiency pattern)

Bell's Palsy / Idiopathic Facial Paralys.scope: ** Diagnosis and management of Bell's palsy (idiopathic facial nerve palsy) in adults. Covers workup to exclude secondary causes, medical treatment, and eye protection. Includes Ramsay Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster oticus) which requires different treatment. Excludes central facial palsy (stroke), facial nerve tumors, traumatic facial nerve injury, and bilateral facial palsy workup.

Brain Metastases.title: Brain Metastases
icd10: C79.32 (Secondary malignant neoplasm of cerebral meninges)

Brain Metastases.scope: ** Management of newly diagnosed or progressive brain metastases in adults. Covers initial stabilization, vasogenic edema management with corticosteroids, seizure management, imaging evaluation, molecular/histopathologic workup, treatment modalities (surgery, stereotactic radiosurgery, whole-brain radiation, systemic therapy with CNS penetration), and disposition. Excludes primary brain tumors (separate template), leptomeningeal carcinomatosis (partially addressed), and spinal metastases (separate template).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; chemotherapy planning; leukocytosis/infection; thrombocytopenia (bleeding risk, treatment candidacy)
Essential/Core Labs.target: WBC, platelets within normal limits; ALC (absolute lymphocyte count) for immunotherapy eligibility

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Renal function for contrast imaging; hepatic function for chemotherapy dosing; electrolytes (SIADH from brain lesions); glucose (steroid hyperglycemia)
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; anticipate glucose elevation with dexamethasone

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Coagulopathy assessment; surgical candidacy; hemorrhagic metastases (melanoma, RCC, choriocarcinoma, thyroid)
Steroid-induced hyperglycemia; baseline before dexamethasone

Treatment planning; β-hCG-secreting tumors (choriocarcinoma, germ cell); radiation contraindication in pregnancy
Essential/Core Labs.target: Negative; if elevated consider choriocarcinoma or germ cell tumor

Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; abnormal may indicate thyroid primary

Rare/Specialized.target: Normal; elevated protein and low glucose suggest LMD

Lumbar Puncture.target: Cytology: malignant cells (50% sensitivity single LP; repeat improves to ~80%); elevated opening pressure; elevated protein (>50 mg/dL); low glucose (<40 mg/dL or <60% serum); lymphocytic pleocytosis

Essential/First-line.target: Number/size/location of metastases; ring-enhancement pattern; hemorrhagic component; leptomeningeal enhancement; dural-based vs. parenchymal
Essential/First-line.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; GFR <30 (gadolinium risk); severe claustrophobia
