Intracerebral Hemorrhage (ICH).title: Intracerebral Hemorrhage (ICH)
Intracerebral Hemorrhage (ICH).scope: ** Spontaneous (non-traumatic) intracerebral hemorrhage in adults. Covers acute BP management, anticoagulant reversal, ICH score and prognosis, ICP management, surgical indications, etiology workup, and secondary prevention. Excludes traumatic ICH, subarachnoid hemorrhage (separate template), hemorrhagic transformation of ischemic stroke, and subdural/epidural hematomas.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; thrombocytopenia as cause or complication; transfusion needs
Warfarin-related ICH requires emergent reversal; coagulopathy assessment
Heparin-related ICH; coagulopathy
DIC; consumptive coagulopathy; tPA-related hemorrhage
Electrolytes; renal function for contrast/medication; hepatic function for coagulopathy
Hyperglycemia worsens ICH outcomes; hypoglycemia mimics stroke
Potential need for blood products, surgery, reversal agents
Essential/Core Labs.target: On file; crossmatch if OR likely

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Neurogenic cardiac injury (stress cardiomyopathy); concurrent ACS
Coagulopathy; exam reliability; alcoholism is ICH risk factor
Cocaine/amphetamine-associated ICH (sympathomimetic surge)
Affects management (eclampsia differential; imaging)

Essential/Core Labs.item: Thrombin time (TT) and/or ecarin clotting time (ECT)
Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Dabigatran (direct thrombin inhibitor) detection; if patient on DOACs
Rivaroxaban/apixaban/edoxaban detection; guides reversal need

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Young patient ICH without clear etiology; cerebral venous thrombosis with secondary hemorrhage
CNS vasculitis-related hemorrhage
Sympathomimetic drug use; synthetic drug-associated hemorrhage
Cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA) confirmation; research context
Rare/Specialized.target: Positive amyloid deposition in lobar distribution

Rare/Specialized.rationale: CAA risk stratification; APOE ε2/ε4 associated with ICH

Essential/First-line.timing: Door-to-CT <25 minutes; determines ICH diagnosis, location, volume, IVH, hydrocephalus, midline shift
Essential/First-line.target: Hemorrhage location (deep: basal ganglia/thalamus = hypertensive; lobar: CAA, tumor, AVM), volume (ABC/2 method), intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), hydrocephalus, midline shift >5mm

Essential/First-line.timing: With initial CT; identify "spot sign" (active contrast extravasation = hematoma expansion risk), underlying vascular malformation (AVM, aneurysm)
Essential/First-line.target: Spot sign (30-50% risk of expansion); AVM; aneurysm; dural AV fistula; Moyamoya
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Contrast allergy; renal impairment (benefit outweighs risk in emergency)

Essential/First-line.timing: Baseline; neurogenic cardiac injury; arrhythmia; QTc prolongation risk
Essential/First-line.target: Normal; ST changes may be neurogenic

Essential/First-line.timing: At 6h and 24h OR any neurologic decline; assess for hematoma expansion (>33% or >6mL increase from baseline = significant expansion)
Essential/First-line.target: Stable hematoma size; no new hemorrhage; no hydrocephalus progression

Extended.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (include GRE/SWI sequences)
Extended.timing: Within 24-72h when stable; or urgently if underlying mass/AVM suspected
Extended.target: Underlying tumor; cavernous malformation; microbleeds (CAA pattern: lobar; hypertensive: deep). SWI shows microhemorrhages

Extended.timing: If cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) suspected as cause of hemorrhagic venous infarct
Young patient (<50) with lobar ICH and no clear etiology; suspected AVM/aneurysm where CTA inconclusive; negative initial CTA but high suspicion
Extended.target: AVM; aneurysm; dural AV fistula; Moyamoya; vasculitis

Extended.timing: Repeat at 3-6 months; small AVM may be compressed by acute hematoma and missed initially
Neurogenic cardiac injury; baseline cardiac function; endocarditis if mycotic aneurysm suspected
If altered consciousness disproportionate to hemorrhage size; suspected seizures
Extended.target: Non-convulsive seizures; NCSE (seen in 20-30% of ICH patients)

Extended.timing: Aspiration; pulmonary edema (neurogenic); baseline for ventilator

Rare/Specialized.timing: If underlying tumor, vasculitis, or amyloid angiopathy suspected and non-invasive workup inconclusive
CAA diagnosis in lobar ICH with microbleeds

Referrals & Consults.indication: ALL ICH patients; surgical decision for EVD, hematoma evacuation, decompression
Medical management; BP optimization; ICP management; seizure management
Anticoagulant reversal guidance; coagulopathy management; thrombocytopenia
Reversal agent dosing; anticoagulant identification; drug interactions
AF management; anticoagulation restart decision; LAAO evaluation; neurogenic cardiac injury
Dysphagia screening before PO intake; aphasia assessment
Early mobilization (24-48h if stable); fall prevention; strength
ADL assessment; cognitive rehabilitation; adaptive equipment
Rehabilitation disposition; functional prognosis
Family support; advance directives; discharge planning
Goals of care discussion (especially ICH score ≥3); early palliative involvement improves care quality
AVM/aneurysm treatment planning; dural AV fistula

Patient Instructions.item: ICH is serious but outcomes vary; early aggressive treatment improves survival
Call 911 if: sudden headache, new weakness, speech changes, altered consciousness
Blood pressure control is the MOST IMPORTANT factor in preventing recurrence
Take all medications as prescribed; never stop blood pressure medications without physician guidance
Do NOT restart anticoagulation or antiplatelet without specific neurology/cardiology guidance
Home blood pressure monitoring daily; keep log; target per physician guidance
Follow-up with neurology in 2-4 weeks; neurosurgery if applicable
Do NOT drive until cleared
Fall prevention at home

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Blood pressure target <130/80 mmHg (most important)
Smoking cessation (doubles ICH risk)
Alcohol cessation or limitation (heavy drinking increases ICH risk)
Cocaine/amphetamine cessation (sympathomimetic ICH)
Avoid excessive anticoagulation (keep INR in range if on warfarin)
Regular exercise (moderate intensity after recovery)
Weight management
DASH or Mediterranean diet
Depression screening (PHQ-9 at 1-3 months)

Medication Overuse Headache (MOH).title: Medication Overuse Headache (MOH)
Medication Overuse Headache (MOH).scope: ** Diagnosis and management of medication overuse headache in adults. Covers identification of offending medications, withdrawal strategies, preventive medication initiation, and relapse prevention. Excludes primary headache disorders without overuse component, and headache due to medication side effects (not overuse).

Electrolytes, renal/hepatic function (chronic NSAID/acetaminophen use)

Referrals & Consults.indication: All patients; management and prevention
CBT for headache, coping strategies, anxiety/depression

Patient Instructions.item: MOH is caused by frequent use of pain medications; stopping them is essential for improvement
Expect headaches to WORSEN for 2-10 days during withdrawal before improving
Most patients improve significantly within 2-3 months of stopping overused medications
STRICT medication limits going forward: triptans ≤9 days/month, NSAIDs ≤14 days/month
Keep detailed headache diary tracking medications and headache days
Preventive medication takes 4-8 weeks to work; be patient
Relapse is common (~40%); call if headache frequency increasing
Do NOT restart butalbital-containing medications (Fioricet, Fiorinal)
Opioids should NOT be used for primary headache disorders

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular sleep schedule (7-8 hours)
Regular meal schedule (don't skip meals)
Regular exercise (30 min, 5 days/week)
Stress management techniques (biofeedback, relaxation, CBT)
Limit caffeine to consistent moderate intake (<200 mg/day)
Stay well-hydrated
Avoid known migraine triggers
Establish "medication rules" and stick to them

Migraine / Status Migrainosus.title: Migraine / Status Migrainosus

Patient Instructions.item: Keep headache diary (frequency, severity, triggers, medications)

Covers antibody testing, electrodiagnostic studies, thymoma screening, acute stabilization, and long-term immunotherapy initiation. For myasthenic crisis with respiratory failure, use "Myasthenic Crisis" template. For established MG on maintenance therapy, use "MG - Maintenance" template.

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately if difficulty breathing, swallowing, or speaking
Return to ED if new severe weakness, double vision worsening acutely, or unable to hold head up
Take pyridostigmine 30-60 minutes BEFORE meals to help with chewing and swallowing
Do NOT take pyridostigmine more frequently than prescribed (cholinergic crisis risk)
Report excessive salivation, diarrhea, cramping, or muscle twitching (cholinergic side effects)
Carry MG medical alert identification at all times
Provide MG medication list to ALL healthcare providers (emergency, dental, surgical)
Avoid extreme heat, hot baths/saunas (may worsen weakness)
Plan activities for times of best strength (usually morning after pyridostigmine)
Rest before meals if dysphagia present; eat smaller, more frequent meals
Do NOT stop prednisone or immunosuppressant abruptly (adrenal crisis/flare risk)
Avoid alcohol (potentiates weakness and interacts with medications)
Report any signs of infection immediately (fever, cough, dysuria) especially if on immunosuppression
Contact neurologist before taking any new medications (many drugs worsen MG)
Do NOT use over-the-counter magnesium-containing products without physician approval
Keep emergency contact numbers for MG specialist readily available
Understand the difference between myasthenic crisis and cholinergic crisis
Monitor and report progressive difficulty climbing stairs, rising from chairs, or lifting arms above head

differential.features: Proximal weakness with improvement after exertion (facilitation); autonomic dysfunction; dry mouth; associated with SCLC; depressed reflexes that improve post-exercise
differential.tests: VGCC antibody (P/Q-type); incremental response on RNS at 50 Hz; CT chest for malignancy

differential.features: Acute onset descending paralysis; dilated/fixed pupils; recent ingestion of canned food or wound; autonomic dysfunction; no prior NMJ disease
differential.tests: Stool/serum botulinum toxin assay; EMG: BSAP pattern; incremental response on high-frequency RNS

differential.features: Childhood onset; family history; seronegative; variable inheritance patterns; specific gene mutations
differential.tests: Genetic testing (CMS gene panel: CHRNE, DOK7, RAPSN, CHAT, COLQ); no autoantibodies

differential.features: Proptosis; restrictive (not fatigable) diplopia; lid lag; thyroid dysfunction; MRI shows enlarged EOMs
differential.tests: TSH, free T4, TSI, orbital MRI showing EOM enlargement (not NMJ issue)

differential.features: Slowly progressive bilateral ptosis and ophthalmoparesis; non-fatigable; no diurnal variation; may have pigmentary retinopathy
differential.tests: Muscle biopsy (ragged red fibers, COX-negative); mitochondrial DNA analysis

differential.features: Late-onset (>40) progressive ptosis and dysphagia; autosomal dominant; no fatigability; specific ethnic prevalence (French-Canadian, Bukharan Jewish)
differential.tests: Genetic testing (PABPN1 gene, GCN trinucleotide repeat); CK may be mildly elevated

differential.features: Progressive weakness without fatigability; fasciculations; UMN signs (hyperreflexia, Babinski); no sensory loss; bulbar onset may mimic MG
differential.tests: EMG/NCS: active denervation, fasciculations; normal RNS; no antibodies

differential.features: Proximal weakness without fatigability; elevated CK; skin findings in DM; no ptosis/diplopia (usually); IBM with grip/quad weakness
differential.tests: CK; myositis antibody panel; EMG: myopathic pattern; muscle biopsy

differential.features: Acute onset; cranial nerve palsies without fatigability; other focal neurological signs; vascular risk factors
differential.tests: Brain MRI with DWI; MRA; CTA

differential.features: Acute ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, areflexia; post-infectious; no fatigability
differential.tests: Anti-GQ1b antibody; CSF albuminocytologic dissociation; NCS (reduced SNAPs)

differential.features: Ptosis and facial weakness; myotonia (delayed relaxation); distal > proximal weakness; cataracts; cardiac conduction abnormalities
differential.tests: Genetic testing (DMPK CTG repeat for DM1, CNBP CCTG repeat for DM2); EMG: myotonic discharges

differential.features: Progressive proximal and distal weakness; hyporeflexia/areflexia; sensory involvement; elevated CSF protein
differential.tests: NCS: demyelinating pattern; CSF protein; nerve biopsy

differential.features: Granulomatous myopathy or cranial neuropathy; systemic involvement (lungs, skin, eyes); elevated ACE
differential.tests: ACE level; chest CT; biopsy (non-caseating granulomas); gallium scan

differential.features: Temporal correlation with offending drug (D-penicillamine, checkpoint inhibitors, statins); antibodies may be present
differential.tests: Drug history; antibody testing; improvement after drug withdrawal

evidence.source: [Gilhus NE et al. Nat Rev Dis Primers 2019](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31048702/); AAN Guidelines
[Evoli A et al. Brain 2003](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12821509/); Guptill JT et al. 2011

evidence.recommendation: Steroid-induced transient worsening in ~50% of MG patients
evidence.source: Bae JS et al. Muscle Nerve 2006

evidence.evidenceLevel: Class I (negative RCTs but widely used)
evidence.source: Sanders DB et al. Neurology 2008; MG Study Group (note: RCTs were short-duration)
[Diaz-Manera J et al. Neurology 2012](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22218276/); [Hehir MK et al. Neurology 2017](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28801338/)
Tandan R et al. (BeatMG trial) Lancet Neurol 2023

evidence.recommendation: IVIG for MG acute exacerbation and maintenance
IVIG equivalent to PLEX for MG exacerbation
MGTX trial: thymectomy + prednisone superior at 3 years
evidence.source: [Wolfe GI et al. NEJM 2016](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27509100/); 5-year extension data 2019

evidence.recommendation: Medications to avoid in MG (comprehensive review)
evidence.source: [Gilhus NE. NEJM 2016](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28029925/); Sheikh S et al. Muscle Nerve 2021

evidence.recommendation: FVC <15 mL/kg predicts need for intubation
NIF weaker than -20 cm H2O: intubation threshold
QMG score as validated outcome measure
evidence.source: [Barohn RJ et al. Ann NY Acad Sci 1998](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9668327/)
[Norwood F et al. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2014](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23757420/); [Batocchi AP et al. Neurology 1999](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10025772/)

evidence.recommendation: Transient neonatal MG in 10-20% of births

monitoring.frequency: Q4-6h in acute; Q shift if stable
monitoring.action: If <15 mL/kg or <1 L: impending respiratory failure, prepare for intubation; ICU transfer

monitoring.frequency: Q4-6h in acute; Q shift if stable
monitoring.action: If weaker than -20 cm H2O: intubate; -20 to -30 = ICU monitoring
Supplemental O2; BiPAP; intubation if declining

monitoring.frequency: Daily; each meal if bulbar symptoms
monitoring.action: NPO if aspiration risk; NG tube or modified diet; SLP consult

monitoring.frequency: Q shift inpatient; BID in ICU
monitoring.action: If worsening: reassess pyridostigmine dose; consider IVIG/PLEX; check for cholinergic crisis
Insulin sliding scale; endocrine consult if persistent >250
Infection workup if febrile (infection is leading MG crisis trigger)
Replace aggressively; hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia worsen NMJ transmission

monitoring.frequency: Continuous if on neostigmine IV; during PLEX
monitoring.action: Atropine for bradycardia; PLEX can cause electrolyte-mediated arrhythmias
HOB elevated; thickened liquids; SLP-guided diet

disposition.criteria: Mild symptoms (ocular only or mild generalized); FVC >60% predicted and stable; adequate oral intake; pyridostigmine optimized; reliable follow-up within 1-2 weeks; understands return precautions; crisis action plan reviewed

Moderate generalized weakness; FVC 40-60% predicted and stable; dysphagia requiring diet modification but tolerating PO; new diagnosis requiring expedited workup; steroid initiation with concern for transient worsening; IVIG infusion
FVC 30-40% predicted or declining trend; moderate bulbar symptoms; starting PLEX; significant comorbidities requiring closer monitoring; recent cholinergic vs myasthenic crisis distinction unclear

FVC <30% predicted or <1 L; NIF weaker than -25 cm H2O; progressive respiratory failure; impending intubation; active myasthenic crisis; severe bulbar dysfunction with aspiration; hemodynamic instability during PLEX
PLEX needed but unavailable; neuromuscular specialist not available; ICU capability needed but not present; thymectomy needed at specialized center

FVC >50% predicted and improving; adequate oral intake; stable on oral medications; immunotherapy plan established; outpatient follow-up scheduled within 1-2 weeks; patient and family educated on crisis recognition

Neuromuscular Respiratory Failure.title: Neuromuscular Respiratory Failure
Neuromuscular Respiratory Failure.scope: ** Emergency evaluation and management of respiratory failure from neuromuscular disorders in adults. Covers recognition of impending respiratory failure, monitoring parameters (FVC, NIF), indications for intubation, non-invasive ventilation (NIV) considerations, disease-specific treatments (myasthenia gravis crisis, GBS, ALS, muscular dystrophy, other myopathies), and weaning considerations. Excludes central causes of respiratory failure (brainstem stroke, sedative overdose) and primary pulmonary causes (pneumonia, ARDS, COPD exacerbation).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: **CRITICAL**: Assess ventilation (PaCO2) and oxygenation (PaO2); hypercapnia (PaCO2 >45) indicates hypoventilation; respiratory acidosis = severe; PaO2/FiO2 ratio
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal: pH 7.35-7.45, PaCO2 35-45, PaO2 >80; **Hypercapnia with respiratory acidosis = impending/current respiratory failure** — consider intubation

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Infection (pneumonia as trigger or complication); baseline; anemia (reduces O2 carrying capacity)
Electrolytes (K, Mg, Ca, Phos — all affect muscle function); renal function; glucose
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia can all worsen neuromuscular weakness

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypomagnesemia worsens neuromuscular junction transmission and muscle weakness
Hypophosphatemia causes profound muscle weakness including respiratory muscles
Essential/Core Labs.target: >2.5 mg/dL; replete if low (can cause respiratory failure at <1.0)

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypocalcemia increases neuromuscular excitability; hypercalcemia causes weakness
**MG workup**: positive in 85% of generalized MG; 50% of ocular MG; confirms diagnosis
Essential/Core Labs.target: Positive = MG; negative does NOT exclude (check MuSK, LRP4)

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: If AChR negative but MG suspected clinically; MuSK-positive MG has distinct features (bulbar predominant, may not respond well to cholinesterase inhibitors)
If both AChR and MuSK negative ("seronegative MG"); less commonly available
Elevated in myopathies, muscular dystrophies; may be normal in MG, GBS, ALS
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal in MG, GBS; elevated in myopathies, rhabdomyolysis; very high (>10,000) in inflammatory myopathies, dystrophies

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Thyroid dysfunction: hyperthyroidism worsens MG; hypothyroidism causes myopathy
Infection as trigger (pneumonia, UTI can precipitate MG crisis); distinguish infection from disease exacerbation
Drugs affecting neuromuscular function; intoxication as mimicker

Extended Workup.rationale: Rarely available; assess for cholinergic crisis (too much pyridostigmine vs. myasthenic crisis)
Extended Workup.target: Therapeutic range varies; clinical assessment more reliable

Extended Workup.rationale: GBS workup; GQ1b positive in Miller Fisher syndrome
Extended Workup.target: Positive supports GBS diagnosis; negative does NOT exclude

Extended Workup.rationale: GBS: albuminocytologic dissociation (elevated protein, normal cells — may not be present in first week); exclude infection
Extended Workup.target: GBS: protein elevated (>45 mg/dL), WBC <10 (usually <5); may be normal early

Extended Workup.rationale: **MG diagnosis**: decremental response at 3 Hz stimulation (>10% decrement) in proximal muscles
Extended Workup.target: >10% decrement = neuromuscular junction defect (MG); no decrement does NOT exclude MG

Extended Workup.rationale: **Most sensitive test for MG** (92-98%); increased jitter and blocking
GBS: demyelinating pattern (prolonged F-waves, conduction block, temporal dispersion) or axonal (reduced amplitudes); ALS: widespread denervation; myopathy: myopathic units
Extended Workup.target: GBS: demyelinating or axonal; ALS: diffuse denervation; myopathy: small, polyphasic MUPs

Extended Workup.rationale: **Thymoma screening in MG**: 10-15% of MG patients have thymoma; all MG patients need chest imaging
Extended Workup.target: Thymoma (anterior mediastinal mass); thymic hyperplasia; normal thymus

Extended Workup.rationale: Associated with thymoma in MG; may indicate need for more aggressive thymoma search
Extended Workup.target: Positive in older MG patients and thymoma-associated MG

Extended Workup.rationale: Paraneoplastic neuromuscular syndromes (LEMS with anti-VGCC and small cell lung cancer); myositis with malignancy
Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS); associated with SCLC in 50-60%

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Inflammatory myopathy (dermatomyositis, polymyositis); muscular dystrophy; congenital myopathy
Rare/Specialized.target: Inflammatory infiltrate; dystrophic changes; structural abnormalities

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Suspected hereditary myopathy/dystrophy; known family history; young patient with progressive weakness
Rare/Specialized.target: Specific mutations (dystrophin, FSHD, myotonic dystrophy, etc.)

Rare/Specialized.item: Myositis-specific antibodies (Jo-1, Mi-2, SRP, MDA5, etc.)
Rare/Specialized.rationale: Inflammatory myopathy workup
Rare/Specialized.target: Specific antibodies guide diagnosis and prognosis

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Rarely done now (replaced by serologic testing and SFEMG); bedside MG test; risk of cholinergic crisis; atropine must be at bedside
Rare/Specialized.target: Transient improvement = positive (MG); false positives/negatives occur

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Bedside test for ocular MG; apply ice pack to closed eyelid for 2 min; improvement in ptosis suggests MG
Rare/Specialized.target: Improvement = positive; negative does NOT exclude

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Upper airway obstruction pattern (variable extrathoracic obstruction in vocal cord weakness); restrictive pattern in neuromuscular disease
Rare/Specialized.target: Restrictive pattern; flattened inspiratory loop suggests extrathoracic obstruction

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Sleep-disordered breathing in neuromuscular disease; nocturnal hypoventilation; assess need for nocturnal NIV
Baseline and monitoring in chronic neuromuscular disease; FVC, MIP, MEP, SNIP
Rare/Specialized.target: FVC; supine vs. upright FVC (>20% drop suggests diaphragm weakness)

Lumbar Puncture.timing: GBS diagnosis (albuminocytologic dissociation); may be normal in first week; NOT typically needed for MG diagnosis
Lumbar Puncture.target: GBS: elevated protein (often >100 mg/dL after first week), normal WBC (<10, usually <5); cytoalbuminous dissociation
Lumbar Puncture.contraindications: Coagulopathy; skin infection at LP site; elevated ICP

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate; assess for aspiration, pneumonia (trigger for crisis), atelectasis, elevated hemidiaphragm
Essential/First-line.target: Aspiration pneumonia; atelectasis (from weak cough); elevated hemidiaphragm (diaphragm weakness); anterior mediastinal mass (thymoma)

Essential/First-line.timing: **CRITICAL: q4-6h in unstable patients; q1-2h if rapidly declining**; most important monitoring parameter
Essential/First-line.target: FVC >20 mL/kg = adequate; FVC <15-20 mL/kg = consider intubation; FVC declining >30% from baseline = concerning
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Patient cooperation required; cannot perform if intubated (use ventilator parameters)

Essential/First-line.timing: **CRITICAL: Assess inspiratory muscle strength**; complement to FVC; easier for fatigued patients
Essential/First-line.target: NIF < -30 cm H2O = adequate; NIF > -20 to -25 cm H2O (less negative) = weak, consider intubation

Essential/First-line.timing: Assess cough strength; correlates with ability to clear secretions
Essential/First-line.target: MEP <40 cm H2O = weak cough; aspiration risk

Essential/First-line.timing: Assess ventilation and oxygenation; hypercapnia is late sign
Essential/First-line.target: PaCO2 >45 = hypoventilation; rising PaCO2 is ominous; PaO2 <60 = hypoxemia

Essential/First-line.timing: Arrhythmia from autonomic dysfunction (GBS); cardiac involvement in muscular dystrophies; baseline for IVIG/PLEX
Essential/First-line.target: Arrhythmia; conduction abnormalities; cardiomyopathy (DMD, LGMD)

Extended.timing: Within 24-48h for MG; thymoma screening; all newly diagnosed generalized MG
If CT contraindicated or additional characterization needed
Cardiomyopathy screening in muscular dystrophies (DMD, BMD, LGMD2I, myotonic dystrophy); autonomic dysfunction in GBS; baseline before IVIG
Extended.target: Cardiomyopathy; reduced EF; conduction abnormalities (perform ECG first)

Extended.timing: Assess diaphragm excursion and thickness; non-invasive diaphragm function assessment; bedside
Extended.target: Reduced diaphragm excursion (<1.5 cm during tidal breathing, <4 cm during deep breath); paradoxical motion = diaphragm paralysis

Extended.timing: If pulmonary embolism suspected (immobile patients at high VTE risk)
If LEMS diagnosed to search for underlying malignancy (SCLC in 50-60%)

Rare/Specialized.timing: Assess phrenic nerve function; bilateral phrenic neuropathy as cause of respiratory failure
Rare/Specialized.target: Absent or reduced phrenic CMAP = phrenic neuropathy; prolonged latency

Rare/Specialized.timing: Diaphragm function; "sniff test" — paradoxical upward diaphragm motion with sniff = paralysis
Gold standard for diaphragm strength; requires esophageal and gastric balloon catheters; specialized centers
Nocturnal hypoventilation assessment; sleep-disordered breathing; guide NIV
Rare/Specialized.target: Nocturnal hypoventilation (elevated PtcCO2); desaturations; REM-related events

dosing.instructions: **"20/30/40 Rule":** FVC <20 mL/kg, NIF > -30 cm H2O (less negative), MEP <40 cm H2O = HIGH RISK for respiratory failure; monitor q2-4h (or more frequently if declining); **INTUBATION THRESHOLD:** FVC <15-20 mL/kg, NIF > -20 to -25 cm H2O, rising PaCO2, or clinical distress

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: NMD respiratory failure is often predictable by serial FVC/NIF; intubate BEFORE crisis (controlled intubation is safer); ABG abnormalities are LATE signs

dosing.instructions: **Indications:** FVC <15-20 mL/kg (or <1 L); NIF > -20 to -25 cm H2O; PaCO2 rising or >50; clinical respiratory distress; inability to clear secretions; aspiration; fatigue; **RSI considerations:** AVOID succinylcholine in myopathies/muscular dystrophy (hyperkalemia), MG (resistance); use rocuronium (may need reduced dose in MG); can use sugammadex for reversal

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Elective intubation is safer than emergent; neuromuscular patients are difficult to bag-mask ventilate; have difficult airway equipment ready; avoid neuromuscular blockers post-intubation if possible

dosing.instructions: **ROLE IS LIMITED IN ACUTE NMD RESPIRATORY FAILURE**; may be considered as bridge in: stable patients with nocturnal hypoventilation, mild hypercapnia without distress, secretion clearance ability preserved, no aspiration risk, patient can protect airway; **AVOID NIV if:** Bulbar dysfunction (aspiration risk), unable to clear secretions, severe hypercapnia (PaCO2 >60), acidosis, rapid decline, altered mental status

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: NIV (BiPAP) has lower threshold for failure in neuromuscular disease than COPD/CHF; bulbar weakness increases aspiration risk; low threshold for intubation; useful for chronic nocturnal hypoventilation

dosing.instructions: **Use CAUTIOUSLY**: Oxygen can mask hypoventilation (hypercapnia develops before desaturation); may eliminate hypoxic drive (though less relevant in NMD than COPD); titrate to SpO2 92-96%; **If hypoxemic + hypercapnic:** This indicates severe failure — intubate, do NOT rely on oxygen alone

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Hypoxemia is a late finding in pure neuromuscular hypoventilation; if hypoxemic, consider aspiration, atelectasis, or imminent failure

dosing.instructions: Weak cough = poor secretion clearance; **Techniques:** Assisted cough (abdominal thrust during cough); mechanical insufflation-exsufflation (CoughAssist) — pressures +40/-40 cm H2O; aggressive pulmonary toilet; chest physiotherapy; suction PRN; **If unable to clear secretions:** Intubate

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Aspiration pneumonia is leading cause of death in chronic NMD; weak cough (MEP <40) = high risk; mechanical cough assist is underutilized and highly effective

dosing.instructions: **MG crisis precipitants (AVOID):** Aminoglycosides (gentamicin, tobramycin), fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin — less risky but still caution), macrolides (azithromycin, erythromycin), beta-blockers, magnesium (IV), neuromuscular blockers, D-penicillamine, interferon-alpha, checkpoint inhibitors (nivolumab, pembrolizumab); **Full list in Appendix**

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Many medications can worsen neuromuscular transmission; careful medication review essential; see comprehensive list in appendix

dosing.instructions: SCDs immediately; pharmacologic prophylaxis (enoxaparin 40 mg SQ daily) once stable; immobile patients at very high VTE risk

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: High VTE risk in paralyzed/weak patients; balance with IVIG timing (hold anticoagulation during IVIG infusion in some protocols)

dosing.instructions: HOB elevated 30-45°; NPO if significant bulbar weakness; speech-language pathology evaluation; modified diet or enteral feeding if prolonged weakness

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Aspiration pneumonia is major complication; bulbar weakness (dysphagia, weak cough, voice changes) = high risk

dosing.instructions: **First-line for MG crisis (with PLEX):** 2 g/kg total divided over 2-5 days (400 mg/kg/day x 5 days OR 1 g/kg/day x 2 days); **Onset:** 2-5 days; **Duration:** 3-6 weeks; **Pre-treatment:** Check IgA (IgA deficiency = anaphylaxis risk); renal function; volume status

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Efficacy equivalent to PLEX (RCTs); easier logistics than PLEX; side effects: headache (aseptic meningitis), renal failure (sucrose-containing products), thrombosis, hemolysis; slower onset than PLEX

dosing.instructions: **First-line for MG crisis (with IVIG):** 5-7 exchanges over 10-14 days (1-1.5 plasma volumes per exchange; typically 3-4 L); **Onset:** Faster than IVIG (improvement may begin after 2-3 exchanges); requires large-bore central venous access; **Caution:** Hypotension, citrate toxicity (hypocalcemia), infection

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: May work faster than IVIG; useful if rapid response needed; RCT showed PLEX and IVIG equivalent in MG exacerbation; PLEX preferred if IVIG contraindicated (IgA deficiency, renal failure)

dosing.instructions: **In intubated MG crisis patients:** STOP pyridostigmine while intubated; excessive secretions worsen pulmonary toilet; cannot distinguish myasthenic from cholinergic crisis if on pyridostigmine; **Resume cautiously when extubation nearing**

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Pyridostigmine increases secretions; in intubated patient, secretions worsen; hold until preparing for extubation; some restart at lower dose (30 mg q6h) and titrate

dosing.instructions: **CAUTION: Steroids can cause TRANSIENT WORSENING in MG (up to 50% of patients)**; **In crisis:** Start AFTER IVIG/PLEX initiated and patient stabilizing (days 3-5 or later); do NOT start steroids as initial therapy in crisis; **Protocol:** Prednisone 10-20 mg daily, increase by 10 mg every 3-5 days to 1 mg/kg/day (max 60-80 mg); OR IV methylprednisolone 1g daily x 3-5 days then oral

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Steroids are maintenance therapy but can worsen MG acutely ("steroid dip"); always start with IVIG or PLEX first in crisis; steroid-sparing agents (azathioprine, mycophenolate) for long-term

dosing.instructions: **Infection:** Most common trigger; treat aggressively but AVOID contraindicated antibiotics (see list); **Medication-induced:** Stop offending drug; **Surgery/anesthesia:** Stress can trigger crisis; **Tapering immunosuppression:** Restart or increase

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: 30-40% of MG crises have identifiable trigger; treating trigger may hasten recovery

dosing.instructions: **Mode:** Volume-controlled (AC/VC) or Pressure-support (PS) during weaning; **Tidal volume:** 6-8 mL/kg IBW (lung-protective); **Rate:** 12-16 to achieve adequate minute ventilation; **PEEP:** 5 (higher if atelectasis or hypoxemia); **FiO2:** Titrate to SpO2 92-96%; **I:E ratio:** 1:2 or 1:3; avoid breath-stacking

Ventilator Management and Weaning.monitoring: NMD patients generally have healthy lungs; lung-protective ventilation still applies; goal is to support ventilation while disease-specific treatment works

dosing.instructions: **NMD weaning is often prolonged:** Disease-specific treatment must take effect (MG: IVIG/PLEX effect in 3-7 days; GBS: weeks); **Weaning trial criteria:** FVC >15 mL/kg; NIF < -25 cm H2O; adequate cough; secretions manageable; underlying disease improving; **SBT (spontaneous breathing trial):** T-piece or low PS (5-8 cm H2O) x 30-120 min; assess for fatigue, tachypnea, hypercapnia

Ventilator Management and Weaning.monitoring: Premature extubation leads to re-intubation; NMD patients may need longer ventilation than other ICU patients; patience; daily SBT when criteria met

dosing.instructions: Pass SBT; FVC >15-20 mL/kg AND improving trajectory; NIF < -25 to -30 cm H2O; effective cough (able to clear secretions); alert and cooperative; bulbar function adequate (can swallow); no heavy sedation; consider cuff leak test

Ventilator Management and Weaning.monitoring: Higher threshold for extubation in NMD than general ICU patients; failed extubation is dangerous

dosing.instructions: **Consider if:** Unable to wean after 2-3 weeks of optimal disease-specific treatment; ALS with decision for long-term ventilation; severe GBS; **Timing:** No firm consensus; typically discuss at 10-14 days if no progress; earlier in conditions with known prolonged course

Ventilator Management and Weaning.monitoring: Tracheostomy allows for weaning, reduces sedation needs, allows speech (with speaking valve), but has complications and care burden; goals of care discussion essential

dosing.instructions: Close monitoring for 24-48h; serial FVC/NIF; watch for fatigue, stridor; have reintubation equipment ready; consider prophylactic NIV post-extubation in borderline cases

Ventilator Management and Weaning.monitoring: Re-intubation rates higher in NMD; close monitoring; low threshold for NIV support post-extubation

Patient Instructions.item: Respiratory therapy
Physical therapy
Occupational therapy
Nutrition / Dietitian
Social work
Palliative care
Cardiology
Psychiatry / Psychology

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Repeat IVIG or PLEX
Rituximab (MG)
Eculizumab (MG)
Thymectomy (MG)
Tracheostomy and long-term ventilation
Home mechanical ventilation
Diaphragm pacing

differential.features: Etiologies
differential.tests: Key Distinguishing Features

differential.features: Myasthenia gravis; Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS); botulism; organophosphate poisoning
differential.tests: MG: fatigable weakness, ptosis, diplopia, AChR Ab; LEMS: proximal weakness, autonomic symptoms, improves with repetition, anti-VGCC; Botulism: descending paralysis, dilated pupils, recent exposure; OP poisoning: miosis, salivation, bradycardia, cholinergic crisis

differential.features: Guillain-Barré syndrome; critical illness polyneuropathy (CIP); phrenic nerve injury (cardiac surgery); Charcot-Marie-Tooth (rare)
differential.tests: GBS: ascending weakness, areflexia, post-infectious, elevated CSF protein; CIP: ICU patient, sepsis, prolonged weakness; Phrenic injury: post-cardiac surgery, unilateral diaphragm paralysis

differential.features: ALS (amyotrophic lateral sclerosis); spinal muscular atrophy; poliomyelitis (rare)
differential.tests: ALS: UMN + LMN signs, progressive, fasciculations, no sensory involvement; SMA: childhood onset, proximal weakness

differential.features: Muscular dystrophies (DMD, BMD, LGMD, myotonic, FSHD); inflammatory myopathies (dermatomyositis, polymyositis, inclusion body myositis); critical illness myopathy; metabolic myopathies
differential.tests: DMD: young males, elevated CK, cardiac involvement; Myotonic: myotonia, cataracts, cardiac; Inflammatory: elevated CK, rash (DM), proximal weakness; CIM: ICU patient, prolonged steroids/NMB, flaccid weakness

differential.features: Bilateral diaphragm paralysis; diaphragmatic fatigue; isolated phrenic neuropathy
differential.tests: Orthopnea; paradoxical breathing; supine FVC drop >20%; fluoroscopy: paradoxical motion

evidence.evidenceLevel: IVIG = PLEX for GBS; combination not better
evidence.source: Either IVIG or PLEX; no combination

evidence.evidenceLevel: Thymectomy + prednisone > prednisone alone for AChR+ MG (even without thymoma); improved outcomes at 3 years
evidence.source: Thymectomy recommended for generalized AChR+ MG

evidence.evidenceLevel: NIV prolongs survival in ALS (7-11 months) and improves QoL
evidence.source: NIV is standard of care for ALS respiratory insufficiency

evidence.recommendation: [Lawn et al. Respiratory Failure in GBS (2001)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11405803/)
evidence.evidenceLevel: FVC <20 mL/kg or NIF > -30 cm H2O predicted need for intubation; "20/30/40 rule"
evidence.source: Established monitoring thresholds for MG crisis

evidence.evidenceLevel: Eculizumab reduced exacerbations in refractory generalized MG
evidence.source: FDA approval of eculizumab for refractory AChR+ MG
Weak cough; unable to clear secretions; aspiration risk

monitoring.action: Declining trend or <15-20: prepare for intubation

monitoring.target: < -30 cm H2O safe; > -20 to -25 = intubation threshold

monitoring.frequency: q6-8h or PRN; with any clinical change

monitoring.action: Desaturation: assess for aspiration, atelectasis, failure; supplement O2 cautiously
Tachypnea >30 with shallow breathing suggests fatigue
Worsening weakness: reassess treatment; anticipate respiratory decline
Arrhythmia: treat; wide BP swings: short-acting agents; bradycardia: atropine/pacing
Excessive secretions + weak cough: aggressive pulmonary toilet; consider intubation

disposition.criteria: Criteria

FVC <25 mL/kg or declining; NIF > -40 cm H2O; any respiratory distress; autonomic instability (GBS); need for frequent monitoring (q1-4h); NIV initiation for acute failure; intubation anticipated or performed
Stable but requires monitoring q4-6h; improving trajectory; stable on NIV; post-extubation observation
Stable respiratory function; FVC >30 mL/kg and stable; for diagnostic workup of mild exacerbation; initiation of immunotherapy without respiratory compromise

Parkinson's Disease - New Diagnosis.title: Parkinson's Disease - New Diagnosis
Parkinson's Disease - New Diagnosis.scope: ** Initial diagnosis and early management of idiopathic Parkinson's disease in adults. Covers diagnostic workup to exclude secondary causes and atypical parkinsonism, initiation of symptomatic therapy, and patient education. Excludes drug-induced parkinsonism, atypical parkinsonian syndromes (PSP, MSA, CBD, DLB), juvenile/young-onset PD, and advanced PD with motor fluctuations.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: General health, rule out anemia
Hepatic/renal function for medication dosing
Hypothyroidism can cause slowness/tremor
Deficiency can cause parkinsonism
Neurosyphilis in differential

Extended Workup.rationale: Young onset (<50), family history, Ashkenazi Jewish

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Manganese exposure, other toxins
Autoimmune parkinsonism (rare)
Emerging biomarker

Essential/First-line.target: Rule out structural cause, vascular parkinsonism

Essential/First-line.timing: If mass or infection suspected
Essential/First-line.target: Rule out structural lesion

Extended.timing: Diagnostic uncertainty (ET vs PD, drug-induced)
Distinguish atypical parkinsonism
Wilson disease, iron deposition
Distinguish PD from MSA
If REM sleep behavior disorder suspected
Supportive criterion; impaired in PD

Rapidly Progressive Dementia (RPD).title: Rapidly Progressive Dementia (RPD)
Rapidly Progressive Dementia (RPD).scope: ** Urgent evaluation of cognitive decline progressing over weeks to months (typically <1-2 years from symptom onset to severe disability). Covers comprehensive workup to identify treatable causes including autoimmune encephalitis, infectious etiologies, toxic-metabolic causes, CNS malignancy, and prion disease (CJD). The key principle: assume a treatable cause exists until proven otherwise. Excludes typical slowly progressive dementias (Alzheimer's, FTD) unless presenting atypically fast, and acute delirium (<days).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Infection screen; hematologic malignancy; B12 deficiency (macrocytosis)
Hepatic encephalopathy (ammonia); renal failure (uremia); electrolyte abnormalities (Na, Ca); hypo/hyperglycemia
Hypothyroid encephalopathy (Hashimoto encephalopathy); hyperthyroidism
B12 deficiency — reversible cause of cognitive decline and myelopathy
Deficiency associated with cognitive impairment
Vasculitis screen; inflammatory conditions; infection; malignancy
Inflammatory marker
Neurosyphilis — treatable cause; "the great imitator"
HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder (HAND); opportunistic infections
Hepatic encephalopathy
UTI causing delirium (especially elderly)
Substance-related cognitive impairment; prescription drug toxicity
Hypoglycemia; diabetic encephalopathy

Extended Workup.rationale: Hashimoto encephalopathy (SREAT) — treatable with steroids even if euthyroid
CNS vasculitis (granulomatosis with polyangiitis, microscopic polyangiitis)
Multiple myeloma; POEMS; Waldenström; M-protein-associated neuropathy/encephalopathy
Wernicke encephalopathy — reversible with treatment; alcoholism, malnutrition, bariatric surgery
Wilson disease (young patients <50); acquired copper deficiency (zinc excess, gastric surgery)
Zinc excess causes copper deficiency → myeloneuropathy + cognitive decline
ANNA-1 (Hu), ANNA-2 (Ri), CRMP-5 (CV2), amphiphysin, PCA-1 (Yo), PCA-2, PCA-Tr (DNER), GAD65

Malignant Spinal Cord Compression (MSCC).scope: ** Emergency evaluation and management of malignant (metastatic) spinal cord compression in adults. Covers dexamethasone protocols, emergent imaging, surgical decompression criteria (Patchell criteria), radiation therapy, vertebral body assessment, functional prognostication, and disposition. Excludes non-malignant compressive myelopathy (disc herniation, epidural abscess — separate templates), primary spinal cord tumors (intramedullary), and cauda equina syndrome from malignancy (partially overlaps — see separate template for CES).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; surgical candidacy; chemotherapy effects; infection (epidural abscess differential)
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; leukocytosis may suggest infection; thrombocytopenia affects surgical/procedural candidacy

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Renal function (contrast, medications); electrolytes (hypercalcemia of malignancy); hepatic function (chemotherapy dosing, metastatic disease)
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; calcium >10.5 mg/dL → assess for hypercalcemia of malignancy

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Coagulopathy assessment; surgical candidacy; anticoagulation reversal if emergent surgery needed
Epidural abscess differential (highly elevated ESR >30-50 typically); inflammatory markers for malignancy
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal-mildly elevated in malignancy; markedly elevated ESR/CRP → strongly consider abscess

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Epidural abscess differential; bacteremia if febrile
Essential/Core Labs.target: Negative; positive → epidural abscess more likely than tumor

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline before high-dose dexamethasone; steroid hyperglycemia
Essential/Core Labs.target: <180 mg/dL; anticipate significant hyperglycemia with high-dose steroids

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Surgical candidacy; blood product availability
Hypercalcemia of malignancy (present in 10-30% of cancer patients); can cause confusion, weakness mimicking cord compression progression
Essential/Core Labs.target: Corrected Ca <10.5 mg/dL; if elevated → IV fluids, calcitonin, bisphosphonate

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Tumor burden marker; lymphoma (very high LDH); prognostic
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; very high → lymphoma, aggressive malignancy

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Urinary retention (neurogenic bladder from cord compression); UTI (fever differential); baseline renal function
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; retention with high post-void residual expected in cord compression

Extended Workup.item: Tumor markers (PSA, CEA, CA 19-9, CA 125, CA 15-3, AFP, β-hCG)
Extended Workup.rationale: Unknown primary cancer; PSA (prostate — most common spinal metastasis), CEA (GI, lung), CA 15-3 (breast), etc.
Multiple myeloma (common cause of vertebral compression/cord compression); M-protein, light chains
Extended Workup.target: No monoclonal protein; if present → myeloma workup

Extended Workup.rationale: Osteoblastic metastases (prostate, breast); Paget's disease differential
Tumor lysis syndrome risk (lymphoma, rapidly proliferating tumors); pre-treatment assessment
If infection/abscess differential is high; more specific than CRP for bacterial infection
Thyroid cancer metastases (follicular thyroid cancer has bony tropism)
Bone health; pathologic fracture risk; supplement if deficient

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Lymphoma/leukemia presenting as epidural mass
Myeloma; lymphoma; unknown primary with bone marrow involvement
If myelopathy features atypical for compression (e.g., subacute progressive without clear structural compression)
Rare/Specialized.target: Negative; positive changes diagnosis from compression to paraneoplastic myelopathy

Rare/Specialized.rationale: If imaging shows longitudinal intramedullary lesion rather than epidural compression → NMOSD differential
Rare/Specialized.target: Negative; positive → NMOSD not metastatic compression

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Unknown primary; tissue diagnosis needed before treatment; lymphoma requires tissue for definitive diagnosis (sensitive to steroids — obtain tissue BEFORE steroids if possible in suspected lymphoma)

Lumbar Puncture.timing: LP is NOT routinely indicated in MSCC; CSF cytology only if leptomeningeal disease suspected AND no complete block; CT myelogram if MRI not available (different indication)
Lumbar Puncture.target: N/A — LP is diagnostic adjunct only in specific situations
Lumbar Puncture.contraindications: CONTRAINDICATED with complete spinal block above LP level (risk of neurologic deterioration/coning); coagulopathy; local infection

Essential/First-line.item: MRI entire spine with and without contrast (gadolinium)
Essential/First-line.timing: **Within 4 hours of presentation (24h max)**; GOLD STANDARD; must image ENTIRE spine (multifocal metastases in 30-40%)
Essential/First-line.target: Epidural mass with cord compression; level(s) of compression; Bilsky grade (0-3); vertebral body involvement; number of levels; intramedullary vs. extramedullary-intradural vs. epidural; cord signal change (T2 hyperintensity = edema/myelopathy — poor prognostic sign); paraspinal soft tissue extension
Essential/First-line.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; severe claustrophobia (sedate); GFR <30 (gadolinium risk — benefit outweighs risk in emergency)

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate while awaiting MRI; identifies vertebral collapse, pathologic fracture, alignment; 70% sensitivity for vertebral metastases (30% miss rate)
Essential/First-line.target: Vertebral body collapse; pedicle erosion ("winking owl sign" on AP); pathologic fracture; kyphosis; alignment

Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24-48h; staging; primary identification; lung is most common primary
Essential/First-line.target: Primary tumor; staging of metastatic disease; lymphadenopathy; visceral metastases

Essential/First-line.timing: If MRI contraindicated or unavailable; pre-operative planning for bone assessment; vertebral body stability (SINS score); CT myelogram if MRI not possible
Essential/First-line.target: Bone destruction pattern (lytic vs. blastic vs. mixed); posterior element involvement; fracture; canal compromise; vertebral body collapse >50%

Extended.timing: If MRI contraindicated (pacemaker, implant); intrathecal contrast via LP → CT; demonstrates level of block
Extended.target: Complete or partial subarachnoid block; level of compression; multiple levels of disease
Extended.contraindications: LP contraindicated if complete block above puncture site (risk of neurologic deterioration); coagulopathy

Extended.timing: Staging; primary identification; assessing treatment response; distinguishing active tumor from treated/necrotic bone
Extended.target: Active metastatic disease; primary tumor identification

Extended.timing: Skeletal staging; identifies additional osseous metastases; blastic > lytic sensitivity; useful for prostate, breast
Extended.target: Additional bone metastases; may miss purely lytic lesions (renal, thyroid, myeloma)

Extended.timing: If lung primary or melanoma (high brain metastasis risk); symptoms suggesting intracranial disease
Extended.target: Brain metastases (concurrent in 10-30% of patients with MSCC)

Extended.timing: Tissue diagnosis if unknown primary; CRITICAL for suspected lymphoma (radiosensitive — may not need surgery); obtain BEFORE steroids if lymphoma suspected (steroids can render biopsy non-diagnostic)
Baseline bone density if prolonged steroids anticipated; osteoporosis risk

Rare/Specialized.timing: If highly vascular tumor suspected (RCC, thyroid) — pre-operative embolization to reduce surgical bleeding
Rare/Specialized.target: Tumor vascularity; feeding vessels; embolization candidacy

Rare/Specialized.timing: Highly vascular metastases (RCC, thyroid); 24-48h before surgery to reduce intraoperative blood loss
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Contrast allergy; tumor supplying anterior spinal artery (risk of cord infarction)

Rare/Specialized.timing: Post-treatment stability assessment; if clinical instability suspected
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Acute cord compression (do NOT flex/extend if acute neurologic deficit)

Rare/Specialized.timing: If thyroid primary suspected (follicular thyroid cancer has high bone tropism)

dosing.instructions: **Standard loading dose:** 10 mg IV bolus STAT; **Then:** 4 mg IV/PO q6h (16 mg/day); **High-dose (severe deficits or rapidly progressive):** 96 mg IV bolus (controversial — see evidence) → 24 mg q6h x 3 days → rapid taper; **Moderate deficits / ambulatory:** 10 mg IV → 4 mg q6h; **Begin taper after definitive treatment initiated;** GI prophylaxis: PPI while on steroids; Monitor glucose q6h

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Sorensen et al. (1994): Dexamethasone + radiation vs. radiation alone → 81% vs. 63% ambulatory at treatment end; High-dose (96 mg) vs. standard (10 mg): Vecht et al. (1989) — higher response rate at 1 week but more side effects; MOST centers now use moderate dose (10 mg load → 16 mg/day); Begin within 6h of diagnosis

dosing.instructions: Strict log-roll precautions; flat bed transport; cervical collar if cervical spine involved; thoracolumbar brace (TLSO) if thoracolumbar; avoid flexion/extension; transfer on spine board if unstable fracture suspected

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Unstable pathologic fracture may worsen cord compression with movement; SINS score guides instability assessment

dosing.instructions: Assess for urinary retention (cord compression causes neurogenic bladder); straight catheterize if retention → place Foley if residual >200 mL or ongoing retention; monitor I&O strictly

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Urinary retention is a common presenting feature and may be the first sign of cord compression; bladder function correlates with motor recovery prognosis

dosing.instructions: SCDs immediately; pharmacologic prophylaxis (enoxaparin 40 mg SQ daily) within 24-48h unless surgery imminent; spinal cord compression patients have VERY HIGH VTE risk (up to 25-50% without prophylaxis)

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Cancer + immobility + spinal cord injury = extremely high VTE risk; mechanical prophylaxis alone insufficient

dosing.instructions: Back pain often severe; acetaminophen 650-1000 mg q6h scheduled + opioids PRN (morphine 2-4 mg IV q3h PRN or oxycodone 5-10 mg PO q4h PRN); NSAIDs cautiously (renal function, bleeding risk); dexamethasone itself reduces pain from edema/inflammation; neuropathic pain: gabapentin 300 mg TID (titrate) or pregabalin 75 mg BID

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Pain is the presenting symptom in 83-95% of patients; median 7 weeks before diagnosis; adequate analgesia essential for function and quality of life

dosing.instructions: Neurogenic bowel from cord compression + opioid constipation; docusate 100 mg BID + senna 2 tabs HS; bisacodyl suppository PRN; monitor for ileus

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Bowel dysfunction common; proactive management prevents complications

dosing.instructions: Fingerstick q6h on high-dose dexamethasone; insulin sliding scale → basal-bolus if persistent >180; anticipate glucose will rise significantly within hours of steroid initiation

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: High-dose dexamethasone causes severe hyperglycemia in majority of patients

dosing.instructions: **Indications (Patchell criteria + expanded):** (1) Single site of compression, (2) Paraplegia ≤48h, (3) Not radiosensitive tumor (not lymphoma, myeloma, SCLC, germ cell), (4) Life expectancy >3 months, (5) ECOG ≤2 / able to tolerate surgery, (6) Mechanical instability (SINS ≥7), (7) Neurologic deterioration during radiation; **Approach:** Posterior decompressive laminectomy ± instrumented stabilization; anterior corpectomy with cage/cement for anterior compression with instability; **Timing:** Within 24h of presentation (ideally <12h); Followed by radiation within 2-4 weeks post-op

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: **Patchell et al. (2005) — LANDMARK:** Surgery + radiation vs. radiation alone: ambulatory rate 84% vs. 57% (p=0.001); maintained ambulation longer (122 vs. 13 days); more patients regained ambulation (62% vs. 19%); surgery retained continence longer; survival trend (126 vs. 100 days)

dosing.instructions: **Primary modality if:** Radiosensitive tumor (lymphoma, myeloma, SCLC, seminoma), surgical contraindication, multiple noncontiguous levels, life expectancy <3 months, poor surgical candidate; **Standard:** 30 Gy in 10 fractions (2 weeks) or 20 Gy in 5 fractions (1 week); **Short course (poor prognosis):** 8 Gy single fraction; **Begin within 24h of diagnosis**; Can start same day as dexamethasone; Radiation field covers 1-2 vertebral bodies above and below involved segment

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Rades et al. (2008): No significant difference between 30 Gy/10 vs. 20 Gy/5 for motor function recovery or local control; 8 Gy single fraction appropriate for poor prognosis (life expectancy <6 months)

dosing.instructions: **Indications:** Previously irradiated segment (re-irradiation); radioresistant histology (RCC, melanoma, sarcoma); oligometastatic disease; post-operative; **Dose:** 16-24 Gy single fraction or 24-30 Gy in 3 fractions; **Requires:** Spinal cord dose constraints (max cord dose 10-14 Gy single fraction); MRI-based planning; **Timing:** As soon as technically feasible
dosing.orderSentence: **Stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT) / Spine SRS** - - - see dosing

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: RTOG 0631 and multiple institutional series: High local control (85-95%) for radioresistant histologies; superior to conventional EBRT for RCC, melanoma; separation surgery + SBRT emerging as preferred approach for radioresistant tumors

dosing.instructions: **Indication:** Epidural tumor compressing cord from radioresistant primary (RCC, melanoma, sarcoma); goal is NOT gross total resection — goal is to decompress cord and create ≥2mm separation between tumor and cord to enable safe SBRT delivery; Followed by SBRT within 2-4 weeks

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Laufer et al. (2013): Separation surgery + SBRT: 90% local control at 1 year for radioresistant tumors; allows definitive radiation dose to tumor while respecting cord tolerance

dosing.instructions: **Indications:** Painful pathologic compression fracture; vertebral body instability; post-radiation pain; NO epidural extension compressing cord (cement leak risk into canal); **SINS 7-12 (indeterminate stability):** Consider as adjunct; **Procedure:** Percutaneous PMMA cement injection into vertebral body

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Pain relief in 70-90% within 24-48h; structural support; does NOT address epidural disease; risk of cement leak into epidural space (1-5%)

dosing.instructions: **Radiosensitive tumors as primary/adjunct therapy:** Lymphoma (R-CHOP or equivalent); myeloma (bortezomib-based); SCLC (cisplatin/etoposide); germ cell (BEP); **Other primaries:** Per disease-specific guidelines after stabilization; coordinate with medical oncology

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Chemosensitive tumors (lymphoma, myeloma, germ cell, SCLC) may respond rapidly to systemic therapy; may be used as primary treatment with radiation or as consolidation post-radiation

dosing.instructions: Prostate cancer: ADT (LHRH agonist/antagonist) + enzalutamide/abiraterone/darolutamide; Breast cancer: anti-estrogen/AI per receptor status; Thyroid: levothyroxine suppression + RAI (spine metastases do NOT concentrate RAI well — external radiation preferred)

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Prostate and breast cancer spinal metastases may respond to hormonal manipulation; adjunct to radiation

dosing.instructions: Begin taper once definitive treatment (surgery/radiation) initiated and neurologic status stable/improving; **Taper schedule:** Reduce by 2-4 mg every 3-5 days; typical: 16→12→8→6→4→2→off over 2-3 weeks; slower taper if symptoms recur; monitor for adrenal insufficiency if >2-3 weeks of steroids

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Prolonged high-dose steroids cause significant morbidity; steroid myopathy (proximal weakness — may mimic neurologic progression); PJP risk; hyperglycemia; GI bleed

dosing.instructions: Omeprazole 20 mg daily or pantoprazole 40 mg daily while on dexamethasone

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Steroid + critical illness increases GI bleed risk

dosing.instructions: Calcium 1000-1200 mg + Vitamin D 800-1000 IU daily during steroid course and beyond (bone health in cancer patients)

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Steroid-induced osteoporosis prevention; already compromised bone integrity

dosing.instructions: Zoledronic acid 4 mg IV q4 weeks OR denosumab 120 mg SQ q4 weeks; reduces skeletal-related events (SRE); dental clearance before starting (ONJ risk); renal adjustment for zoledronic acid (hold if GFR <35)

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Zoledronic acid: Rosen et al. (2003) — reduced SRE by 48% in bone metastases; denosumab: Fizazi et al. (2011) — superior to zoledronic acid for SRE reduction in bone metastases (prostate trial)

dosing.instructions: Gabapentin 300 mg TID → titrate to 600-900 mg TID; OR pregabalin 75 mg BID → titrate to 150-300 mg BID; duloxetine 30-60 mg daily as alternative; amitriptyline 10-25 mg HS (anticholinergic caution with urinary retention)

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Radicular and central neuropathic pain common in cord compression; adjuvant analgesics reduce opioid requirements

dosing.instructions: PT/OT evaluation within 24h of admission; early mobilization when cleared by spine surgery; adaptive equipment; wheelchair assessment if paraparetic/paraplegic; ROM exercises; strengthening; transfer training

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Early rehabilitation improves functional outcomes; cancer rehabilitation is evidence-based; patients with MSCC benefit from structured rehab programs

dosing.instructions: Turn q2h; pressure-reducing mattress; heel protectors; skin assessment with Braden scale; nutrition optimization
dosing.orderSentence: **Skin care / pressure ulcer prevention** - - - see dosing

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Immobile patients with cord compression at very high risk for pressure injuries; prevention is critical

dosing.orderSentence: Methotrexate (high-dose, with spinal radiation) - - - see dosing
Intrathecal chemotherapy (with spinal block) - IT - see dosing
Steroids in suspected lymphoma (BEFORE biopsy) - - - see dosing
Bisphosphonates (if GFR <35 for zoledronic acid) - - - see dosing

Patient Instructions.item: Interventional radiology consultation
Orthotics / bracing
Wound care (post-operative)
Nutrition / dietitian
Psychology / psychiatry
Urology consultation
Home health referral

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Re-irradiation (spine)
Repeat surgery
Intrathecal drug delivery
Cement augmentation (post-radiation)
Hospice referral
Clinical trial enrollment

differential.features: Key Differentiating Features
differential.tests: Distinguishing Studies

differential.features: Fever (present in 50-66%); IV drug use, recent procedure, immunosuppression; rapidly progressive; ESR >20 (sensitivity 94%); CRP markedly elevated; ring-enhancing epidural collection on MRI; restricted diffusion in abscess; spine pain with percussion tenderness; leukocytosis
differential.tests: MRI: T2-hyperintense epidural collection with rim enhancement; restricted diffusion (DWI bright, ADC dark) within abscess; blood cultures (positive in 60%); ESR/CRP markedly elevated; procalcitonin >0.5

differential.features: Chronic progressive symptoms; myelopathic signs insidious onset; no cancer history; disc/osteophyte complex on imaging; NO destructive bone lesion; congenital canal narrowing
differential.tests: MRI: disc-osteophyte complex; ligamentum flavum hypertrophy; NO bone destruction; NO contrast enhancement of epidural mass; chronic degenerative changes

differential.features: Intramedullary (within cord parenchyma); ependymoma, astrocytoma; cord expansion with central lesion; no vertebral body destruction; slow progression; syrinx may be present
differential.tests: MRI: cord expansion with intramedullary enhancing lesion; no epidural mass; no vertebral body involvement; ependymoma: central location, hemosiderin cap; astrocytoma: eccentric, irregular

differential.features: No cancer history; older patient with osteoporosis; acute back pain after minor trauma/lifting; no neurologic deficits (usually); vertebral body collapsed but NO epidural mass; NO posterior element involvement
differential.tests: MRI: vertebral body edema (T1 low, STIR high) WITHOUT epidural mass or posterior element involvement; CT: no bone destruction beyond fracture; DEXA: osteoporosis; if ambiguous → biopsy

differential.features: Older adult; bone pain; anemia, renal insufficiency, hypercalcemia ("CRAB"); diffuse lytic lesions; monoclonal protein on SPEP; punched-out skull lesions; responsive to chemotherapy AND radiation
differential.tests: SPEP: M-protein; UPEP: Bence Jones protein; free light chains: abnormal ratio; bone marrow biopsy: >10% plasma cells; CT/MRI: multiple lytic lesions; biopsy: plasmacytoma; KEY: myeloma is RADIOSENSITIVE — radiation first-line

differential.features: May present as isolated epidural mass; radiosensitive; responds dramatically to steroids (may "melt" before biopsy); younger patients; constitutional symptoms (B symptoms); elevated LDH
differential.tests: MRI: epidural mass; homogeneous enhancement; may be paraspinal; CT: lymphadenopathy; LDH elevated; flow cytometry; KEY: obtain biopsy BEFORE steroids if possible; radiation is primary treatment

differential.features: Intramedullary T2 lesion on MRI (NOT epidural mass); autoimmune history; AQP4/MOG antibodies; longitudinally extensive (≥3 segments in NMOSD); responds to IV steroids/PLEX; no bone lesion
differential.tests: MRI: intramedullary T2 hyperintensity, NOT epidural mass; AQP4-IgG or MOG-IgG positive; CSF: pleocytosis; no vertebral body destruction

differential.features: Acute onset, often on anticoagulation; post-procedural (LP, epidural injection); acute neurogenic deficit; hyperacute T1 signal on MRI (blood)
differential.tests: MRI: epidural collection with blood signal characteristics (T1 hyperintense in subacute phase); history of anticoagulation or procedure; coagulation studies abnormal; neurosurgical emergency

evidence.evidenceLevel: Direct decompressive surgery + radiation vs. radiation alone for MSCC: ambulatory 84% vs. 57% (p=0.001); regained ambulation 62% vs. 19%; maintained ambulation 122 vs. 13 days; maintained continence longer
evidence.source: LANDMARK study establishing surgery + radiation as superior to radiation alone for single-level MSCC in non-radiosensitive tumors with life expectancy >3 months

evidence.evidenceLevel: Dexamethasone + radiation vs. radiation alone: ambulation 81% vs. 63% at end of treatment; 59% vs. 33% at 3 months
evidence.source: Established dexamethasone as standard adjunct to radiation in MSCC

evidence.evidenceLevel: High-dose (96 mg) vs. standard (10 mg) dexamethasone: faster initial response with high-dose but similar outcomes at 1 week; more side effects with high-dose
evidence.source: Most centers now use moderate dose (10 mg load → 16 mg/day) due to side effect profile

evidence.evidenceLevel: Short-course (20 Gy/5 fractions) vs. standard (30 Gy/10 fractions): no significant difference in motor function improvement for patients with poor prognosis
evidence.source: Short-course radiation appropriate for patients with limited life expectancy

evidence.evidenceLevel: Separation surgery + SBRT for radioresistant MSCC: 90% local control at 1 year; enabled delivery of effective radiation doses to previously radioresistant tumors
evidence.source: Established separation surgery + SBRT paradigm for RCC, melanoma, sarcoma spinal metastases

evidence.evidenceLevel: Zoledronic acid reduced skeletal-related events by 48% compared to placebo in bone metastases from breast cancer and myeloma
evidence.source: Standard bone-modifying therapy for cancer-related bone disease

evidence.evidenceLevel: Denosumab superior to zoledronic acid in reducing SRE in prostate cancer bone metastases (HR 0.82, p=0.008)
evidence.source: Denosumab as alternative/preferred bone-modifying agent; no renal adjustment needed

evidence.evidenceLevel: Lung, osteosarcoma, stomach, bladder, esophagus, pancreas

evidence.source: Palliative or excisional surgery depending on factors

evidence.evidenceLevel: Degree of cord compression (Bilsky grade); functional status; myelopathy
evidence.source: High-grade compression (Bilsky 2-3) → surgical decompression; low-grade → radiation alone may suffice

evidence.evidenceLevel: Radiosensitivity; expected tumor response to radiation
evidence.source: Radiosensitive (lymphoma, myeloma, SCLC) → radiation primary; Radioresistant (RCC, melanoma, sarcoma) → surgery + SBRT

evidence.evidenceLevel: Extent of metastatic burden; medical comorbidities; life expectancy
evidence.source: Widespread disease, poor prognosis → palliative approach; oligometastatic → aggressive local treatment

monitoring.item: Neurologic examination (motor strength, sensory level, rectal tone, reflexes)
monitoring.target: Stable or improving motor function; stable sensory level; preserved rectal tone
monitoring.action: If declining: STAT MRI; escalate dexamethasone to 24 mg/day; emergent neurosurgery
Sliding scale → basal-bolus insulin; endocrine consult if refractory
Escalate analgesics; add neuropathic agents; palliative care consultation
IV fluids; vasopressors if neurogenic shock; avoid excessive hypertension (post-operative bleeding risk)
Foley if retention; intermittent catheterization if PVR 200-500
Aggressive bowel regimen; rectal exam; abdominal X-ray if distended
Turn q2h; specialty mattress; heel protectors; wound care if injury develops
If febrile: blood cultures, UA, chest imaging; consider abscess vs. tumor fever
If FVC declining: ICU transfer; prepare for intubation; consider phrenic nerve involvement

disposition.criteria: Criteria

Neurogenic shock (hypotension + bradycardia from spinal cord injury); respiratory compromise from high cervical lesion; post-operative monitoring (first 24h after major spine surgery); acute paraplegia/quadriplegia requiring close monitoring; hemodynamic instability

New MSCC diagnosis requiring workup and treatment planning; surgical candidate awaiting decompression; radiation therapy initiation; motor deficits requiring monitoring and rehabilitation; pain management; high-dose steroid initiation
Known metastatic disease with new pain but preserved neurologic function; MRI showing compression without cord signal change; stable neurologic exam

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH).title: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH)
Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH).scope: ** Spontaneous (non-traumatic) aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage in adults. Covers thunderclap headache evaluation, CT/LP diagnosis, aneurysm identification and securing, vasospasm prevention and treatment (nimodipine, triple-H therapy), hydrocephalus management, and complications. Excludes traumatic SAH, perimesencephalic (non-aneurysmal) SAH management, and intracerebral hemorrhage (separate template).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; thrombocytopenia; leukocytosis (stress response); pre-surgical
Electrolytes (hyponatremia from cerebral salt wasting or SIADH is common); renal/hepatic function
Coagulopathy assessment; pre-procedure; anticoagulant use
Coagulopathy; DIC screen
Surgical intervention likely; potential blood loss
Neurogenic stunned myocardium occurs in 20-30% of SAH; stress cardiomyopathy
Neurogenic cardiac dysfunction; volume status assessment
Hyperglycemia worsens outcomes; stress response
Hypomagnesemia increases vasospasm risk; maintain high-normal
Electrolyte management; nimodipine monitoring
Electrolyte management; refeeding risk
Perfusion status
Affects imaging, anesthesia, and treatment decisions

Extended Workup.rationale: Cerebral salt wasting vs SIADH differentiation; osmotherapy monitoring
CSW: high urine Na, high urine osm, hypovolemic. SIADH: high urine Na, high urine osm, euvolemic
If febrile (differentiate central fever vs infection)

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Pheochromocytoma as cause of hypertensive hemorrhage
Sympathomimetic-associated SAH
Sickle cell associated aneurysms and SAH (young patients, African descent)
Familial aneurysm syndromes; young SAH with marfanoid habitus or skin hyperextensibility

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Distinguish SAH from traumatic tap: SAH = RBC count does NOT clear significantly between tube 1 and tube 4
Lumbar Puncture.target: RBC in tube 4 ≥ tube 1 (SAH); if tube 4 << tube 1 = traumatic tap

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Yellow discoloration from RBC breakdown (bilirubin); develops >6h after SAH; spectrophotometry more sensitive than visual inspection
Lumbar Puncture.target: Present = SAH (sensitivity >95% at 12h-2 weeks post-bleed). Absent = unlikely SAH

Essential/First-line.timing: IMMEDIATE (door-to-CT <25 min). Sensitivity: 98-100% within 6h; ~93% at 12h; ~85% at 24h; declines after 3-5 days
Essential/First-line.target: Hyperdense blood in basal cisterns, Sylvian fissure, interhemispheric fissure; modified Fisher grade; hydrocephalus; intraventricular hemorrhage

Essential/First-line.timing: Simultaneously with non-contrast CT. Identifies aneurysm (sensitivity 95-100% for aneurysms >3mm)
Essential/First-line.target: Aneurysm location, size, morphology; multiple aneurysms (15-20% have >1); vasospasm (delayed)
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Contrast allergy (premedicate); renal impairment (benefit outweighs risk)

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediately
Essential/First-line.target: Deep T-wave inversions ("cerebral T waves"), ST changes, QT prolongation, arrhythmias — all may be neurogenic; do NOT misdiagnose as primary cardiac event

Extended.timing: Within 24h — GOLD STANDARD for aneurysm identification; also therapeutic (coiling). If CTA negative but clinical suspicion high, DSA is mandatory
Extended.target: Aneurysm (location, neck width, dome-to-neck ratio, relationship to branches); may find aneurysm missed by CTA; vasospasm assessment

Extended.timing: At 7-14 days if initial DSA negative and non-perimesencephalic pattern; small aneurysm may be thrombosed or compressed by hematoma
When stable; helpful for subacute diagnosis or if CT negative but suspicion persists
Extended.target: Blood products (FLAIR); aneurysm (MRA); ischemia from vasospasm (DWI)

Extended.timing: Begin daily on post-bleed day 3; continue through day 14 (vasospasm window)
Extended.target: Mean flow velocities: MCA >120 cm/s concerning; >200 cm/s severe vasospasm. Lindegaard ratio >3 suggests vasospasm (>6 = severe)

Extended.timing: If vasospasm suspected clinically (new deficit days 4-14)
Extended.target: Perfusion deficits in vascular territory of spastic vessel; mismatch (reversible ischemia)

Extended.timing: If clinical vasospasm suspected
Extended.target: Arterial narrowing; correlate with TCD and clinical exam

Extended.timing: Within 24-48h
Extended.target: Takotsubo (apical ballooning); regional wall motion abnormalities; EF assessment — neurogenic stunned myocardium in 20-30%

Extended.timing: If altered consciousness; delayed deterioration; suspected seizures
Extended.target: Non-convulsive seizures; electrographic vasospasm correlate; periodic discharges

Extended.timing: On admission; daily in ICU

Rare/Specialized.timing: During DSA for complex aneurysm anatomy
Rare/Specialized.target: Detailed aneurysm morphology for treatment planning

Rare/Specialized.timing: Research/advanced vasospasm assessment

Rare/Specialized.item: MRA screening (unruptured aneurysm in family members)
Rare/Specialized.timing: Elective — for first-degree relatives of SAH patients (2 or more affected family members)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Blood pressure control: Nicardipine IV 5 mg/h IV

dosing.instructions: 5 mg/h IV; titrate by 2.5 mg/h q5-15min; max 15 mg/h. Target SBP <160 mmHg UNTIL aneurysm is secured (re-bleed risk highest in first 24h with uncontrolled HTN); after securing: target SBP <180 (or higher if vasospasm)
dosing.orderSentence: Blood pressure control: Nicardipine IV 5 mg/h IV

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Continuous arterial BP; neuro checks q1h

doseOptions.orderSentence: Blood pressure control: Labetalol IV 10-20 mg IV

dosing.instructions: 10-20 mg IV q10-20min; max 300 mg. Alternative to nicardipine
dosing.orderSentence: Blood pressure control: Labetalol IV 10-20 mg IV

doseOptions.orderSentence: Blood pressure control: Clevidipine IV 1-2 mg/h IV

dosing.instructions: 1-2 mg/h IV; max 32 mg/h
dosing.orderSentence: Blood pressure control: Clevidipine IV 1-2 mg/h IV

doseOptions.orderSentence: Nimodipine (CORNERSTONE of vasospasm prevention) 60 mg IV

dosing.instructions: 60 mg PO/NG q4h x 21 days. START within 96h of SAH onset. If hypotension: 30 mg q2h. This is an ORAL calcium channel blocker — do NOT give IV (severe hypotension). Proven to reduce poor outcomes from vasospasm
dosing.orderSentence: Nimodipine (CORNERSTONE of vasospasm prevention) 60 mg IV

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Hypotension (SBP <90 — reduce dose); do NOT crush extended-release formulations; use oral syringe if NG
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: BP with each dose; do NOT give IV; ensure enteral route only

dosing.instructions: For acute hydrocephalus (GCS declining; CT showing ventriculomegaly); allows ICP monitoring and CSF drainage. Set drain height per neurosurgery (typically 15-20 cm above tragus)

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: ICP continuous; CSF output q1h; drain position; infection surveillance (CSF culture q3 days per some protocols)

dosing.instructions: Levetiracetam 1000 mg IV/PO load, then 500-1000 mg BID. AHA 2012: short-term (3-7 days) prophylaxis is reasonable. Avoid phenytoin (associated with worse cognitive outcomes in SAH — Naidech et al.)
GCS ≤8; inability to protect airway; respiratory failure; impending herniation

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Avoid hypotension during RSI; maintain SBP goal

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: I/O; daily weights; CVP if central line; serum Na q6-8h

dosing.instructions: Continue 60 mg PO q4h x 21 days total
If clinical vasospasm (new deficit days 4-14, aneurysm MUST be secured first): raise SBP to 180-220 mmHg using vasopressors. Phenylephrine 0.5-5 µg/kg/min or norepinephrine 0.05-0.3 µg/kg/min IV

Vasospasm Treatment (Post-Bleed Days 4-1.contraindications: Unsecured aneurysm (NEVER induce hypertension before securing); cardiac failure; pulmonary edema
Vasospasm Treatment (Post-Bleed Days 4-1.monitoring: Arterial line; neuro checks q1h; TCD; CT perfusion

dosing.instructions: NS bolus 500-1000 mL if hypovolemic; maintain euvolemia. Avoid prophylactic hypervolemia (no benefit per current evidence — Robertson et al.)

Vasospasm Treatment (Post-Bleed Days 4-1.monitoring: BP (may cause hypotension); HR; cardiac output

doseOptions.orderSentence: Intra-arterial vasodilator therapy (endovascular rescue) 5-10 mg PO
