dosing.orderSentence: Intra-arterial vasodilator therapy (endovascular rescue) 5-10 mg PO

dosing.instructions: Mechanical dilation of spastic proximal vessels during angiography. For focal proximal vasospasm refractory to medical treatment

Vasospasm Treatment (Post-Bleed Days 4-1.contraindications: Vessel rupture risk; distal vasospasm (not amenable to balloon)

dosing.instructions: Target serum Mg >2.0 mg/dL; replete with MgSO4 2-4 g IV over 1-2h PRN. MASH-2 trial: IV magnesium infusion did NOT improve outcomes, but maintaining normal-high Mg is standard

Vasospasm Treatment (Post-Bleed Days 4-1.monitoring: Serum Mg q12-24h; deep tendon reflexes

Complications Management.item: Hyponatremia management: Differentiate CSW vs SIADH
Complications Management.indication: Na <135: CSW = volume depleted (treat with NS/hypertonic saline + fludrocortisone). SIADH = euvolemic (treat with fluid restriction ± hypertonic saline)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Hyponatremia management: Differentiate CSW vs SIADH 0.1-0.2 mg PO

dosing.instructions: CSW: NS or 3% saline; fludrocortisone 0.1-0.2 mg PO BID. SIADH: fluid restriction 1-1.2 L/day; 3% saline if <120
dosing.orderSentence: Hyponatremia management: Differentiate CSW vs SIADH 0.1-0.2 mg PO

Complications Management.monitoring: Na q6h during correction; avoid >8-10 mEq/L rise in 24h (central pontine myelinolysis risk)

dosing.instructions: 0.1-0.2 mg PO BID

Complications Management.indication: Refractory hyponatremia; cerebral salt wasting; adrenal insufficiency

Neurosurgical procedure

Referrals & Consults.indication: ALL SAH patients; EVD placement; surgical clipping decision; hydrocephalus management
Endovascular coiling; intra-arterial vasospasm treatment; angioplasty
ICU management; vasospasm monitoring; medical optimization
Neurogenic stunned myocardium; Takotsubo; arrhythmia management
Neurogenic pulmonary edema; ARDS; ventilator management
Pituitary dysfunction post-SAH (growth hormone, cortisol, thyroid); diabetes insipidus
Dysphagia evaluation; cognitive-linguistic assessment
Early mobilization when stable; fall prevention; strength
ADL assessment; cognitive rehabilitation
Rehabilitation planning; disposition
Family support; advance directives; discharge planning
Poor-grade SAH (Hunt-Hess IV-V); goals of care
Familial aneurysm screening; connective tissue disorders

Patient Instructions.item: SAH is life-threatening; treatment is time-sensitive
Call 911 immediately if: sudden severe headache ("worst headache of life"), loss of consciousness, seizure, new weakness, vision changes
Blood pressure control is critical long-term — take all prescribed medications
Smoking cessation is essential (smoking is the strongest modifiable risk factor for aneurysm formation and rupture)
Do NOT drive until cleared by neurology/neurosurgery
Avoid heavy lifting, straining, and Valsalva maneuvers for 4-6 weeks
Follow-up imaging (CTA or MRA) at 6 months, then annually for several years to assess treated aneurysm and screen for new aneurysm
First-degree relatives should discuss aneurysm screening with their physician if ≥2 family members have had SAH
Cognitive difficulties (memory, attention, fatigue) are common after SAH — neuropsychological evaluation and rehabilitation are available
Depression and anxiety are common; seek support early

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Smoking cessation (ABSOLUTE — strongest modifiable risk factor)
Blood pressure control (<130/80 mmHg)
Alcohol moderation/cessation (heavy drinking increases SAH risk)
Cocaine/stimulant cessation (vasospasm and SAH risk)
Avoid excessive straining (constipation management; stool softeners)
Regular moderate exercise after recovery and medical clearance
Adequate hydration
Stress management

differential.diagnosis: Thunderclap headache — reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS)
differential.features: Recurrent thunderclap headaches over days-weeks; triggered by exertion, Valsalva, sexual activity; vasospasm on CTA; may have convexity SAH; no aneurysm
differential.tests: CTA (multifocal segmental narrowing); MRI (may show edema, infarct, cortical SAH); DSA; clinical course (resolves in weeks)

differential.features: Parenchymal hematoma with minimal/no subarachnoid blood; hypertensive location (basal ganglia, thalamus)
differential.tests: CT (parenchymal not cisternal); CTA (no aneurysm unless hemorrhage extends into subarachnoid space)

differential.features: Fever, meningismus, altered mental status, CSF neutrophilic pleocytosis with low glucose
differential.tests: LP (gram stain, culture, BioFire); procalcitonin elevated; CT without blood

differential.features: Prior migraine history; gradual onset of associated features; photophobia, phonophobia; no blood on CT
differential.tests: Normal CT; normal LP; clinical history

differential.features: Severely elevated BP; headache; but no blood on CT; may have PRES features
differential.tests: CT (no blood); MRI (PRES: posterior white matter edema)

differential.features: Neck pain, headache, Horner syndrome, stroke; may have traumatic SAH from vertebral dissection
differential.tests: CTA neck (intimal flap, pseudoaneurysm); MRI neck (crescent sign)

differential.features: Headache, seizures; may have hemorrhagic venous infarct or cortical SAH; risk factors (OCPs, pregnancy)
differential.tests: MRV/CT venogram (thrombosed sinus)

differential.features: Sudden headache, visual field defect, ophthalmoplegia; known pituitary adenoma; may have subarachnoid blood from pituitary hemorrhage
differential.tests: MRI sella (hemorrhagic pituitary mass); hormone panel

differential.features: Blood confined to perimesencephalic cisterns (anterior to brainstem); benign course; CTA/DSA negative for aneurysm
differential.tests: CT pattern (perimesencephalic); negative CTA and DSA; excellent prognosis

differential.features: History of trauma; may have other traumatic injuries (contusion, subdural, skull fracture)
differential.tests: Clinical history; CT pattern

differential.features: Sudden back/leg pain with meningismus; blood on lumbar CT or MRI; rare
differential.tests: Spinal MRI; spinal angiography

evidence.recommendation: Nimodipine 60 mg PO q4h x 21 days
evidence.source: Pickard et al. (BMJ 1989); only proven agent to improve outcomes in SAH vasospasm
ISAT; AHA/ASA 2012 SAH Guidelines; de Gans et al. (Stroke 2002)

evidence.recommendation: Endovascular coiling preferred over clipping for most aneurysms
evidence.source: ISAT trial (Molyneux et al. Lancet 2002); long-term follow-up

evidence.recommendation: Induced hypertension for clinical vasospasm (after aneurysm secured)
Avoid phenytoin in SAH (worse cognitive outcomes)

evidence.source: Perry et al. (BMJ 2011); Backes et al. (Stroke 2012)

evidence.recommendation: LP if CT negative but clinical suspicion
Aminocaproic acid (short-term) if aneurysm securing delayed
Magnesium infusion does NOT improve outcomes
evidence.source: MASH-2 trial (Dorhout Mees et al. Lancet 2012)

evidence.recommendation: Intra-arterial vasodilator / balloon angioplasty for refractory vasospasm
Avoid self-fulfilling prophecy in poor-grade SAH
evidence.source: AHA/ASA 2012: aggressive treatment for at least 72h in poor-grade

monitoring.frequency: Continuous via arterial line in ICU. Pre-securing: target SBP <160. Post-securing: allow SBP 120-180 (higher if vasospasm treatment)
q1h x 24h; then q2h x 48h; then q4h. Hunt-Hess grade at admission
monitoring.action: If declining: STAT CT (rebleed, hydrocephalus, infarct); TCD; adjust treatment
Tiered ICP management; CSF drainage; osmotherapy

monitoring.frequency: Daily from day 3 through day 14 (vasospasm window); some continue to day 21
monitoring.action: If MCA >120: CTA/CTP; clinical correlation. If >200: severe vasospasm — consider induced hypertension +/- endovascular rescue
If <135: differentiate CSW vs SIADH; treat accordingly. If <120: 3% saline; limit correction <10 mEq/24h
Central fever (common): cooling; acetaminophen. If >38.3°C: infection workup (cultures, CXR, UA)

monitoring.frequency: Troponin daily x 3; BNP at admission and PRN
monitoring.action: If rising with new ECG changes or hemodynamic instability: echo; cardiology

monitoring.frequency: q1h in ICU; q4h shift on floor
monitoring.action: Avoid dehydration (vasospasm risk); avoid overhydration (pulmonary edema)

monitoring.frequency: At 24h post-admission; with any neurologic change; post-procedure; if new hydrocephalus suspected

monitoring.action: Goals of care if poor grade

disposition.criteria: Never discharge from ED with confirmed SAH. Discharge from hospital when: aneurysm secured; past vasospasm window (day 14-21); stable neurologic exam; Na stable; able to take oral nimodipine; no EVD dependency; adequate follow-up
ALL confirmed aneurysmal SAH patients; minimum 14-21 days ICU-level monitoring during vasospasm window. Transfer to step-down only after vasospasm window passed

disposition.disposition: Transfer to comprehensive stroke center / Neurovascular center
disposition.criteria: If no neurosurgery or interventional neuroradiology on-site — TRANSFER IMMEDIATELY. SAH requires tertiary neurovascular services
Significant deficits but medically stable; past vasospasm window; able to participate in 3h/day therapy
Cannot tolerate intensive rehab; requires ongoing skilled care
Devastating SAH (Hunt-Hess V with poor prognostic factors); after appropriate observation period and family discussion

Syncope.title: Syncope
Syncope.scope: ** Evaluation and management of transient loss of consciousness (TLOC) due to syncope in adults. Includes risk stratification, etiologic workup, and treatment by type. Applies to ED, hospital, and outpatient settings. Excludes seizure, stroke, metabolic causes, and traumatic loss of consciousness.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypoglycemia as cause
Anemia; hemorrhage
Electrolyte abnormalities
Cardiac ischemia as trigger
Heart failure; risk stratification
Ectopic pregnancy; influences workup

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate; ALL patients
Essential/First-line.target: No arrhythmia, normal intervals

Essential/First-line.timing: If admitted
Essential/First-line.target: No arrhythmia

Essential/First-line.timing: If cardiac cause suspected
Essential/First-line.target: Normal structure/function

Essential/First-line.timing: If exertional syncope
Essential/First-line.target: No ischemia, no arrhythmia

Essential/First-line.timing: Suspected cardiomyopathy, ARVC
Essential/First-line.target: Normal or define pathology

Intermittent symptoms
Infrequent, unexplained recurrent syncope
Suspected arrhythmic cause; structural heart disease

Suspected vasovagal if recurrent; dx uncertain
Age >40 with unexplained syncope (not if carotid bruit)
Suspected autonomic failure

Pacemaker for cardioinhibitory carotid sinus syncope
Risk stratification scores (Canadian Syncope Risk Score)

High-risk features (abnormal ECG, cardiac history, exertional, no prodrome, abnormal vitals); unexplained syncope in elderly

Vertigo / Dizziness Evaluation.title: Vertigo / Dizziness Evaluation
Vertigo / Dizziness Evaluation.scope: ** Evaluation and management of acute vertigo and dizziness in adults. Covers differentiation of peripheral vs. central causes, the HINTS exam, Dix-Hallpike and canalith repositioning maneuvers, evaluation for posterior circulation stroke, and management of common vestibular disorders (BPPV, vestibular neuritis, Meniere's disease, vestibular migraine). Excludes chronic non-specific dizziness (persistent postural-perceptual dizziness), medication-induced dizziness (covered briefly), and presyncope/orthostatic hypotension (separate evaluation).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypoglycemia can cause dizziness/lightheadedness; hyperglycemia (diabetic neuropathy); metabolic dizziness
Anemia (lightheadedness, presyncope); infection (labyrinthitis); baseline
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; anemia (Hgb <10) can cause dizziness; infection markers

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Electrolyte abnormalities (hyponatremia, hypoglycemia); renal dysfunction; dehydration
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; hyponatremia <130 can cause neurologic symptoms including imbalance

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Thyroid dysfunction can cause dizziness/imbalance; hyperthyroidism especially
Cardiac arrhythmia causing presyncope/dizziness; differentiates cardiac from vestibular
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; arrhythmia → cardiac workup; prolonged QTc

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Orthostatic hypotension is common cause of dizziness, especially in elderly; drop in SBP >20 or DBP >10 with symptoms
Essential/Core Labs.target: No orthostatic drop; positive orthostatics → volume status, medication review, autonomic evaluation

Extended Workup.rationale: Vascular risk factors if central cause suspected; stroke risk stratification
Diabetes (vascular risk factor; diabetic neuropathy affecting balance)
Neurosyphilis (rare cause of vertigo, especially in HIV); otosyphilis
Extended Workup.target: Negative; positive → CSF analysis, penicillin treatment

Extended Workup.rationale: B12 deficiency causes peripheral neuropathy and imbalance; subacute combined degeneration
Iron deficiency (even without anemia) can cause dizziness
Autoimmune inner ear disease; vasculitis (CNS vasculitis affecting posterior circulation)
Ototoxic medications (aminoglycosides, salicylates); anticonvulsant toxicity (phenytoin, carbamazepine)
Extended Workup.target: Therapeutic; toxic levels → adjust or discontinue

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Confirmatory for syphilis if RPR positive; otosyphilis/neurosyphilis
Lyme disease can cause cranial neuropathies, including vestibular neuritis; endemic areas
Cerebellar ataxia; autoimmune cerebellitis
Paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration (anti-Yo, anti-Hu); subacute ataxia with vertigo
If infectious, inflammatory, or neoplastic cause suspected; normal in peripheral vestibular disorders
Familial episodic ataxia; spinocerebellar ataxia; hereditary vestibular disorders
Rare/Specialized.target: Specific mutations (CACNA1A for EA2; SCA genes)

Lumbar Puncture.timing: NOT routinely indicated for peripheral vestibular disorders; consider if meningitis, MS, CNS vasculitis, or leptomeningeal disease suspected
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal in BPPV, vestibular neuritis, Meniere's; abnormal → specific CNS pathology

Essential/First-line.item: **HINTS exam (Head Impulse, Nystagmus, Test of Skew)**
Essential/First-line.timing: **CRITICAL bedside exam**; must be performed in patient with ACUTE VESTIBULAR SYNDROME (continuous vertigo, nausea, nystagmus, gait instability); performed by trained examiner; more sensitive than early MRI for stroke
Essential/First-line.target: **Peripheral pattern (benign):** Positive head impulse (catch-up saccade), horizontal nystagmus with unidirectional fast phase, no skew deviation; **Central pattern (concerning for stroke):** Negative/normal head impulse, direction-changing or vertical nystagmus, skew deviation
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Cannot perform if patient not having acute continuous vertigo; requires examiner training

Essential/First-line.timing: **NOT sensitive for posterior fossa stroke** (sensitivity ~20-40%); useful for hemorrhage; may be appropriate for trauma or if MRI not available; does NOT rule out posterior circulation stroke
Essential/First-line.target: Cerebellar or brainstem hemorrhage; mass lesion; hydrocephalus; **NEGATIVE CT does NOT exclude stroke in posterior circulation**

Essential/First-line.timing: **Gold standard for posterior circulation stroke**; DWI highly sensitive for acute ischemia; **HOWEVER:** Early MRI (<48h) can miss 12-20% of small posterior fossa strokes — clinical (HINTS) may be more sensitive; repeat MRI if high suspicion and initial negative
Essential/First-line.target: Acute infarction (restricted diffusion); brainstem lesion; cerebellar lesion; MS plaque; tumor; vestibular schwannoma

Essential/First-line.timing: If central cause suspected; vertebral artery dissection; basilar artery stenosis; vertebrobasilar insufficiency
Essential/First-line.target: Vertebral artery dissection; stenosis; occlusion; aneurysm
Essential/First-line.contraindications: MRA: same as MRI; CTA: contrast allergy, renal impairment

Extended.timing: **Diagnostic for BPPV** (posterior canal, most common); performed on ALL patients with episodic positional vertigo; positive if nystagmus and vertigo provoked with latency and limited duration
Extended.target: **Positive:** Upbeating-torsional nystagmus toward affected ear, 2-20 sec latency, <60 sec duration, fatigable with repetition = posterior canal BPPV
Extended.contraindications: Cervical spine disease/instability (modify technique); carotid stenosis (theoretical)

Extended.timing: **Diagnostic for horizontal canal BPPV**; patient supine, rapidly turn head 90° to each side; geotropic (toward ground) or apogeotropic (away from ground) horizontal nystagmus
Extended.target: Horizontal nystagmus provoked by head turning; geotropic (canalithiasis) vs. apogeotropic (cupulolithiasis)

Extended.timing: Essential if hearing loss suspected (Meniere's disease, labyrinthitis, vestibular schwannoma); sudden sensorineural hearing loss is emergency
Extended.target: Meniere's: low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss; Schwannoma: asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss; Labyrinthitis: hearing loss + vertigo

Extended.timing: If cardioembolic source suspected for stroke; PFO evaluation; valvular disease
If paroxysmal arrhythmia suspected as cause of dizziness; palpitations with dizziness
Carotid stenosis (though carotid disease rarely causes isolated vertigo without other symptoms)

Rare/Specialized.timing: Quantitative vestibular function testing; caloric testing (ice water or warm/cool air); localizes peripheral lesion; documents vestibular hypofunction
Rare/Specialized.target: Unilateral weakness on calorics (peripheral lesion); central patterns

Rare/Specialized.timing: Quantitative bedside test of vestibulo-ocular reflex; tests individual semicircular canals; more sensitive than bedside HIT
Rare/Specialized.target: Reduced VOR gain; covert/overt saccades; identifies affected canal

Rare/Specialized.timing: Tests saccule (cVEMP) and utricle (oVEMP); superior semicircular canal dehiscence; Meniere's
Rare/Specialized.target: Abnormal in superior canal dehiscence; saccular dysfunction

Rare/Specialized.timing: Quantitative VOR assessment; bilateral vestibular hypofunction
Superior semicircular canal dehiscence; cholesteatoma; temporal bone abnormality
Rare/Specialized.target: Dehiscence of superior canal; bony erosion

Rare/Specialized.timing: Meniere's disease confirmation; endolymphatic hydrops

dosing.instructions: **Acute severe vertigo:** Meclizine 25-50 mg PO q6-8h; OR Dimenhydrinate (Dramamine) 50 mg PO/IV q6h; OR Promethazine 25 mg PO/IM/IV q6h; OR Ondansetron 4-8 mg IV/PO q8h (for nausea); **IV fluids** for dehydration from vomiting; **Diazepam** 2-5 mg IV/PO for severe acute vertigo (benzodiazepines are potent vestibular suppressants)

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Short-term use only (24-72h); vestibular suppressants interfere with central compensation if used chronically; avoid in suspected central cause until stroke ruled out

dosing.instructions: If dehydrated from vomiting; NS or LR bolus then maintenance; assess orthostatic hypotension

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Supportive care; correct volume depletion

dosing.instructions: Ondansetron 4-8 mg IV/PO; metoclopramide 10 mg IV (avoid in elderly — EPS); prochlorperazine 5-10 mg IV/IM

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Nausea is often the most debilitating symptom

dosing.instructions: **If ANY central features on HINTS:** STAT MRI with DWI; vascular imaging (MRA or CTA); neurology/stroke consultation; **Central features:** Normal/negative head impulse test, vertical or direction-changing nystagmus, skew deviation, focal neurologic signs, severe imbalance (cannot walk), hearing loss + vertigo without Meniere's history

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: HINTS is more sensitive than early CT or MRI for posterior circulation stroke; do NOT rely on negative CT to exclude stroke

dosing.instructions: **For BPPV (positive Dix-Hallpike):** Immediately perform Epley maneuver; highly effective (80-90% single treatment); may repeat if symptoms persist; send home with instructions for home Epley or Brandt-Daroff exercises

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Epley is definitive treatment for posterior canal BPPV; medications are NOT indicated for BPPV — repositioning maneuvers are the treatment

dosing.instructions: Standard canalith repositioning; patient starts seated, Dix-Hallpike position for 30 sec, rotate head 90° toward opposite side (30 sec), roll body to face down with head still turned (30 sec), sit up; NNT = 2-3 for resolution

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: First-line treatment for posterior canal BPPV; highly effective; may repeat same day or next visit

dosing.instructions: Alternative to Epley; patient moved rapidly from side to side; less commonly used but effective

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Alternative if Epley difficult or ineffective

dosing.instructions: For horizontal canal BPPV; patient rotates 360° along long axis of body (log roll) toward unaffected side; 90° increments with 30 sec pauses
dosing.orderSentence: **BBQ roll (Lempert maneuver) — horizontal canal** - - - see dosing

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Treatment for horizontal canal BPPV; geotropic variant

dosing.instructions: Patient alternates lying on each side x 30 sec, 10-20 repetitions, 3x daily; habituates symptoms; less effective than Epley for posterior canal

Disease-Specific Treatment.monitoring: Adjunctive home therapy; may help with residual symptoms; promotes compensation

dosing.instructions: Do NOT prescribe meclizine for ongoing BPPV treatment; medications delay compensation and do not address the mechanical problem
dosing.orderSentence: **Avoid vestibular suppressants for BPPV** - - - see dosing

evidence.evidenceLevel: HINTS exam (H: head impulse; I: nystagmus; TS: test of skew) was 100% sensitive and 96% specific for stroke in acute vestibular syndrome; superior to MRI in first 24-48h

evidence.source: Epley is definitive treatment for BPPV

evidence.evidenceLevel: Individual HINTS components analyzed; normal head impulse most predictive of stroke

evidence.evidenceLevel: 12-20% of posterior fossa strokes missed on early MRI (<48h) but detected on repeat MRI

Wernicke Encephalopathy.title: Wernicke Encephalopathy
icd10: unspecified with alcohol-induced persisting amnestic disorder)
Wernicke Encephalopathy.scope: ** Diagnosis and treatment of Wernicke encephalopathy in adults including classic and non-alcoholic etiologies. Covers acute treatment, prevention of Korsakoff syndrome, and at-risk populations. Applies primarily to ED, hospital, and ICU settings as this is a medical emergency. Excludes chronic Korsakoff syndrome management.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypoglycemia; DO NOT give dextrose before thiamine
Electrolytes; magnesium essential for thiamine function
Required cofactor for thiamine; replace if low
Refeeding syndrome risk
Macrocytic anemia (alcohol, B12/folate deficiency)
Hepatic dysfunction; malnutrition
Hepatic encephalopathy (may coexist)
Thiamine deficiency causes lactic acidosis
Document; withdrawal risk

Extended Workup.item: Thiamine level (whole blood or RBC transketolase)
Extended Workup.rationale: Confirms deficiency (do not delay treatment for result)

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Functional thiamine status; low in deficiency
>25% increase suggests deficiency
If meningitis suspected; usually normal in WE

Essential/First-line.timing: After stabilization; supports diagnosis
Essential/First-line.target: Bilateral symmetric T2/FLAIR hyperintensity in medial thalami, mammillary bodies, periaqueductal gray, tectal plate

Essential/First-line.timing: Exclude other causes (hemorrhage, mass); often normal in WE
Essential/First-line.target: No mass, hemorrhage

Rare/Specialized.timing: If seizure suspected or encephalopathy unclear
If meningitis or encephalitis suspected

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Wernicke encephalopathy is a medical emergency caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency
Without treatment, permanent brain damage (Korsakoff syndrome) can occur
Take thiamine supplements as prescribed
If alcohol use disorder: Thiamine is critical; take before drinking if relapse
Alcohol cessation is essential to prevent recurrence
Eat a balanced diet; malnutrition worsens risk
Report confusion, vision changes, unsteady walking
SAMHSA helpline 1-800-662-4357 for alcohol treatment resources

Intracerebral Hemorrhage.title: Intracerebral Hemorrhage
Intracerebral Hemorrhage.scope: ** Spontaneous (non-traumatic) intracerebral hemorrhage in adults. Covers acute BP management, anticoagulant reversal, ICH score and prognosis, ICP management, surgical indications, etiology workup, and secondary prevention. Excludes traumatic ICH, subarachnoid hemorrhage (separate template), hemorrhagic transformation of ischemic stroke, and subdural/epidural hematomas.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; thrombocytopenia as cause or complication; transfusion needs
Warfarin-related ICH requires emergent reversal; coagulopathy assessment
Heparin-related ICH; coagulopathy
DIC; consumptive coagulopathy; tPA-related hemorrhage
Electrolytes; renal function for contrast/medication; hepatic function for coagulopathy
Hyperglycemia worsens ICH outcomes; hypoglycemia mimics stroke
Potential need for blood products, surgery, reversal agents
Essential/Core Labs.target: On file; crossmatch if OR likely

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Neurogenic cardiac injury (stress cardiomyopathy); concurrent ACS
Coagulopathy; exam reliability; alcoholism is ICH risk factor
Cocaine/amphetamine-associated ICH (sympathomimetic surge)
Affects management (eclampsia differential; imaging)

Essential/Core Labs.item: Thrombin time (TT) and/or ecarin clotting time (ECT)
Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Dabigatran (direct thrombin inhibitor) detection; if patient on DOACs
Rivaroxaban/apixaban/edoxaban detection; guides reversal need

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Young patient ICH without clear etiology; cerebral venous thrombosis with secondary hemorrhage
CNS vasculitis-related hemorrhage
Sympathomimetic drug use; synthetic drug-associated hemorrhage
Cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA) confirmation; research context
Rare/Specialized.target: Positive amyloid deposition in lobar distribution

Rare/Specialized.rationale: CAA risk stratification; APOE ε2/ε4 associated with ICH

Essential/First-line.timing: Door-to-CT <25 minutes; determines ICH diagnosis, location, volume, IVH, hydrocephalus, midline shift
Essential/First-line.target: Hemorrhage location (deep: basal ganglia/thalamus = hypertensive; lobar: CAA, tumor, AVM), volume (ABC/2 method), intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), hydrocephalus, midline shift >5mm

Essential/First-line.timing: With initial CT; identify "spot sign" (active contrast extravasation = hematoma expansion risk), underlying vascular malformation (AVM, aneurysm)
Essential/First-line.target: Spot sign (30-50% risk of expansion); AVM; aneurysm; dural AV fistula; Moyamoya
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Contrast allergy; renal impairment (benefit outweighs risk in emergency)

Essential/First-line.timing: Baseline; neurogenic cardiac injury; arrhythmia; QTc prolongation risk
Essential/First-line.target: Normal; ST changes may be neurogenic

Essential/First-line.timing: At 6h and 24h OR any neurologic decline; assess for hematoma expansion (>33% or >6mL increase from baseline = significant expansion)
Essential/First-line.target: Stable hematoma size; no new hemorrhage; no hydrocephalus progression

Extended.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (include GRE/SWI sequences)
Extended.timing: Within 24-72h when stable; or urgently if underlying mass/AVM suspected
Extended.target: Underlying tumor; cavernous malformation; microbleeds (CAA pattern: lobar; hypertensive: deep). SWI shows microhemorrhages

Extended.timing: If cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) suspected as cause of hemorrhagic venous infarct
Young patient (<50) with lobar ICH and no clear etiology; suspected AVM/aneurysm where CTA inconclusive; negative initial CTA but high suspicion
Extended.target: AVM; aneurysm; dural AV fistula; Moyamoya; vasculitis

Extended.timing: Repeat at 3-6 months; small AVM may be compressed by acute hematoma and missed initially
Neurogenic cardiac injury; baseline cardiac function; endocarditis if mycotic aneurysm suspected
If altered consciousness disproportionate to hemorrhage size; suspected seizures
Extended.target: Non-convulsive seizures; NCSE (seen in 20-30% of ICH patients)

Extended.timing: Aspiration; pulmonary edema (neurogenic); baseline for ventilator

Rare/Specialized.timing: If underlying tumor, vasculitis, or amyloid angiopathy suspected and non-invasive workup inconclusive
CAA diagnosis in lobar ICH with microbleeds

doseOptions.orderSentence: Blood pressure reduction: Nicardipine IV 5 mg/h IV

dosing.instructions: 5 mg/h IV; increase by 2.5 mg/h q5-15min; max 15 mg/h. Target SBP 130-150 mmHg (INTERACT2: <140 safe; AHA 2022: <140 reasonable if presenting SBP 150-220)
dosing.orderSentence: Blood pressure reduction: Nicardipine IV 5 mg/h IV

4 mg IV q6h PRN

Surgical Interventions.indication: IVH with acute hydrocephalus; GCS declining; need for ICP monitoring

dosing.instructions: Neurosurgery places; allows CSF drainage and ICP monitoring; target ICP <22, CPP >60

dosing.instructions: Alteplase 1 mg q8h via EVD; up to 12 doses; clamp EVD 1h after dosing then open to drain

dosing.instructions: Craniotomy or craniectomy for clot evacuation

Surgical Interventions.contraindications: Deep ICH (generally no benefit from open surgery); GCS 3-4 without brainstem reflexes (futile); severe coagulopathy

Surgical Interventions.item: Minimally invasive surgery (MIS) — endoscopic or stereotactic aspiration
Surgical Interventions.indication: Supratentorial ICH >30 mL with stable or mild deficits (MISTIE III, ENRICH trials: emerging data; ENRICH showed benefit for lobar ICH)

dosing.instructions: Stereotactic catheter-based aspiration or endoscopic evacuation with lower morbidity than craniotomy
dosing.orderSentence: Minimally invasive surgery (MIS) — endoscopic or stereotactic aspiration - - - see dosing

Surgical Interventions.indication: Massive ICH with refractory elevated ICP; malignant cerebellar edema

dosing.instructions: Bone flap removal to allow brain expansion

Surgical Interventions.contraindications: Futile prognosis; bilateral fixed dilated pupils

dosing.instructions: Posterior fossa decompression; life-saving for cerebellar ICH with brainstem compression

Secondary Prevention (After Acute Phase).indication: ALL ICH patients; BP is most important modifiable risk factor

dosing.instructions: Target SBP <130 mmHg (SPS3 trial, PROGRESS trial); agent choice per comorbidities (ACE-I, ARB, CCB, thiazide)

Secondary Prevention (After Acute Phase).indication: Risk-benefit discussion; SPARCL showed small increased ICH risk with atorvastatin but overall cardiovascular benefit. AHA 2022: statin not contraindicated after ICH

dosing.instructions: Per cardiovascular risk; individualize

Secondary Prevention (After Acute Phase).item: Anticoagulation restart (if AF or mechanical valve)
Secondary Prevention (After Acute Phase).indication: Most controversial decision. AHA 2022: may restart anticoagulation at 4-8 weeks for patients with strong indication (AF with high CHA2DS2-VASc). Avoid in CAA-related lobar ICH if possible

dosing.instructions: Apixaban preferred (APACHE-AF trial: lowest ICH recurrence). Timing: 4-8 weeks; individualized risk-benefit
dosing.orderSentence: Anticoagulation restart (if AF or mechanical valve) - PO - see dosing

Secondary Prevention (After Acute Phase).monitoring: Imaging stability; bleeding risk; CHA2DS2-VASc vs HAS-BLED

Secondary Prevention (After Acute Phase).indication: RESTART trial: restarting antiplatelet after ICH is associated with LOWER risk of recurrent ICH; may restart at 2-4 weeks for patients with cardiovascular indication

dosing.instructions: Aspirin 81 mg or clopidogrel 75 mg daily

Secondary Prevention (After Acute Phase).indication: AF patients who cannot tolerate long-term anticoagulation post-ICH (lobar ICH, CAA)

dosing.instructions: Interventional cardiology procedure; eliminates need for long-term anticoagulation in AF
dosing.orderSentence: Left atrial appendage occlusion (LAAO/Watchman) - Procedure - see dosing

Referrals & Consults.indication: ALL ICH patients; surgical decision for EVD, hematoma evacuation, decompression
Medical management; BP optimization; ICP management; seizure management
Anticoagulant reversal guidance; coagulopathy management; thrombocytopenia
Reversal agent dosing; anticoagulant identification; drug interactions
AF management; anticoagulation restart decision; LAAO evaluation; neurogenic cardiac injury
Dysphagia screening before PO intake; aphasia assessment
Early mobilization (24-48h if stable); fall prevention; strength
ADL assessment; cognitive rehabilitation; adaptive equipment
Rehabilitation disposition; functional prognosis
Family support; advance directives; discharge planning
Goals of care discussion (especially ICH score ≥3); early palliative involvement improves care quality
AVM/aneurysm treatment planning; dural AV fistula

Patient Instructions.item: ICH is serious but outcomes vary; early aggressive treatment improves survival
Call 911 if: sudden headache, new weakness, speech changes, altered consciousness
Blood pressure control is the MOST IMPORTANT factor in preventing recurrence
Take all medications as prescribed; never stop blood pressure medications without physician guidance
Do NOT restart anticoagulation or antiplatelet without specific neurology/cardiology guidance
Home blood pressure monitoring daily; keep log; target per physician guidance
Follow-up with neurology in 2-4 weeks; neurosurgery if applicable
Do NOT drive until cleared
Fall prevention at home

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Blood pressure target <130/80 mmHg (most important)
Smoking cessation (doubles ICH risk)
Alcohol cessation or limitation (heavy drinking increases ICH risk)
Cocaine/amphetamine cessation (sympathomimetic ICH)
Avoid excessive anticoagulation (keep INR in range if on warfarin)
Regular exercise (moderate intensity after recovery)
Weight management
DASH or Mediterranean diet
Depression screening (PHQ-9 at 1-3 months)

differential.diagnosis: Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) with hemorrhagic infarct

differential.features: Subacute symptoms preceding hemorrhage; ring enhancement around hemorrhage; disproportionate edema

differential.features: Lobar location (NOT deep); age >55; recurrent lobar hemorrhages; cortical superficial siderosis; multiple lobar microbleeds on SWI
differential.tests: MRI SWI (lobar microbleeds, superficial siderosis); Boston criteria

differential.features: Younger patient; recurrent hemorrhages at same location; AVM on CTA/DSA; cavernoma on MRI (popcorn appearance)
differential.tests: CTA; DSA; MRI (especially SWI)

differential.features: Subarachnoid + intraparenchymal hemorrhage; near aneurysm location
differential.tests: CTA (aneurysm); DSA

differential.features: Deep location (putamen, thalamus, pons, cerebellum); history of poorly controlled HTN

differential.features: Young adults or Asian patients; recurrent stroke; stenotic proximal vessels with collateral network
