q1h x 24h, then q2h x 24h, then q4h
monitoring.action: If declining: STAT CT; ICP assessment; neurosurgery
Tiered ICP management: drain CSF → osmotherapy → sedation → hypothermia → decompression

monitoring.frequency: At 6h (routine); at 24h; and with ANY neurologic decline
monitoring.action: If expanding: re-evaluate BP; reversal; surgical consultation
Aggressive fever management; cooling devices; infection workup

monitoring.frequency: 15 min after PCC; then q6h x 24h; then daily

monitoring.action: Goals of care discussion if score ≥3

disposition.criteria: Small ICH; stable exam; GCS 15; ambulatory; adequate home support; medications filled; BP controlled; follow-up arranged
Small-moderate ICH; GCS 13-15; no surgical indication; stable repeat CT; BP controlled on oral/IV medications
ALL moderate-large ICH; GCS <13 or declining; anticoagulant-related ICH; posterior fossa ICH; IVH with hydrocephalus; EVD in place; requiring arterial line and IV antihypertensives; post-surgical
Cerebellar ICH >3 cm with brainstem compression or hydrocephalus; deteriorating lobar ICH >30 mL; obstructive hydrocephalus needing EVD
Need for neurosurgery not available; need for neuro-ICU; need for reversal agents not available; need for endovascular treatment
Significant deficits but able to participate in 3h/day therapy; medically stable
ICH score ≥4; devastating ICH with poor prognosis after family goals of care discussion

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage.title: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
Subarachnoid Hemorrhage.scope: ** Spontaneous (non-traumatic) aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage in adults. Covers thunderclap headache evaluation, CT/LP diagnosis, aneurysm identification and securing, vasospasm prevention and treatment (nimodipine, triple-H therapy), hydrocephalus management, and complications. Excludes traumatic SAH, perimesencephalic (non-aneurysmal) SAH management, and intracerebral hemorrhage (separate template).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; thrombocytopenia; leukocytosis (stress response); pre-surgical
Electrolytes (hyponatremia from cerebral salt wasting or SIADH is common); renal/hepatic function
Coagulopathy assessment; pre-procedure; anticoagulant use
Coagulopathy; DIC screen
Surgical intervention likely; potential blood loss
Neurogenic stunned myocardium occurs in 20-30% of SAH; stress cardiomyopathy
Neurogenic cardiac dysfunction; volume status assessment
Hyperglycemia worsens outcomes; stress response
Hypomagnesemia increases vasospasm risk; maintain high-normal
Electrolyte management; nimodipine monitoring
Electrolyte management; refeeding risk
Perfusion status
Affects imaging, anesthesia, and treatment decisions

Extended Workup.rationale: Cerebral salt wasting vs SIADH differentiation; osmotherapy monitoring
CSW: high urine Na, high urine osm, hypovolemic. SIADH: high urine Na, high urine osm, euvolemic
If febrile (differentiate central fever vs infection)

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Pheochromocytoma as cause of hypertensive hemorrhage
Sympathomimetic-associated SAH
Sickle cell associated aneurysms and SAH (young patients, African descent)
Familial aneurysm syndromes; young SAH with marfanoid habitus or skin hyperextensibility

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Distinguish SAH from traumatic tap: SAH = RBC count does NOT clear significantly between tube 1 and tube 4
Lumbar Puncture.target: RBC in tube 4 ≥ tube 1 (SAH); if tube 4 << tube 1 = traumatic tap

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Yellow discoloration from RBC breakdown (bilirubin); develops >6h after SAH; spectrophotometry more sensitive than visual inspection
Lumbar Puncture.target: Present = SAH (sensitivity >95% at 12h-2 weeks post-bleed). Absent = unlikely SAH

Essential/First-line.timing: IMMEDIATE (door-to-CT <25 min). Sensitivity: 98-100% within 6h; ~93% at 12h; ~85% at 24h; declines after 3-5 days
Essential/First-line.target: Hyperdense blood in basal cisterns, Sylvian fissure, interhemispheric fissure; modified Fisher grade; hydrocephalus; intraventricular hemorrhage

Essential/First-line.timing: Simultaneously with non-contrast CT. Identifies aneurysm (sensitivity 95-100% for aneurysms >3mm)
Essential/First-line.target: Aneurysm location, size, morphology; multiple aneurysms (15-20% have >1); vasospasm (delayed)
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Contrast allergy (premedicate); renal impairment (benefit outweighs risk)

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediately
Essential/First-line.target: Deep T-wave inversions ("cerebral T waves"), ST changes, QT prolongation, arrhythmias — all may be neurogenic; do NOT misdiagnose as primary cardiac event

Extended.timing: Within 24h — GOLD STANDARD for aneurysm identification; also therapeutic (coiling). If CTA negative but clinical suspicion high, DSA is mandatory
Extended.target: Aneurysm (location, neck width, dome-to-neck ratio, relationship to branches); may find aneurysm missed by CTA; vasospasm assessment

Extended.timing: At 7-14 days if initial DSA negative and non-perimesencephalic pattern; small aneurysm may be thrombosed or compressed by hematoma
When stable; helpful for subacute diagnosis or if CT negative but suspicion persists
Extended.target: Blood products (FLAIR); aneurysm (MRA); ischemia from vasospasm (DWI)

Extended.timing: Begin daily on post-bleed day 3; continue through day 14 (vasospasm window)
Extended.target: Mean flow velocities: MCA >120 cm/s concerning; >200 cm/s severe vasospasm. Lindegaard ratio >3 suggests vasospasm (>6 = severe)

Extended.timing: If vasospasm suspected clinically (new deficit days 4-14)
Extended.target: Perfusion deficits in vascular territory of spastic vessel; mismatch (reversible ischemia)

Extended.timing: If clinical vasospasm suspected
Extended.target: Arterial narrowing; correlate with TCD and clinical exam

Extended.timing: Within 24-48h
Extended.target: Takotsubo (apical ballooning); regional wall motion abnormalities; EF assessment — neurogenic stunned myocardium in 20-30%

Extended.timing: If altered consciousness; delayed deterioration; suspected seizures
Extended.target: Non-convulsive seizures; electrographic vasospasm correlate; periodic discharges

Extended.timing: On admission; daily in ICU

Rare/Specialized.timing: During DSA for complex aneurysm anatomy
Rare/Specialized.target: Detailed aneurysm morphology for treatment planning

Rare/Specialized.timing: Research/advanced vasospasm assessment

Rare/Specialized.item: MRA screening (unruptured aneurysm in family members)
Rare/Specialized.timing: Elective — for first-degree relatives of SAH patients (2 or more affected family members)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Blood pressure control: Nicardipine IV 5 mg/h IV

dosing.instructions: 5 mg/h IV; titrate by 2.5 mg/h q5-15min; max 15 mg/h. Target SBP <160 mmHg UNTIL aneurysm is secured (re-bleed risk highest in first 24h with uncontrolled HTN); after securing: target SBP <180 (or higher if vasospasm)
dosing.orderSentence: Blood pressure control: Nicardipine IV 5 mg/h IV

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Continuous arterial BP; neuro checks q1h

doseOptions.orderSentence: Blood pressure control: Labetalol IV 10-20 mg IV

dosing.instructions: 10-20 mg IV q10-20min; max 300 mg. Alternative to nicardipine
dosing.orderSentence: Blood pressure control: Labetalol IV 10-20 mg IV

doseOptions.orderSentence: Blood pressure control: Clevidipine IV 1-2 mg/h IV

dosing.instructions: 1-2 mg/h IV; max 32 mg/h
dosing.orderSentence: Blood pressure control: Clevidipine IV 1-2 mg/h IV

doseOptions.orderSentence: Nimodipine (CORNERSTONE of vasospasm prevention) 60 mg IV

dosing.instructions: 60 mg PO/NG q4h x 21 days. START within 96h of SAH onset. If hypotension: 30 mg q2h. This is an ORAL calcium channel blocker — do NOT give IV (severe hypotension). Proven to reduce poor outcomes from vasospasm
dosing.orderSentence: Nimodipine (CORNERSTONE of vasospasm prevention) 60 mg IV

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Hypotension (SBP <90 — reduce dose); do NOT crush extended-release formulations; use oral syringe if NG
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: BP with each dose; do NOT give IV; ensure enteral route only

dosing.instructions: For acute hydrocephalus (GCS declining; CT showing ventriculomegaly); allows ICP monitoring and CSF drainage. Set drain height per neurosurgery (typically 15-20 cm above tragus)

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: ICP continuous; CSF output q1h; drain position; infection surveillance (CSF culture q3 days per some protocols)

dosing.instructions: Levetiracetam 1000 mg IV/PO load, then 500-1000 mg BID. AHA 2012: short-term (3-7 days) prophylaxis is reasonable. Avoid phenytoin (associated with worse cognitive outcomes in SAH — Naidech et al.)
GCS ≤8; inability to protect airway; respiratory failure; impending herniation

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Avoid hypotension during RSI; maintain SBP goal

dosing.instructions: 4g IV load then 1g/h IV infusion. ONLY use for short-term (<72h) if aneurysm securing will be delayed. Reduces re-bleeding risk but increases thrombotic risk. Discontinue once aneurysm is secured

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Coagulation; thrombotic events; discontinue when aneurysm treated

dosing.instructions: NS at 1-1.5 mL/kg/h (80-125 mL/h); goal euvolemia. Avoid hypovolemia (worsens vasospasm) and avoid aggressive hypervolemia (no proven benefit; risk of pulmonary edema). Target CVP 5-8 or clinical euvolemia

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: I/O; daily weights; CVP if central line; serum Na q6-8h

doseOptions.orderSentence: Stress ulcer prophylaxis: Pantoprazole 40 mg IV

dosing.instructions: 40 mg IV/PO daily
dosing.orderSentence: Stress ulcer prophylaxis: Pantoprazole 40 mg IV

dosing.instructions: Apply bilaterally on admission; SAH patients are HIGH VTE risk
dosing.orderSentence: DVT prophylaxis: Pneumatic compression devices - - - see dosing

Acute/Emergent.item: DVT prophylaxis: Heparin SC (after aneurysm secured)

doseOptions.orderSentence: DVT prophylaxis: Heparin SC (after aneurysm secured) 5000 units SC

dosing.instructions: 5000 units SC q8h; start 24h after aneurysm is secured (clipping or coiling); some centers start earlier
dosing.orderSentence: DVT prophylaxis: Heparin SC (after aneurysm secured) 5000 units SC

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Active bleeding; within 24h of craniotomy (per surgeon)

dosing.instructions: Interventional neuroradiology; catheter-based platinum coil deployment into aneurysm sac. Preferred per ISAT trial for posterior circulation and many anterior circulation aneurysms

Aneurysm Securing (Definitive Treatment).contraindications: Difficult vascular access; very wide neck without stent option

dosing.instructions: Neurosurgical; microsurgical clip placement across aneurysm neck

Aneurysm Securing (Definitive Treatment).contraindications: Poor grade with brain swelling (relative — may clip if accessible); medically unstable

dosing.instructions: For large/giant or wide-necked aneurysms not amenable to standard coiling

Aneurysm Securing (Definitive Treatment).contraindications: Requires dual antiplatelet therapy (may not be ideal in acute SAH)

dosing.instructions: Continue 60 mg PO q4h x 21 days total
If clinical vasospasm (new deficit days 4-14, aneurysm MUST be secured first): raise SBP to 180-220 mmHg using vasopressors. Phenylephrine 0.5-5 µg/kg/min or norepinephrine 0.05-0.3 µg/kg/min IV

Vasospasm Treatment (Post-Bleed Days 4-1.contraindications: Unsecured aneurysm (NEVER induce hypertension before securing); cardiac failure; pulmonary edema
Vasospasm Treatment (Post-Bleed Days 4-1.monitoring: Arterial line; neuro checks q1h; TCD; CT perfusion

dosing.instructions: NS bolus 500-1000 mL if hypovolemic; maintain euvolemia. Avoid prophylactic hypervolemia (no benefit per current evidence — Robertson et al.)
0.25-0.75 µg/kg/min IV continuous; some centers use as rescue for vasospasm not responding to induced hypertension; acts as cerebral vasodilator
dosing.orderSentence: Milrinone IV (alternative vasospasm treatment) - IV - see dosing

Vasospasm Treatment (Post-Bleed Days 4-1.monitoring: BP (may cause hypotension); HR; cardiac output

doseOptions.orderSentence: Intra-arterial vasodilator therapy (endovascular rescue) 5-10 mg PO

dosing.instructions: Verapamil 5-10 mg intra-arterial or nicardipine 5-10 mg intra-arterial; via catheter into spastic vessel during angiography. For medically refractory vasospasm
dosing.orderSentence: Intra-arterial vasodilator therapy (endovascular rescue) 5-10 mg PO

dosing.instructions: Mechanical dilation of spastic proximal vessels during angiography. For focal proximal vasospasm refractory to medical treatment

Vasospasm Treatment (Post-Bleed Days 4-1.contraindications: Vessel rupture risk; distal vasospasm (not amenable to balloon)

dosing.instructions: Target serum Mg >2.0 mg/dL; replete with MgSO4 2-4 g IV over 1-2h PRN. MASH-2 trial: IV magnesium infusion did NOT improve outcomes, but maintaining normal-high Mg is standard

Vasospasm Treatment (Post-Bleed Days 4-1.monitoring: Serum Mg q12-24h; deep tendon reflexes

Complications Management.item: Hyponatremia management: Differentiate CSW vs SIADH
Complications Management.indication: Na <135: CSW = volume depleted (treat with NS/hypertonic saline + fludrocortisone). SIADH = euvolemic (treat with fluid restriction ± hypertonic saline)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Hyponatremia management: Differentiate CSW vs SIADH 0.1-0.2 mg PO

dosing.instructions: CSW: NS or 3% saline; fludrocortisone 0.1-0.2 mg PO BID. SIADH: fluid restriction 1-1.2 L/day; 3% saline if <120
dosing.orderSentence: Hyponatremia management: Differentiate CSW vs SIADH 0.1-0.2 mg PO

Complications Management.monitoring: Na q6h during correction; avoid >8-10 mEq/L rise in 24h (central pontine myelinolysis risk)

dosing.instructions: 0.1-0.2 mg PO BID

Complications Management.indication: Refractory hyponatremia; cerebral salt wasting; adrenal insufficiency

dosing.instructions: 50-100 mg IV q8h
Neurosurgical procedure

Complications Management.indication: CSF diversion after EVD if transitioning; mild chronic hydrocephalus

dosing.instructions: Neurosurgical placement

Referrals & Consults.indication: ALL SAH patients; EVD placement; surgical clipping decision; hydrocephalus management
Endovascular coiling; intra-arterial vasospasm treatment; angioplasty
ICU management; vasospasm monitoring; medical optimization
Neurogenic stunned myocardium; Takotsubo; arrhythmia management
Neurogenic pulmonary edema; ARDS; ventilator management
Pituitary dysfunction post-SAH (growth hormone, cortisol, thyroid); diabetes insipidus
Dysphagia evaluation; cognitive-linguistic assessment
Early mobilization when stable; fall prevention; strength
ADL assessment; cognitive rehabilitation
Rehabilitation planning; disposition
Family support; advance directives; discharge planning
Poor-grade SAH (Hunt-Hess IV-V); goals of care
Familial aneurysm screening; connective tissue disorders

Patient Instructions.item: SAH is life-threatening; treatment is time-sensitive
Call 911 immediately if: sudden severe headache ("worst headache of life"), loss of consciousness, seizure, new weakness, vision changes
Blood pressure control is critical long-term — take all prescribed medications
Smoking cessation is essential (smoking is the strongest modifiable risk factor for aneurysm formation and rupture)
Do NOT drive until cleared by neurology/neurosurgery
Avoid heavy lifting, straining, and Valsalva maneuvers for 4-6 weeks
Follow-up imaging (CTA or MRA) at 6 months, then annually for several years to assess treated aneurysm and screen for new aneurysm
First-degree relatives should discuss aneurysm screening with their physician if ≥2 family members have had SAH
Cognitive difficulties (memory, attention, fatigue) are common after SAH — neuropsychological evaluation and rehabilitation are available
Depression and anxiety are common; seek support early

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Smoking cessation (ABSOLUTE — strongest modifiable risk factor)
Blood pressure control (<130/80 mmHg)
Alcohol moderation/cessation (heavy drinking increases SAH risk)
Cocaine/stimulant cessation (vasospasm and SAH risk)
Avoid excessive straining (constipation management; stool softeners)
Regular moderate exercise after recovery and medical clearance
Adequate hydration
Stress management

differential.diagnosis: Thunderclap headache — reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS)
differential.features: Recurrent thunderclap headaches over days-weeks; triggered by exertion, Valsalva, sexual activity; vasospasm on CTA; may have convexity SAH; no aneurysm
differential.tests: CTA (multifocal segmental narrowing); MRI (may show edema, infarct, cortical SAH); DSA; clinical course (resolves in weeks)

differential.features: Parenchymal hematoma with minimal/no subarachnoid blood; hypertensive location (basal ganglia, thalamus)
differential.tests: CT (parenchymal not cisternal); CTA (no aneurysm unless hemorrhage extends into subarachnoid space)

differential.features: Fever, meningismus, altered mental status, CSF neutrophilic pleocytosis with low glucose
differential.tests: LP (gram stain, culture, BioFire); procalcitonin elevated; CT without blood

differential.features: Prior migraine history; gradual onset of associated features; photophobia, phonophobia; no blood on CT
differential.tests: Normal CT; normal LP; clinical history

differential.features: Severely elevated BP; headache; but no blood on CT; may have PRES features
differential.tests: CT (no blood); MRI (PRES: posterior white matter edema)

differential.features: Neck pain, headache, Horner syndrome, stroke; may have traumatic SAH from vertebral dissection
differential.tests: CTA neck (intimal flap, pseudoaneurysm); MRI neck (crescent sign)

differential.features: Headache, seizures; may have hemorrhagic venous infarct or cortical SAH; risk factors (OCPs, pregnancy)
differential.tests: MRV/CT venogram (thrombosed sinus)

differential.features: Sudden headache, visual field defect, ophthalmoplegia; known pituitary adenoma; may have subarachnoid blood from pituitary hemorrhage
differential.tests: MRI sella (hemorrhagic pituitary mass); hormone panel

differential.features: Blood confined to perimesencephalic cisterns (anterior to brainstem); benign course; CTA/DSA negative for aneurysm
differential.tests: CT pattern (perimesencephalic); negative CTA and DSA; excellent prognosis

differential.features: History of trauma; may have other traumatic injuries (contusion, subdural, skull fracture)
differential.tests: Clinical history; CT pattern

differential.features: Sudden back/leg pain with meningismus; blood on lumbar CT or MRI; rare
differential.tests: Spinal MRI; spinal angiography

evidence.recommendation: Nimodipine 60 mg PO q4h x 21 days
evidence.source: [Pickard et al. (BMJ 1989)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2496789/); only proven agent to improve outcomes in SAH vasospasm
ISAT; AHA/ASA 2012 SAH Guidelines; [de Gans et al. (Neurosurgery 2002)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11844269/)

evidence.recommendation: Endovascular coiling preferred over clipping for most aneurysms
evidence.source: ISAT trial ([Molyneux et al. Lancet 2002](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12414200/)); long-term follow-up

evidence.recommendation: Induced hypertension for clinical vasospasm (after aneurysm secured)
Avoid phenytoin in SAH (worse cognitive outcomes)
LP if CT negative but clinical suspicion
Aminocaproic acid (short-term) if aneurysm securing delayed
Magnesium infusion does NOT improve outcomes
evidence.source: MASH-2 trial ([Dorhout Mees et al. Lancet 2012](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22633825/))

evidence.recommendation: Intra-arterial vasodilator / balloon angioplasty for refractory vasospasm
Avoid self-fulfilling prophecy in poor-grade SAH
evidence.source: AHA/ASA 2012: aggressive treatment for at least 72h in poor-grade

monitoring.frequency: Continuous via arterial line in ICU. Pre-securing: target SBP <160. Post-securing: allow SBP 120-180 (higher if vasospasm treatment)
q1h x 24h; then q2h x 48h; then q4h. Hunt-Hess grade at admission
monitoring.action: If declining: STAT CT (rebleed, hydrocephalus, infarct); TCD; adjust treatment
Tiered ICP management; CSF drainage; osmotherapy

monitoring.frequency: Daily from day 3 through day 14 (vasospasm window); some continue to day 21
monitoring.action: If MCA >120: CTA/CTP; clinical correlation. If >200: severe vasospasm — consider induced hypertension +/- endovascular rescue
If <135: differentiate CSW vs SIADH; treat accordingly. If <120: 3% saline; limit correction <10 mEq/24h
Central fever (common): cooling; acetaminophen. If >38.3°C: infection workup (cultures, CXR, UA)

monitoring.frequency: Troponin daily x 3; BNP at admission and PRN
monitoring.action: If rising with new ECG changes or hemodynamic instability: echo; cardiology

monitoring.frequency: q1h in ICU; q4h shift on floor
monitoring.action: Avoid dehydration (vasospasm risk); avoid overhydration (pulmonary edema)

monitoring.frequency: At 24h post-admission; with any neurologic change; post-procedure; if new hydrocephalus suspected

monitoring.action: Goals of care if poor grade

disposition.criteria: Never discharge from ED with confirmed SAH. Discharge from hospital when: aneurysm secured; past vasospasm window (day 14-21); stable neurologic exam; Na stable; able to take oral nimodipine; no EVD dependency; adequate follow-up
ALL confirmed aneurysmal SAH patients; minimum 14-21 days ICU-level monitoring during vasospasm window. Transfer to step-down only after vasospasm window passed

disposition.disposition: Transfer to comprehensive stroke center / Neurovascular center
disposition.criteria: If no neurosurgery or interventional neuroradiology on-site — TRANSFER IMMEDIATELY. SAH requires tertiary neurovascular services
Significant deficits but medically stable; past vasospasm window; able to participate in 3h/day therapy
Cannot tolerate intensive rehab; requires ongoing skilled care
Devastating SAH (Hunt-Hess V with poor prognostic factors); after appropriate observation period and family discussion

Elevated Intracranial Pressure Managemen.title: Elevated Intracranial Pressure Management
Elevated Intracranial Pressure Managemen.scope: ** Emergency evaluation and management of elevated intracranial pressure in adults. Covers recognition of elevated ICP (Cushing triad, papilledema, declining GCS), emergent interventions (osmotherapy, hyperventilation, sedation, CSF drainage), ICP monitoring indications, surgical decompression, and specific etiology-based management. Includes management across etiologies: traumatic brain injury, stroke (ischemic/hemorrhagic), tumor, infection, hydrocephalus, and idiopathic intracranial hypertension. Excludes pediatric ICP management (different thresholds/approaches).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Infection workup; anemia (reduced O2 carrying capacity); thrombocytopenia (bleeding risk); baseline
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; leukocytosis → infection; thrombocytopenia → hemorrhage risk

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Electrolytes (sodium critical for osmotherapy); renal function (contrast, mannitol); glucose; hepatic function
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; track sodium closely (goal varies by treatment); avoid hyponatremia

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hyperglycemia worsens outcomes in brain injury; hypoglycemia mimics neurologic deterioration
Essential/Core Labs.target: 140-180 mg/dL target in critically ill; <180 in general

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Coagulopathy (hemorrhagic causes); ICP monitor placement safety; surgical candidacy
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; INR <1.4 for ICP monitor placement

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: **CRITICAL for osmotherapy monitoring**; baseline before mannitol/hypertonic saline; target for therapy
Essential/Core Labs.target: 280-295 mOsm/kg baseline; therapeutic target 300-320 (do not exceed 320)

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: **CRITICAL**; hypertonic saline therapy monitoring; cerebral salt wasting vs. SIADH; target for ICP management
Essential/Core Labs.target: 135-145 mEq/L baseline; therapeutic hypernatremia target 145-155 mEq/L (with hypertonic saline)

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Ventilation status (PaCO2 critical for ICP); oxygenation; pH; metabolic status
Essential/Core Labs.target: PaCO2 35-40 mmHg (normal); pH 7.35-7.45; PaO2 >80; for hyperventilation: target PaCO2 30-35

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Tissue perfusion; systemic sepsis; prognostic
Surgical candidacy; potential for decompressive craniectomy or other neurosurgical intervention
Neurogenic cardiac injury (stress cardiomyopathy); particularly in SAH, TBI, ICH
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; elevated → neurogenic stress cardiomyopathy; obtain echo

Extended Workup.rationale: **q4-6h during osmotherapy**; osmolar gap calculation; prevent hyper-osmolar state
Extended Workup.target: Maintain <320 mOsm/kg; osmolar gap >10-15 → accumulating mannitol

Extended Workup.rationale: **q2-6h during active ICP management**; hypertonic saline monitoring; avoid rapid correction
Extended Workup.target: Target 145-155 mEq/L during active ICP crisis; avoid fluctuations >10 mEq/24h

Extended Workup.rationale: Adrenal insufficiency (pituitary injury in TBI, tumor); steroid responsiveness in tumor edema
Extended Workup.target: >10 mcg/dL (AM); if low → cortisol stimulation test or empiric steroids

Extended Workup.rationale: Hepatic encephalopathy differential; can cause cerebral edema and elevated ICP
Extended Workup.target: <35 μmol/L; elevated → hepatic cause; lactulose, rifaximin

Extended Workup.rationale: Intoxication as cause of altered mental status; drug-induced cerebral edema (rare)
Infection (meningitis); malignancy (leptomeningeal disease); subarachnoid hemorrhage (xanthochromia); IIH (elevated OP with normal composition)
Extended Workup.target: Normal CSF composition with elevated opening pressure → IIH; abnormal composition → specific diagnosis

Rare/Specialized.rationale: **IIH diagnosis**: OP >25 cm H2O (obese patients >28 cm); therapeutic in IIH; NOT indicated if mass lesion or obstructive hydrocephalus
Rare/Specialized.target: IIH: OP >25 cm H2O with normal composition; if OP >40-50 → severe

Rare/Specialized.rationale: If barbiturate coma induced for refractory ICP; therapeutic monitoring; guide dosing; monitor for toxicity
Rare/Specialized.target: Therapeutic: 30-50 mcg/mL (for burst suppression); higher may be needed

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Monitor for burst suppression during barbiturate coma; detect subclinical seizures (common in brain injury); guide sedation titration
Rare/Specialized.target: Target: burst suppression pattern during barbiturate coma; no seizures

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Advanced cerebral metabolism monitoring; guide CPP management; detect ischemia or hyperemia
Rare/Specialized.target: 55-75%; <55% = ischemia (increase CPP or reduce CMRO2); >75% = hyperemia

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Direct brain oxygenation monitoring; guide therapy in severe TBI; multimodal monitoring
Research/specialized centers; metabolic monitoring; lactate:pyruvate ratio; glucose; glutamate

Lumbar Puncture.timing: **IIH diagnosis and treatment**: measure opening pressure → therapeutic CSF removal; **CONTRAINDICATED if mass lesion, obstructive hydrocephalus, or herniation risk**; imaging FIRST
Lumbar Puncture.target: Opening pressure: normal <20 cm H2O (obese <25); IIH: >25 cm H2O with normal CSF composition; high-volume tap (20-30 mL) for symptomatic relief in IIH
Lumbar Puncture.contraindications: **ABSOLUTE CONTRAINDICATION**: Mass lesion with mass effect; obstructive hydrocephalus; impending herniation; posterior fossa mass; midline shift; anticoagulation/coagulopathy; skin infection at LP site

Essential/First-line.timing: **Immediate** — within minutes of suspected elevated ICP; before any intervention; determines etiology and guides treatment
Essential/First-line.target: Mass lesion (tumor, hematoma); midline shift (>5mm = significant); hydrocephalus; cerebral edema (effaced sulci, compressed ventricles); herniation signs (uncal, tonsillar); cisternal effacement
Essential/First-line.contraindications: None for non-contrast CT; benefit always outweighs risk in emergency

Essential/First-line.timing: If vascular etiology suspected (SAH, venous sinus thrombosis, AVM); concurrent with non-contrast CT
Essential/First-line.target: Aneurysm (SAH); venous sinus thrombosis (filling defect in dural sinuses); AVM; dissection
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Contrast allergy (premedicate if critical); renal impairment (benefit may outweigh risk)

Essential/First-line.timing: If cerebral venous sinus thrombosis suspected (headache, papilledema, focal deficits, hypercoagulable state); can be done with CTA
Essential/First-line.target: Filling defect in dural sinuses (transverse, sigmoid, sagittal); "empty delta sign" on contrast CT; cord sign

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast
Essential/First-line.timing: When clinically stable; superior for tumor characterization, infection, posterior fossa; MRV for venous thrombosis; DWI for ischemia
Essential/First-line.target: Tumor; abscess; encephalitis; venous sinus thrombosis; ischemic stroke; PRES; herniation; meningeal enhancement

Essential/First-line.timing: ETT position confirmation; pulmonary complications (aspiration, ARDS); central line position
Essential/First-line.target: ETT position; no pulmonary infiltrate; line position

Extended.timing: Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis confirmation; if CTV equivocal; can be done without contrast (TOF technique)
Extended.target: Venous sinus thrombosis; flow void absence

Extended.timing: Non-invasive ICP estimation (pulsatility index); vasospasm detection (SAH); cerebral circulatory arrest (brain death)
Extended.target: Pulsatility index >1.4 suggests elevated ICP; MCA velocities for vasospasm; reverberating flow = no cerebral circulation

Extended.timing: Bedside non-invasive ICP estimation; ONSD >5-5.5 mm suggests ICP >20 mmHg; useful when formal monitoring not available
Extended.target: ONSD >5 mm (some use 5.5 mm) = elevated ICP
Extended.contraindications: Limited accuracy; operator-dependent; not a substitute for invasive monitoring

Extended.timing: Ischemic stroke workup; penumbra assessment; vasospasm evaluation
Extended.target: Perfusion deficits; core vs. penumbra; vasospasm patterns

Extended.timing: Papilledema detection (takes hours-days to develop); retinal hemorrhages (Terson syndrome in SAH); IIH evaluation
Extended.target: Papilledema (indicates chronically or subacutely elevated ICP); absent papilledema does NOT exclude acute ICP elevation; venous pulsations absent if ICP >180 mm H2O

Extended.timing: IIH monitoring; chronic elevated ICP; document visual field loss for treatment decisions
Extended.target: Enlarged blind spot; peripheral constriction; nasal field loss

Rare/Specialized.timing: **Gold standard for ICP measurement**; indications: GCS ≤8 with abnormal CT, or GCS ≤8 with normal CT + 2 of (age >40, SBP <90, motor posturing); also for hydrocephalus management; typically EVD or parenchymal monitor
Rare/Specialized.target: Direct ICP measurement; normal <15 mmHg; elevated >20-22 mmHg; treatment threshold >22 mmHg (Brain Trauma Foundation 2016)
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Coagulopathy (correct first); infection at insertion site; uncontrolled bleeding diathesis

Rare/Specialized.timing: ICP monitoring + therapeutic CSF drainage; preferred in hydrocephalus; allows ICP waveform analysis
Rare/Specialized.target: ICP measurement; CSF drainage; waveform analysis (P2 > P1 = decreased compliance)

Rare/Specialized.timing: Detect subclinical seizures (common in TBI, ICH, SAH — up to 20-30%); guide sedation; burst suppression monitoring during barbiturate coma
Rare/Specialized.target: No seizures; appropriate sedation level; burst suppression if pentobarbital coma

Rare/Specialized.timing: Brain death confirmation (ancillary test); no cerebral blood flow
Rare/Specialized.target: No uptake = brain death (if clinical criteria met and confounders excluded)

Rare/Specialized.timing: Brain death confirmation; no cerebral perfusion

dosing.instructions: **GCS ≤8: Secure airway**; RSI with agents that do NOT raise ICP; preferred: etomidate 0.3 mg/kg OR propofol 1-2 mg/kg + rocuronium 1.2 mg/kg OR succinylcholine 1.5 mg/kg; AVOID ketamine in severe TBI (controversial — emerging data suggest may be safe); lidocaine 1.5 mg/kg IV 2-3 min before laryngoscopy (may blunt ICP spike — controversial benefit); avoid hypotension during RSI

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Airway protection; ventilation control (PaCO2 management); GCS ≤8 cannot protect airway; avoid hypoxia (PaO2 <60) and hypotension (SBP <90) — both worsen outcomes

dosing.instructions: **Elevate HOB 30°**; neutral head position (avoid neck flexion/rotation that impedes jugular venous drainage); avoid tight cervical collar if possible; reverse Trendelenburg if cervical spine immobilization required

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Promotes venous drainage; reduces ICP by 3-5 mmHg; no evidence of reduced CPP with 30° elevation; simple and immediate intervention

dosing.instructions: **Acute herniation ONLY (bridging therapy)**; target PaCO2 30-35 mmHg; induces cerebral vasoconstriction → reduced cerebral blood volume → reduced ICP; **Duration: <30 minutes ideally, maximum 2-4 hours**; taper gradually; avoid PaCO2 <25 (causes ischemia)

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: BTF Guidelines: Avoid prophylactic hyperventilation; use only for acute ICP crisis/herniation as bridge to definitive therapy; prolonged hyperventilation causes rebound vasodilation and ischemia; monitor with SjvO2 or PbtO2 if prolonged use needed

dosing.instructions: **Mannitol 20%:** 1-1.5 g/kg IV bolus (e.g., 100g = 500 mL of 20% for 70 kg patient) over 15-20 minutes; repeat doses: 0.25-0.5 g/kg q4-6h PRN; **Hold if:** serum osmolality >320 mOsm/kg, osmolar gap >15-20; **Requires:** Foley catheter (massive diuresis); volume replacement; **Onset:** 15-30 min; **Duration:** 2-6 hours

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Creates osmotic gradient → draws water from brain parenchyma; reduces brain volume; also improves blood rheology; BTF: Level II evidence; monitor for renal toxicity (ATN), hypovolemia, rebound edema

dosing.instructions: **23.4% NaCl:** 30 mL IV bolus over 15-20 min via central line (preferred for acute crisis); **3% NaCl:** 250-500 mL IV bolus over 30 min (can give peripherally); **Continuous infusion:** 3% NaCl at 30-50 mL/hr to maintain Na 145-155 mEq/L; **Target sodium:** 145-155 mEq/L; avoid >160; correct slowly if hypernatremia develops (no faster than 8-10 mEq/24h decrease)

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Equivalent or superior to mannitol for ICP reduction; does NOT cause diuresis (better for hypovolemic patients); no osmolality ceiling (unlike mannitol); does not accumulate in injured brain (mannitol may); preferred in many centers; SAFE-TBI trial (2021): 20% mannitol = HTS for ICP control

dosing.instructions: **Goal:** Reduce metabolic demand, prevent agitation-induced ICP spikes; **Propofol:** 25-75 mcg/kg/min (first-line; reduces CMRO2 and ICP; allows rapid awakening for neuro exams); **Fentanyl:** 25-100 mcg/hr (analgesia without histamine release); **Midazolam:** 0.05-0.2 mg/kg/hr (alternative to propofol); **Avoid:** Ketamine in severe ICP (controversial); prolonged propofol (PRIS syndrome >48-72h at high doses)

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Agitation, pain, coughing raise ICP; sedation reduces cerebral metabolic rate; propofol has favorable ICP properties; daily sedation holiday for neuro assessment if stable

dosing.instructions: For refractory ICP spikes with ventilator dyssynchrony, coughing, posturing; **Cisatracurium** 0.1-0.2 mg/kg bolus → 1-3 mcg/kg/min infusion (organ-independent metabolism); **Rocuronium** 0.6-1 mg/kg bolus → 0.6 mg/kg/hr; **Requires:** Concurrent sedation/analgesia; train-of-four monitoring; prevents detection of seizures (need cEEG)

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Prevents ICP spikes from coughing, posturing; reduces intrathoracic pressure; use judiciously — obscures neuro exam and seizure detection; requires cEEG monitoring

dosing.instructions: **Prophylaxis (TBI):** Levetiracetam 1000-1500 mg IV load → 500-1000 mg q12h x 7 days (BTF: early seizure prophylaxis x 7 days for severe TBI); **Active seizure:** Lorazepam 0.1 mg/kg (max 4 mg) → Levetiracetam 60 mg/kg load (max 4500 mg) OR fosphenytoin 20 mg PE/kg; **Status epilepticus:** Per SE protocol

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Seizures dramatically increase CMRO2 and ICP; early seizures occur in 10-15% of severe TBI; prophylaxis beyond 7 days NOT recommended (does not prevent late epilepsy); levetiracetam preferred (no drug interactions, IV/PO equivalent)

dosing.instructions: **Avoid fever aggressively**: fever increases CMRO2 by 10-13% per °C; target 36-37°C; acetaminophen 650-1000 mg q4-6h; cooling blankets; **Therapeutic hypothermia:** 32-35°C controversial; EUROTHERM (2015) showed harm from prophylactic hypothermia to 32-35°C in TBI; may use for refractory ICP as rescue

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Fever worsens neurologic outcomes; aggressive normothermia is standard; therapeutic hypothermia is rescue therapy only (not prophylactic); if used: 32-35°C, avoid shivering (increases CMRO2), slow rewarming

dosing.instructions: **Target CPP 60-70 mmHg** (CPP = MAP - ICP); avoid CPP <60 (ischemia) and >70 (BTF: avoid aggressive CPP >70 due to ARDS risk); **If hypotensive:** IV fluids (isotonic crystalloid; avoid hypotonic fluids); vasopressors (norepinephrine first-line); **If hypertensive with ICP crisis:** Treat ICP first (osmotherapy, sedation); avoid precipitously lowering BP (reduces CPP)
dosing.orderSentence: **Blood pressure / CPP management** - IV - see dosing

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: CPP is the primary determinant of cerebral perfusion; BTF 2016: target CPP 60-70; lower threshold 60 mmHg; aggressive CPP >70 increases ARDS risk without outcome benefit; individualized based on autoregulation status

dosing.instructions: **Indications (BTF 2016):** GCS ≤8 + abnormal CT; OR GCS ≤8 + normal CT + ≥2 of: age >40, SBP <90, motor posturing; **EVD preferred if:** Hydrocephalus; need for CSF drainage; **Parenchymal monitor if:** No hydrocephalus; cannot drain CSF; **Target ICP:** <22 mmHg (BTF 2016); some centers use <20

Definitive/Targeted Treatment (Tier 2 —.monitoring: Invasive ICP monitoring guides therapy; EVD allows therapeutic CSF drainage; parenchymal monitors cannot drain; infection risk ~5-10%; ventriculostomy is both diagnostic and therapeutic

dosing.instructions: **Continuous drainage:** Set drain to maintain ICP <22 mmHg; drain 5-10 mL CSF if ICP spike; **Intermittent drainage:** Drain for ICP >22, then clamp to re-measure; **Typical:** Remove 5-20 mL for ICP crisis; **Rate:** Avoid draining >20 mL/hour (risk of over-drainage, collapse of ventricles, hemorrhage)

Definitive/Targeted Treatment (Tier 2 —.monitoring: Immediate ICP reduction; removes volume (CSF) from closed cranial compartment; critical for hydrocephalus; risk: infection, hemorrhage, over-drainage

dosing.instructions: Scheduled or PRN osmotherapy based on ICP readings; **Mannitol:** 0.25-0.5 g/kg q4-6h; **HTS 3%:** 30 mL/hr continuous or 250 mL bolus PRN; **Monitor:** Serum osm q4-6h (hold mannitol if >320); serum Na q2-4h (target 145-155 with HTS)

Definitive/Targeted Treatment (Tier 2 —.monitoring: Sustained osmotherapy for sustained ICP elevation; alternating mannitol and HTS may extend treatment window; monitor for accumulation

dosing.instructions: **Indications:** Refractory ICP despite maximal medical therapy; malignant MCA stroke (large hemispheric infarct with edema); large ICH with mass effect; traumatic brain injury with refractory ICP; **Timing:** TBI: DECRA trial (2011) — early DC did not improve 6-mo outcomes but reduced ICP/ICU stay; RESCUEicp (2016) — late rescue DC improved survival but increased severe disability; **Stroke:** DESTINY/DECIMAL/HAMLET — DC improves survival in malignant MCA stroke age <60 (NNT=2); must discuss goals of care

Definitive/Targeted Treatment (Tier 2 —.monitoring: Removes skull to allow brain expansion; definitive ICP reduction; increases survival but may increase proportion surviving with severe disability; requires extensive goals of care discussion; timing and patient selection critical

dosing.instructions: **ONLY for vasogenic edema from tumor or abscess**; **NOT for TBI, stroke, or cytotoxic edema** (steroids worsen outcomes in TBI — CRASH trial); **Dose:** 10 mg IV load → 4 mg IV q6h; **Duration:** Until definitive tumor treatment; taper over 1-2 weeks after radiation/surgery; GI prophylaxis with PPI

Definitive/Targeted Treatment (Tier 2 —.monitoring: Reduces vasogenic edema around tumors; inhibits VEGF; dramatic effect within 24-48h; CRASH trial: steroids HARMFUL in TBI — avoid; no benefit in stroke

dosing.instructions: **Epidural hematoma:** Emergent if >30 mL, >15mm thickness, or >5mm midline shift, or GCS deterioration; **Subdural hematoma:** Emergent if >10mm thickness, >5mm midline shift, or GCS decrease >2 points; **ICH:** Consider if lobar >30 mL and deteriorating; cerebellar >3cm or hydrocephalus; **Tumor:** Resection or debulking for mass effect

Definitive/Targeted Treatment (Tier 2 —.monitoring: Removes compressive mass → immediate ICP reduction; life-saving for epidural hematoma; subdural and ICH outcomes less clearly improved by surgery but indicated for mass effect and herniation

dosing.instructions: **LAST RESORT for refractory ICP**; **Protocol:** Pentobarbital 5-10 mg/kg IV load over 30 min → 1-3 mg/kg/hr infusion; titrate to ICP <22 mmHg or burst suppression on EEG; **Target:** Burst suppression (3-10 second bursts with 10-20 second suppression); **Monitor:** Continuous EEG; drug levels (30-50 mcg/mL); hemodynamics (causes hypotension — often need vasopressors); **Duration:** 24-48h then attempt to wean; may need 3-5 days

Refractory ICP Management (Tier 3 — Resc.monitoring: Reduces CMRO2 to minimal levels; dramatic ICP reduction; causes severe hypotension (need vasopressors); immunosuppression; ileus; prolonged sedation; no proven mortality benefit but reduces ICP; requires ICU expertise

dosing.instructions: **For refractory ICP only** (NOT prophylactic); **Target:** 32-35°C; **Method:** Surface cooling (Arctic Sun) or intravascular cooling catheter; **Duration:** 24-72h; **Rewarming:** Slow — 0.25°C/hour (rapid rewarming causes ICP rebound); **Complications:** Shivering (treat with paralysis, buspirone, meperidine), coagulopathy, infection, arrhythmia

Refractory ICP Management (Tier 3 — Resc.monitoring: Reduces CMRO2 and ICP; EUROTHERM (2015): prophylactic hypothermia HARMFUL in TBI; rescue hypothermia for refractory ICP still used but evidence weak; prevents fever spikes; requires expertise

dosing.instructions: **ONLY if:** Communicating hydrocephalus; ICP refractory to EVD drainage; no mass lesion or obstructive hydrocephalus; basal cisterns visible; **Method:** Lumbar drain at 10-15 cm H2O; drain 5-10 mL/hour; **Risk:** Tonsillar herniation if used inappropriately; overdrainage

Refractory ICP Management (Tier 3 — Resc.monitoring: Drains CSF from lumbar space; reduces overall CSF volume; effective adjunct in communicating hydrocephalus; must NOT be used with obstructive hydrocephalus or significant mass effect

dosing.instructions: **For refractory ICP crisis**; 30 mL IV bolus via central line; can repeat; target sodium up to 155-160 mEq/L in refractory cases (with close monitoring); **Risk:** Central pontine myelinolysis if rapid sodium changes (maintain stable elevated sodium; do not rapidly correct back to normal)

Refractory ICP Management (Tier 3 — Resc.monitoring: Potent osmotherapy; can achieve higher sodium targets than 3% NaCl; reserved for refractory cases; requires central line access

dosing.instructions: As above; indicated for refractory ICP after failure of all medical therapies; must discuss survival with potential severe disability (RESCUEicp: DC improved survival from 26.9% to 48.9% but increased severe disability); goals of care critical

Refractory ICP Management (Tier 3 — Resc.monitoring: RESCUEicp (2016): More patients survived with DC but at cost of more survivors with severe disability; DECRA (2011): Early prophylactic DC did not improve functional outcomes; decision requires extensive patient/family discussion

dosing.orderSentence: Corticosteroids in ischemic stroke - - - see dosing
Propofol infusion syndrome (prolonged high-dose propofol) - - - see dosing

Patient Instructions.item: Ophthalmology consultation
Neurology consultation
Physiatry / Rehabilitation
Palliative care / Ethics
Social work
Clinical neurophysiology / EEG

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Multimodal neuromonitoring
Targeted temperature management
Brain death evaluation
VP shunt / CSF diversion (long-term)
Transverse sinus stenting (IIH)

differential.features: Etiologies
differential.tests: Key Features

differential.features: Traumatic brain injury (TBI); epidural hematoma; subdural hematoma; contusions; diffuse axonal injury
differential.tests: History of trauma; CT findings; mechanism of injury

differential.features: Ischemic stroke (malignant edema); intracerebral hemorrhage; subarachnoid hemorrhage; cerebral venous sinus thrombosis
differential.tests: Sudden onset; focal deficits; CT/MRI findings; angiography for vascular lesions

differential.features: Primary brain tumor; metastatic disease; leptomeningeal carcinomatosis
differential.tests: Subacute progressive; known cancer history; MRI with contrast

differential.features: Meningitis; encephalitis; brain abscess; subdural empyema
differential.tests: Fever; meningismus; CSF analysis; ring-enhancing lesion

differential.features: Obstructive (tumor, hemorrhage, aqueductal stenosis); communicating (post-infectious, post-hemorrhagic); normal pressure hydrocephalus
differential.tests: Ventricular enlargement on imaging; gait disturbance, dementia, incontinence (NPH triad)

differential.features: Pseudotumor cerebri
differential.tests: Young obese women; headache; papilledema; pulsatile tinnitus; normal imaging; elevated OP on LP

differential.features: Hepatic encephalopathy; hypertensive encephalopathy (PRES); hyponatremia (cerebral edema); hypoxic-ischemic injury
differential.tests: Metabolic derangement; toxic screen; liver function; blood pressure

differential.features: High altitude cerebral edema (HACE); post-operative; radiation necrosis; posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES)
differential.tests: Exposure history; post-procedural; imaging pattern (PRES: posterior white matter edema)

evidence.recommendation: [Guidelines for the Management of Severe Traumatic Brain Injury](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27654000/)

evidence.evidenceLevel: ICP threshold changed from 20 to 22 mmHg; CPP target 60-70 (avoid >70); Level IIA evidence for ICP monitoring improving outcomes
evidence.source: Standard of care for TBI ICP management

evidence.evidenceLevel: Corticosteroids HARMFUL in TBI — 14-day mortality increased (25.7% vs. 22.3%, RR 1.15); 6-month mortality increased
Early decompressive craniectomy (within 72h) for refractory ICP in TBI did NOT improve 6-month functional outcome (though reduced ICP and ICU stay)
evidence.source: Questioned early prophylactic DC; did not stop DC but informed timing decisions

evidence.evidenceLevel: Late/rescue DC for refractory ICP in TBI improved survival (48.9% vs. 26.9%) but increased proportion with severe disability; similar rates of favorable outcome
evidence.source: DC is life-saving but increases survival with disability; requires goals of care discussion

evidence.evidenceLevel: DC for malignant MCA stroke <60 years within 48h reduces mortality (NNT=2); higher survival with moderate-severe disability (mRS 4); DC should be offered
evidence.source: Standard of care for malignant MCA stroke in appropriate patients

evidence.evidenceLevel: Prophylactic hypothermia (32-35°C) in TBI HARMFUL — worse outcomes; trial stopped early
evidence.source: Hypothermia NOT recommended prophylactically; rescue use only for refractory ICP

evidence.evidenceLevel: Intensive BP lowering (SBP <140) safe in ICH; modest benefit in INTERACT2; no benefit in ATACH-2
evidence.source: SBP <140 within 6h is current recommendation for ICH

evidence.evidenceLevel: 20% mannitol vs. hypertonic saline (various concentrations): no significant difference in ICP control or outcomes
evidence.source: Either osmotic agent acceptable; hypertonic saline may be preferred in hypovolemia
BTF Level IIB (avoid CPP <60; avoid >70 due to ARDS risk)

monitoring.action: Tiered therapy escalation (osmotherapy → sedation → CSF drainage → hyperventilation → DC)
If low: IV fluids, vasopressors; if high (>70) and ICP elevated: focus on ICP reduction
Decline: STAT CT; escalate ICP therapy; surgical evaluation
Adjust osmotherapy; correct slowly if needed
Hold mannitol if >320; switch to HTS

monitoring.frequency: q4-6h; more frequent if adjusting ventilation
monitoring.action: Adjust ventilator; avoid hyperventilation except for crisis
Aggressive cooling; acetaminophen; treat infection source
Assess volume status; diuresis from mannitol expected (replace losses)

disposition.criteria: Criteria

Any patient requiring ICP monitoring; GCS ≤8; signs of herniation; requiring osmotherapy, sedation, or mechanical ventilation for ICP; post-operative after decompressive craniectomy or hematoma evacuation; status epilepticus; hemodynamic instability
Stable ICP; improving neurologically; EVD weaning; transitioning off invasive monitoring; stable post-operative
Stable IIH on medical therapy; post-VP shunt; stable post-operative without ICP concerns

Spinal Epidural Abscess.title: Spinal Epidural Abscess
Spinal Epidural Abscess.scope: ** Emergency evaluation and management of spinal epidural abscess in adults. Covers the classic triad (back pain, fever, neurologic deficit), emergent MRI, surgical drainage vs. medical management decision-making, empiric and targeted antibiotic therapy, and neurologic monitoring. Includes associated vertebral osteomyelitis and discitis. Excludes brain abscess (separate template), subdural empyema, and post-operative wound infections (partially overlaps).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: **CRITICAL: Positive in 60-70%**; identifies organism for targeted therapy; guides antibiotic duration; S. aureus most common (60-70%); draw from 2 separate sites
Essential/Core Labs.target: Positive → organism identification; S. aureus (MRSA vs. MSSA) most common; also Streptococci, gram-negatives, anaerobes

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Leukocytosis (WBC >12,000 in 60-80%); left shift; bandemia; baseline for monitoring; thrombocytopenia may indicate DIC/sepsis
Essential/Core Labs.target: Leukocytosis (66%); normal WBC does NOT exclude SEA (20-40% have normal WBC); leukopenia concerning for overwhelming sepsis

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Renal function (antibiotic dosing, contrast); electrolytes; hepatic function; glucose (diabetes is major risk factor)
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal or abnormal; elevated glucose → diabetes workup; renal dysfunction affects antibiotic choice

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: **Highly sensitive (>94%)**; ESR >20 mm/hr in nearly all cases of SEA; ESR >30-50 typical; useful for monitoring treatment response
Essential/Core Labs.target: ESR >20 mm/hr (sensitivity 94%); mean ESR is typically 50-80 mm/hr; if normal → SEA very unlikely

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Elevated in >90% of SEA; more responsive to treatment changes than ESR; useful for monitoring
Essential/Core Labs.target: Elevated (typically >10 mg/dL); declines faster than ESR with successful treatment

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: More specific for bacterial infection than CRP; helps distinguish bacterial from non-infectious inflammation; prognostic
Essential/Core Labs.target: >0.5 ng/mL suggests bacterial infection; >2.0 ng/mL concerning for sepsis; useful in atypical presentations

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: **Diabetes is a major risk factor (30-50% of SEA patients)**; undiagnosed diabetes common; affects wound healing and immune function
Essential/Core Labs.target: Document diabetes status; HbA1c >6.5% = diabetes; glucose control target <180 mg/dL

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Coagulopathy from sepsis (DIC); surgical candidacy; baseline before anticoagulation decisions; epidural hematoma differential
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; prolonged → concern for DIC, liver dysfunction; affects surgical risk

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Sepsis assessment; tissue hypoperfusion; prognostic
Essential/Core Labs.target: <2 mmol/L (normal); >4 mmol/L = severe sepsis/septic shock requiring aggressive resuscitation

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Surgical candidacy; blood product availability
Urinary source (UTI is common source of hematogenous spread, especially gram-negative SEA); concurrent UTI
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal or pyuria/bacteriuria; if positive → potential primary source

Extended Workup.rationale: Immunocompromised state; increases SEA risk; affects prognosis and opportunistic infection risk
Extended Workup.target: Negative; if positive → CD4 count, viral load; consider opportunistic organisms

Extended Workup.rationale: IVDU population (risk factor for SEA); affects long-term antibiotic choice; liver function
Extended Workup.target: Negative; if positive → affects drug selection, hepatotoxicity monitoring

Extended Workup.rationale: DIC screening; VTE risk (prolonged immobility + inflammation); not specific but elevated in SEA
Extended Workup.target: Elevated (non-specific); very high levels → consider DIC
>150 mg/dL; low fibrinogen = DIC or consumption

Extended Workup.rationale: Nutritional status; wound healing; chronicity of illness; prognostic
Extended Workup.target: >3.5 g/dL (albumin); low = poor nutrition, chronic illness

Extended Workup.rationale: Document clearance of bacteremia; if persistently positive → evaluate for endocarditis, undrained collection, treatment failure
Extended Workup.target: Negative by 48-72h of appropriate antibiotics; persistent positivity → echocardiogram, repeat imaging

Rare/Specialized.rationale: **Gold standard for organism identification**; culture of abscess material at surgery; sensitivity higher than blood cultures; also send for Gram stain and histopathology
Rare/Specialized.target: Organism identification; guides targeted antibiotic therapy

Rare/Specialized.rationale: If non-operative management chosen; tissue diagnosis; culture for organism identification; distinguishes abscess from tumor/hematoma
Rare/Specialized.target: Organism identification; Gram stain; histopathology (rule out tumor)

Rare/Specialized.rationale: TB spine (Pott's disease); endemic areas; immunocompromised; chronic presentation with vertebral destruction
Rare/Specialized.target: Negative; positive → TB requires different treatment (anti-TB regimen; may not need surgery if no instability/neurologic deficit)

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Immunocompromised; IVDU; indwelling catheters; endemic fungi (coccidioidomycosis, blastomycosis, histoplasmosis); chronic presentation
Rare/Specialized.target: Negative; positive → prolonged antifungal therapy (6-12+ months)

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Endemic areas (Mediterranean, Middle East); unpasteurized dairy; occupational exposure (farmers, veterinarians); chronic back pain
Rare/Specialized.target: Negative; positive → doxycycline + streptomycin/gentamicin or rifampin

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Culture-negative SEA; prior antibiotic exposure; fastidious organisms
Rare/Specialized.target: Identifies organism even when cultures are negative; research/reference lab

Rare/Specialized.rationale: **Infective endocarditis screen**; IE present in 10-15% of SEA patients with S. aureus bacteremia; affects antibiotic duration and management
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal; vegetations → endocarditis diagnosis; changes antibiotic duration to 4-6 weeks minimum

Rare/Specialized.rationale: If TTE negative but high suspicion for endocarditis (S. aureus bacteremia, IVDU, prosthetic valve, persistent fever); TEE more sensitive than TTE
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal; vegetations → endocarditis; TEE sensitivity 90-95% vs. TTE 65%

Lumbar Puncture.timing: **LP is generally CONTRAINDICATED in suspected SEA**; risk of seeding infection into subarachnoid space → meningitis/spinal subdural empyema; imaging (MRI) is diagnostic modality of choice
Lumbar Puncture.contraindications: **AVOID LP if SEA suspected** — LP may spread infection into intradural space; if meningitis suspected concurrently, discuss with neurosurgery/ID before LP

Essential/First-line.item: MRI entire spine with and without contrast (gadolinium)
Essential/First-line.timing: **GOLD STANDARD — within 4 hours of ED presentation if neurologic deficit; within 24h if no deficit**; contrast essential for abscess characterization; image ENTIRE spine (multifocal in 15-20%)
Essential/First-line.target: Epidural collection with ring enhancement; T1 hypointense, T2 hyperintense; restricted diffusion (DWI bright, ADC dark within abscess); vertebral body involvement (osteomyelitis); disc involvement (discitis); cord compression; degree of canal compromise
Essential/First-line.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; severe claustrophobia (sedate — do NOT delay); GFR <30 (gadolinium risk — but benefit outweighs risk in emergency)

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate while awaiting MRI; identifies vertebral body destruction, disc space narrowing, alignment abnormality; LOW sensitivity for early SEA
Essential/First-line.target: Disc space narrowing; vertebral body destruction (late finding — takes 2-4 weeks to appear); alignment; pathologic fracture

Essential/First-line.timing: If MRI unavailable or contraindicated; inferior to MRI for soft tissue and epidural collection; shows bone destruction better than MRI
Essential/First-line.target: Bone destruction; disc space narrowing; paraspinal soft tissue mass; canal compromise; less sensitive than MRI for epidural abscess extent

Essential/First-line.timing: Primary pulmonary source (pneumonia); lung abscess; TB (apical infiltrate, cavitation); septic emboli
Essential/First-line.target: Primary infection source; pulmonary complications; TB features

Extended.timing: Source identification if not obvious; look for primary infection (lung abscess, intra-abdominal abscess, psoas abscess); staging for concurrent infection
Extended.target: Primary source: lung abscess, intra-abdominal abscess, psoas abscess (contiguous spread), renal/perinephric abscess; endocarditis emboli

Extended.timing: **All patients with S. aureus bacteremia should have echocardiogram**; endocarditis in 10-15% of S. aureus SEA
Extended.target: Vegetations; valvular regurgitation; abscess; Duke criteria
Extended.contraindications: None (TTE); TEE: esophageal pathology, uncooperative patient

Extended.timing: Only if MRI absolutely contraindicated; intrathecal contrast via LP followed by CT; demonstrates level of compression; risk of meningitis seeding with LP
Extended.target: Complete or partial block; level of compression; intradural vs. extradural
Extended.contraindications: Infection at LP site (SEA itself may preclude LP at involved level); coagulopathy

Extended.timing: If MRI unavailable; can identify osteomyelitis; may show uptake before radiographic changes; less specific than MRI
Extended.target: Increased uptake at infection site(s); may identify multifocal disease

Extended.timing: Chronic/subacute infection; differentiating active infection from degenerative changes; research use
Extended.contraindications: Limited availability; time-consuming; replaced largely by MRI

Rare/Specialized.timing: If diagnosis uncertain; culture acquisition for non-surgical management; distinguish abscess from tumor or hematoma
Rare/Specialized.target: Organism identification; Gram stain; histopathology confirming infection vs. other pathology
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Coagulopathy; inaccessible location; very small collection

Rare/Specialized.timing: Chronic/recurrent infection; assess treatment response; identify additional sites of infection; research use
Rare/Specialized.target: Increased FDG uptake at infection site; may identify occult primary source

Rare/Specialized.timing: At 2-4 weeks or if clinical worsening; assess treatment response; monitor for abscess expansion; may appear worse before better on imaging
Rare/Specialized.target: Stable or decreasing collection size; resolving edema; NOTE: Imaging may lag behind clinical improvement (may appear worse at 2 weeks even with successful treatment)

Rare/Specialized.timing: At end of antibiotic course (6-8 weeks); baseline for comparison; assess for residual disease
Rare/Specialized.target: Resolution or significant improvement of collection; healed osteomyelitis; residual enhancement may persist for months (does not necessarily indicate active infection)

dosing.instructions: **Start IMMEDIATELY after blood cultures drawn — do NOT delay for MRI or organism identification**; **First-line empiric:** Vancomycin 25-30 mg/kg IV load (max 2g), then 15-20 mg/kg IV q8-12h (target trough 15-20 mcg/mL) PLUS Ceftriaxone 2g IV q12h OR Cefepime 2g IV q8h; **Alternative for β-lactam allergy:** Vancomycin + aztreonam 2g IV q8h OR Vancomycin + fluoroquinolone (levofloxacin 750 mg daily); **If Pseudomonas risk (IVDU, immunocompromised):** Add anti-pseudomonal coverage with cefepime or piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5g IV q6h; **Adjust to culture results when available**

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Vancomycin covers MRSA (most important cause); ceftriaxone/cefepime covers MSSA, streptococci, gram-negatives; early antibiotics are associated with better outcomes; every hour of delay increases mortality in sepsis

dosing.instructions: **INDICATIONS (Surgery preferred):** (1) Neurologic deficit (any weakness, bowel/bladder dysfunction), (2) Sepsis/hemodynamic instability not improving with antibiotics, (3) Significant cord compression on imaging, (4) Failure of medical therapy (no improvement at 48-72h, worsening at any time), (5) Unknown organism (need tissue diagnosis); **Procedure:** Posterior laminectomy with abscess drainage; cultures from abscess; débridement of infected tissue; may need instrumentation if instability; **Timing:** Within 24h of diagnosis; emergent (within hours) if progressive deficit

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Darouiche (2006): Surgical outcomes better than medical management in patients with neurologic deficit; earlier surgery (within 24h) associated with better neurologic recovery; pre-operative neurologic status is #1 predictor of outcome

dosing.instructions: SCDs immediately; pharmacologic prophylaxis: enoxaparin 40 mg SQ daily — timing is nuanced: may start within 24h of admission if no imminent surgery; post-operatively start 12-24h after surgery per surgeon; high VTE risk population

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Immobile + infection + inflammatory state = very high DVT risk; mechanical prophylaxis universal; pharmacologic prophylaxis as soon as surgically safe

dosing.instructions: Back pain often severe; acetaminophen 650-1000 mg q6h (scheduled) + opioids (morphine 2-4 mg IV q3h PRN or hydromorphone 0.5-1 mg IV q3h PRN); NSAIDs: use cautiously (renal function, surgical bleeding) — some ID physicians avoid NSAIDs in active infection; neuropathic agents (gabapentin) if radicular component

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Severe pain is hallmark of SEA; adequate analgesia is essential; balance with need for neurologic monitoring

dosing.instructions: Surviving Sepsis guidelines: lactate measurement; blood cultures before antibiotics; IV crystalloid 30 mL/kg for hypotension or lactate ≥4 mmol/L; vasopressors (norepinephrine first-line) if MAP <65 despite fluids; reassess volume status; repeat lactate if initially elevated

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Sepsis from SEA has high mortality; early aggressive resuscitation improves outcomes

dosing.instructions: Target glucose <180 mg/dL; insulin infusion if critically ill; sliding scale or basal-bolus for non-ICU patients; diabetes is major risk factor — optimize control

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Hyperglycemia impairs immune function and wound healing; tight glucose control improves infection outcomes

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.item: **Targeted IV antibiotic therapy (based on culture results)**

doseOptions.orderSentence: **Targeted IV antibiotic therapy (based on culture results)** 2g IV

dosing.instructions: **Tailor to organism and sensitivities; typical regimens:** — **MSSA:** Nafcillin 2g IV q4h OR cefazolin 2g IV q8h (preferred for tolerability); duration 6-8 weeks; — **MRSA:** Vancomycin 15-20 mg/kg IV q8-12h (trough 15-20) for 6-8 weeks; alternatives: daptomycin 6-8 mg/kg IV daily (avoid if pneumonia), linezolid 600 mg IV/PO q12h (monitor for toxicity if >2 weeks); — **Streptococci:** Penicillin G 4 million units IV q4h or ceftriaxone 2g IV q12h x 6 weeks; — **Enterococcus:** Ampicillin 2g IV q4h (if susceptible) ± gentamicin synergy; vancomycin if ampicillin-resistant; — **Gram-negatives:** Ceftriaxone 2g IV q12h or cefepime 2g IV q8h or ciprofloxacin 400 mg IV q8h x 6 weeks depending on sensitivities; — **Pseudomonas:** Cefepime 2g IV q8h or meropenem 2g IV q8h x 6 weeks
dosing.orderSentence: **Targeted IV antibiotic therapy (based on culture results)** 2g IV

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: IV antibiotics are standard for SEA/osteomyelitis; oral transition data emerging (OVIVA trial) but traditionally 6-8 weeks IV; de-escalate from empiric coverage once cultures return

dosing.instructions: **SEA without osteomyelitis:** 4-6 weeks IV; **SEA with vertebral osteomyelitis (most cases):** 6-8 weeks IV; **SEA with endocarditis:** 6 weeks minimum from first negative blood culture; duration guided by clinical response, inflammatory markers (ESR, CRP), repeat imaging; may extend if slow response

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: IDSA guidelines: 6 weeks for vertebral osteomyelitis; 4-6 weeks for epidural abscess alone; endocarditis requires 6-week minimum; individualized based on response

dosing.instructions: **OVIVA trial (2019):** Oral antibiotics non-inferior to IV for bone/joint infections after initial 2 weeks IV in stable patients; **Candidates:** Clinically improving; afebrile; tolerating PO; CRP trending down; adherent; close follow-up available; **Oral options:** Fluoroquinolone (levofloxacin 750 mg daily or ciprofloxacin 750 mg BID) + rifampin 300 mg BID (NOT monotherapy); linezolid 600 mg BID (monitor CBC, neuropathy); TMP-SMX DS 2 tabs BID (for MRSA); **NOT for:** Endocarditis, undrained abscess, persistent bacteremia, non-adherent patient

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: OVIVA trial showed oral switch after 2 weeks IV is non-inferior for bone/joint infections; reduces costs, IV complications, hospital stay; requires careful patient selection and close monitoring; NOT standard for all SEA cases

dosing.instructions: **If initial medical management:** Re-evaluate need for surgery at 48-72h; indications for delayed surgery: failure to improve, neurologic deterioration, persistent fever/bacteremia, abscess enlargement on imaging; **Procedure:** Laminectomy + drainage; send cultures even if already on antibiotics (may still grow organism); instrumented fusion if instability/destruction
dosing.orderSentence: **Surgical drainage (if not done emergently)** - - - see dosing

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Surgery provides source control, tissue diagnosis, and decompression; delayed surgery for medical failure still beneficial if performed before complete paralysis

dosing.instructions: **Candidates for medical management without surgery:** (1) No neurologic deficit, (2) Organism identified (blood cultures positive), (3) Small abscess (<3 cm collection), (4) Poor surgical candidate (extreme comorbidities), (5) Panspinal disease (multiple levels — surgery impractical); **Requirements:** Very close neurologic monitoring (q2-4h initially); repeat MRI at 48-72h and weekly; immediate surgery if any deterioration; adherent patient

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Observational studies: ~40% of SEA can be managed medically if no neurologic deficit and criteria met; HOWEVER, 10-20% will fail medical therapy and require surgery; early surgery generally preferred if feasible

dosing.instructions: If prolonged IV antibiotics planned (6-8 weeks); enables outpatient IV therapy (OPAT); placed once stabilized and duration confirmed; confirm tip position with X-ray

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Required for OPAT; reduces peripheral IV complications; monitor for PICC-associated infection

dosing.instructions: Once clinically stable (afebrile, pain controlled, neurologically stable, adequate PO intake, safe home environment); PICC in place; infusion teaching completed; close ID follow-up (weekly visits); VNA nursing for line care
dosing.orderSentence: **Outpatient parenteral antibiotic therapy (OPAT)** - PO - see dosing

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Reduces hospital stay; comparable outcomes to inpatient therapy in appropriate patients; weekly ID visits with labs (CBC, CMP, drug levels, CRP)

dosing.instructions: For staphylococcal osteomyelitis (vertebral involvement); enhances bone penetration; prevents biofilm; **ONLY as adjunctive therapy — never monotherapy (rapid resistance)**; Rifampin 300 mg PO BID added to primary anti-staphylococcal agent; check interactions (CYP3A4 inducer — reduces warfarin, HIV meds, oral contraceptives, etc.)

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Rifampin improves outcomes in staphylococcal bone infections; biofilm activity; excellent bone penetration; drug interactions are significant

dosing.instructions: If spinal instability (vertebral body destruction, kyphosis, instrumentation); TLSO for thoracolumbar; cervical collar for cervical; duration: typically 6-12 weeks or until radiographic healing

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: External stabilization; pain relief; prevents pathologic fracture progression; may allow non-operative management of mild instability

dosing.instructions: Protein supplementation (1.2-1.5 g/kg/day); calorie optimization; correct vitamin deficiencies; dietitian consultation; affects wound healing and immune function

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Malnutrition common in chronic illness; protein essential for wound healing; improves infection outcomes

dosing.instructions: Endocrinology consult if poorly controlled; insulin titration; goal HbA1c <7.5% (individualized); glucose <180 mg/dL during acute illness

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Diabetes is major risk factor; uncontrolled diabetes impairs healing and immune response

dosing.instructions: IVDU is major risk factor for SEA (20-30% of cases); addiction medicine consultation; harm reduction; hepatitis/HIV screening; reduces recurrence risk

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: IVDU patients at high risk for recurrent infection; addressing substance use reduces future SEA risk

dosing.orderSentence: Epidural steroid injection (as treatment or in area of abscess) - - - see dosing

differential.features: Key Differentiating Features
differential.tests: Distinguishing Studies

differential.diagnosis: Malignant spinal cord compression (MSCC) / Metastatic epidural disease
differential.features: Known cancer history; bone destruction without disc involvement (SEA typically involves disc); no fever (usually); no elevated ESR/CRP/WBC (unless concurrent infection); may be painful but not typically as acute; enhances but no ring-enhancement or diffusion restriction
differential.tests: MRI: enhancing epidural mass WITHOUT ring enhancement or restricted diffusion; bone destruction; CT/PET: metastatic staging; tumor markers; biopsy if uncertain; ESR/CRP may be mildly elevated in malignancy but not as high as SEA

differential.features: Older patient; osteoporosis history; no fever; acute onset with movement; no neurologic deficit (usually); no elevated inflammatory markers; vertebral body wedging; may have benign edema
differential.tests: MRI: vertebral body edema WITHOUT epidural collection; no ring enhancement; normal ESR/CRP; DEXA: osteoporosis; mechanism (fall, lifting); responds to bracing/pain management

differential.features: No fever; no elevated inflammatory markers; unilateral radiculopathy (usually); no epidural collection on MRI; common, benign presentation
differential.tests: MRI: disc herniation without epidural enhancement; no T2 hyperintense collection; normal ESR/CRP; normal WBC; unilateral symptoms more common

differential.features: Anticoagulation; post-procedural (epidural injection, LP, surgery); acute onset; hematoma signal characteristics on MRI (not ring-enhancing); no fever; rapidly progressive
differential.tests: MRI: epidural collection with blood signal (T1 hyperintense in subacute phase); NO ring enhancement; NO restricted diffusion in hematoma (unlike abscess); coagulation studies; anticoagulation history; recent procedure

differential.features: Intramedullary (within cord) rather than epidural; autoimmune; no fever; no elevated ESR/CRP (or mildly elevated); subacute onset; responds to steroids/PLEX
differential.tests: MRI: intramedullary T2 hyperintensity, NOT epidural collection; AQP4/MOG antibodies; CSF: pleocytosis but sterile; normal inflammatory markers

differential.features: Chronic symptoms (claudication); older patient; no fever; no inflammatory markers; bilateral symptoms with walking; relieved by sitting/flexion; chronic findings on MRI
differential.tests: MRI: chronic stenosis (ligamentum flavum hypertrophy, disc bulging, facet hypertrophy) WITHOUT acute epidural collection; normal ESR/CRP; chronic history

differential.features: Similar to SEA but NO epidural collection; disc and vertebral body involvement; back pain and fever; elevated inflammatory markers; may progress to SEA
differential.tests: MRI: vertebral body and disc enhancement and edema WITHOUT epidural collection; blood cultures may be positive; requires IV antibiotics but not emergent surgical decompression (unless instability or progression to SEA)

differential.features: Contiguous spread can cause spinal infection; flank/groin pain; hip flexion pain; may track from spine or vice versa; fever; iliopsoas enhancement on imaging
differential.tests: CT/MRI: psoas muscle enlargement with rim-enhancing collection; may extend to spine; blood cultures; percutaneous drainage often possible

evidence.evidenceLevel: British Infection Association / British Orthopaedic Association

Comprehensive review of SEA: S. aureus most common (60-70%); pre-operative neurologic status is #1 predictor of outcome; early surgery associated with better outcomes; medical management reasonable in selected cases without deficit
evidence.source: Established framework for surgical vs. medical management decision-making

evidence.evidenceLevel: 915 patients: Surgical treatment associated with better neurologic outcomes than medical management alone; patients presenting with neurologic deficit benefit most from early surgery
evidence.source: Supports surgical decompression as preferred approach, especially with neurologic deficit

evidence.evidenceLevel: Timing of surgery: decompression within 24h of neurologic deficit associated with significantly better outcomes than delayed surgery
Risk factors for poor outcome: advanced age, diabetes, MRSA, delayed diagnosis, pre-operative paralysis, cervical/thoracic location
evidence.source: Identified high-risk patients who may benefit from aggressive surgical approach

evidence.evidenceLevel: 6-week IV antibiotic duration for vertebral osteomyelitis; longer for complicated cases (endocarditis, undrained abscess); rifampin adjunct for staphylococcal infections
evidence.source: Standardized antibiotic duration and adjunctive therapy

evidence.evidenceLevel: Oral antibiotics non-inferior to IV for bone/joint infections after initial IV therapy in stable patients; oral switch after 2 weeks IV
evidence.source: Opened possibility of early oral transition for selected patients; reduces hospitalization/OPAT burden; requires careful patient selection

evidence.evidenceLevel: Meta-analysis: mortality 5%; permanent paralysis 4-22%; earlier surgery and better pre-operative function = better outcomes
evidence.source: Established prognostic importance of pre-operative neurologic status and early intervention
Most common; hematogenous spread; IVDU, skin infection, catheters; MRSA requires vancomycin

Adjust dose if outside range; monitor renal function

SEA is NEVER an observation diagnosis; all patients require admission until diagnosis confirmed/excluded and treatment initiated

Rapidly Progressive Dementia.title: Rapidly Progressive Dementia
Rapidly Progressive Dementia.scope: ** Urgent evaluation of cognitive decline progressing over weeks to months (typically <1-2 years from symptom onset to severe disability). Covers comprehensive workup to identify treatable causes including autoimmune encephalitis, infectious etiologies, toxic-metabolic causes, CNS malignancy, and prion disease (CJD). The key principle: assume a treatable cause exists until proven otherwise. Excludes typical slowly progressive dementias (Alzheimer's, FTD) unless presenting atypically fast, and acute delirium (<days).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Infection screen; hematologic malignancy; B12 deficiency (macrocytosis)
Hepatic encephalopathy (ammonia); renal failure (uremia); electrolyte abnormalities (Na, Ca); hypo/hyperglycemia
Hypothyroid encephalopathy (Hashimoto encephalopathy); hyperthyroidism
B12 deficiency — reversible cause of cognitive decline and myelopathy
Deficiency associated with cognitive impairment
Vasculitis screen; inflammatory conditions; infection; malignancy
Inflammatory marker
Neurosyphilis — treatable cause; "the great imitator"
HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder (HAND); opportunistic infections
Hepatic encephalopathy
UTI causing delirium (especially elderly)
Substance-related cognitive impairment; prescription drug toxicity
Hypoglycemia; diabetic encephalopathy

Extended Workup.rationale: Hashimoto encephalopathy (SREAT) — treatable with steroids even if euthyroid
CNS vasculitis (granulomatosis with polyangiitis, microscopic polyangiitis)
Multiple myeloma; POEMS; Waldenström; M-protein-associated neuropathy/encephalopathy
Wernicke encephalopathy — reversible with treatment; alcoholism, malnutrition, bariatric surgery
Wilson disease (young patients <50); acquired copper deficiency (zinc excess, gastric surgery)
Zinc excess causes copper deficiency → myeloneuropathy + cognitive decline
