Referrals & Consults.indication: All RPD cases; diagnostic workup direction; empiric treatment decisions
Suspected autoimmune encephalitis; immunotherapy management
Suspected CNS infection (neurosyphilis, TB, HIV, fungal, Whipple)
Paraneoplastic syndrome; CNS lymphoma; brain metastases
Brain biopsy consideration; hydrocephalus management
Suspected CNS vasculitis; lupus cerebritis; sarcoidosis
Behavioral management; depression; capacity assessment
Formal cognitive testing; baseline and follow-up
Goals of care (especially if CJD suspected); symptom management
Family support; advance directive planning; caregiver resources
If genetic prion disease suspected; family implications
End-of-life decisions; capacity evaluation for untreatable conditions

Referrals & Consults.item: National Prion Disease Pathology Surveillance Center (Cleveland)
Referrals & Consults.indication: If CJD suspected: contact for diagnostic guidance and potential brain autopsy
Dysphagia; communication strategies
Safety; mobility; ADLs; fall prevention

Patient Instructions.item: RPD has many TREATABLE causes — aggressive workup is justified
Return to ED if: new seizure, sudden worsening, falls, inability to swallow, fever
Do NOT drive
Ensure 24/7 supervision at home (fall risk, wandering, impaired judgment)
Advance directives / healthcare power of attorney should be completed early while patient can still participate
If CJD is diagnosed: no cure exists; disease is uniformly fatal; focus on comfort and quality of life
CJD is NOT contagious through casual contact; standard precautions are sufficient; no isolation needed for family
CJD surgical instruments: notify any surgical/dental providers about diagnosis (special sterilization or instrument destruction required)
Family support resources: CJD Foundation (www.cjdfoundation.org); Autoimmune Encephalitis Alliance
Follow-up with neurology frequently (weekly to monthly depending on trajectory)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Fall prevention (remove tripping hazards, grab bars, non-slip surfaces)
No driving, no operating machinery
Medication management by caregiver (patient cannot reliably self-administer)
Home safety evaluation (OT)
Caregiver support and respite care
Nutritional support (swallowing may decline; SLP evaluation)
Medical ID bracelet

differential.features: Weeks-months; myoclonus; startle; akinetic mutism late; MRI cortical ribboning + caudate/putamen DWI signal; PSWCs on EEG
differential.tests: RT-QuIC (CSF); 14-3-3; total tau >1150; MRI DWI; EEG

differential.features: Subacute; psychiatric symptoms → seizures → movement disorder → autonomic → decreased consciousness; young women; ovarian teratoma
differential.tests: NMDAR antibody (CSF > serum); pelvic imaging

differential.features: Faciobrachial dystonic seizures; hyponatremia; memory loss; >40 years
differential.tests: LGI1 antibody (serum > CSF); serum Na

differential.features: Euthyroid or hypothyroid; high anti-TPO; steroid-responsive; diagnosis of exclusion
differential.tests: Anti-TPO elevated; response to steroids; exclude other causes

differential.features: Most common misdiagnosis of CJD; positive AD biomarkers (low Aβ42, high p-tau); no myoclonus typically; MRI shows atrophy, no DWI ribboning
differential.tests: CSF AD biomarkers (Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio low, p-tau elevated); MRI (atrophy without DWI cortical signal); RT-QuIC negative

differential.features: B symptoms; enhancing mass (primary); multifocal white matter changes with LDH elevation and no mass (intravascular)
differential.tests: MRI with contrast; CSF cytology + flow cytometry; EBV PCR; brain biopsy; LDH; peripheral smear

differential.features: Known malignancy; cranial neuropathies; communicating hydrocephalus; CSF cytology positive
differential.tests: CSF cytology (repeat x3); MRI with contrast (leptomeningeal enhancement)

differential.features: RPR/VDRL positive; Argyll Robertson pupils; psychiatric symptoms; may have prior STI history
differential.tests: RPR/VDRL (serum); CSF VDRL; FTA-ABS

differential.features: Acute confusion + ophthalmoplegia + ataxia triad (only 10% have all three); alcoholism, malnutrition
differential.tests: Thiamine level (draw before treatment); MRI (mamillary body, thalamic signal); clinical response to thiamine

differential.features: Headache; multifocal deficits; strokes; CSF pleocytosis
differential.tests: MRA (beading); DSA; brain/meningeal biopsy; ESR/CRP elevated

differential.features: Cranial neuropathies (CN VII); leptomeningeal enhancement; hilar adenopathy; elevated ACE
differential.tests: Chest CT; serum/CSF ACE; biopsy (granulomas)

differential.features: Triad: gait disorder (predominant) + urinary incontinence + dementia; "wet, wobbly, and wacky"; ventricular enlargement disproportionate to atrophy
differential.tests: Large-volume LP (30-50 mL) with pre/post gait assessment; MRI (Evans index >0.3)

differential.features: Medication toxicity (lithium, methotrexate, chemotherapy); substance abuse; hepatic/uremic encephalopathy
differential.tests: Drug levels; LFTs; ammonia; BUN/Cr; UDS

differential.features: Depressive symptoms predominant; subjective cognitive complaints > objective deficits; onset correlates with depressive episode
differential.tests: Neuropsychological testing; psychiatric evaluation; may improve with antidepressant

differential.features: Oculomasticatory myorhythmia (pathognomonic); GI symptoms; arthralgia; chronic diarrhea
differential.tests: T. whipplei PCR (CSF, duodenal biopsy); PAS-positive macrophages on biopsy

differential.features: Immunocompromised; multifocal white matter lesions (no enhancement typically); progressive deficits
differential.tests: JC virus PCR (CSF); MRI pattern; clinical context

differential.features: Genetic prion disease; progressive insomnia → autonomic dysfunction → motor signs → dementia; family history
differential.tests: PRNP gene testing (D178N mutation with 129M); polysomnography (absent sleep spindles)

Neurosyphilis: IV penicillin G x 14 days

Assess at day 5 of steroids/IVIG; then weekly

If rising: relapse risk; adjust immunotherapy
Increase supervision; facility placement if needed

disposition.criteria: Stable cognition; safe home environment with 24/7 caregiver; outpatient workup can be completed; no active seizures; swallowing safe; outpatient follow-up arranged within 1-2 weeks
Acute/subacute decline requiring urgent workup; unable to safely manage at home; seizures; empiric immunotherapy trial; cannot complete workup as outpatient
Status epilepticus; respiratory failure; autonomic instability; severe agitation requiring sedation; ICP management
Complex workup (brain biopsy, specialized autoimmune testing); prion disease expertise; clinical trial access
Progressive untreatable dementia (CJD, advanced neurodegenerative); unable to care for self; caregiver unable to manage
Confirmed CJD or other untreatable rapidly fatal diagnosis; focus on comfort

Breakthrough Seizure (Known Epilepsy).title: Breakthrough Seizure (Known Epilepsy)
Breakthrough Seizure (Known Epilepsy).scope: ** Evaluation and management of breakthrough seizures in adults with known epilepsy who are on established antiseizure medication (ASM) regimens. Covers identification of precipitants, medication level assessment, adjustment strategies, and evaluation for secondary causes. Excludes new-onset seizure (separate workup), status epilepticus (see SE template), and non-epileptic events (psychogenic non-epileptic seizures).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: **CRITICAL**: Subtherapeutic levels are #1 cause of breakthrough seizures; check ALL ASMs with available assays
Essential/Core Labs.target: Therapeutic ranges (see Appendix); subtherapeutic = adjust dose or assess adherence

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Infection as precipitant; baseline for ASM hematologic effects; thrombocytopenia (valproate)
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; leukocytosis → infection workup; low platelets → consider valproate toxicity

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Electrolyte abnormalities (hyponatremia common with carbamazepine/oxcarbazepine); renal function (affects ASM dosing); hepatic function (ASM metabolism, toxicity); glucose (hypoglycemia as seizure cause)
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; hyponatremia <130 mEq/L can provoke seizures; elevated LFTs → ASM hepatotoxicity

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypoglycemia is reversible seizure cause; hyperglycemia (DKA) can also cause seizures
Hyponatremia: carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine cause SIADH; <125-130 mEq/L can provoke seizures
Essential/Core Labs.target: 135-145 mEq/L; <130 → correct slowly (risk of osmotic demyelination)

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypocalcemia can cause seizures; also check if hypocalcemic tetany suspected
Hypomagnesemia lowers seizure threshold; chronic ASM use may deplete Mg
UTI is common occult infection that provokes seizures, especially in elderly
Illicit drug use (cocaine, amphetamines) can provoke seizures; drug interactions with ASMs; adherence assessment
Essential/Core Labs.target: Negative; positive → specific drug-related seizure risk assessment

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Alcohol withdrawal seizures; intoxication; binge drinking
Essential/Core Labs.target: Negative or low; elevated or history of recent heavy use → alcohol withdrawal protocol

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Pregnancy affects ASM levels (increased clearance, volume distribution); teratogenicity concerns; seizure risk in pregnancy
Essential/Core Labs.target: Document result; if positive → urgent neurology/OB consultation; ASM teratogenicity counseling

Extended Workup.rationale: For highly protein-bound drugs (phenytoin, valproate) in patients with hypoalbuminemia, renal failure, pregnancy, or polypharmacy; free level is the active fraction
Extended Workup.target: Free phenytoin: 1-2 mcg/mL; free valproate: 5-15 mcg/mL; adjusted interpretation based on clinical context

Extended Workup.rationale: Valproate-induced hyperammonemic encephalopathy (can occur with normal LFTs); confusion/lethargy post-ictal vs. encephalopathy
Extended Workup.target: <35 μmol/L; elevated → valproate toxicity; consider discontinuation

Extended Workup.rationale: Post-ictal lactate elevation (typically resolves within 2h); persistent elevation may indicate status epilepticus or alternative cause
Extended Workup.target: Mildly elevated post-ictal (normalizes quickly); persistent elevation concerning

Extended Workup.rationale: Elevated 10-20 min post-seizure (2-3x baseline); helps distinguish epileptic seizure from psychogenic non-epileptic seizure (PNES); must be drawn within 20 min
Extended Workup.target: 2-3x baseline within 20 min of convulsive seizure; normal in PNES

Extended Workup.rationale: Thyroid dysfunction can affect seizure threshold and ASM metabolism
Adrenal insufficiency; chronic ASM use (enzyme inducers) may affect cortisol
Phenytoin and carbamazepine can deplete folate; B12 deficiency neuropathy; pregnancy planning
Enzyme-inducing ASMs (phenytoin, carbamazepine, phenobarbital) increase vitamin D metabolism → osteoporosis risk

Rare/Specialized.rationale: HLA-B*15:02 (carbamazepine/SJS risk in Asian populations); HLA-A*31:01 (carbamazepine hypersensitivity in Europeans); before starting new ASMs
Rare/Specialized.target: Negative for risk alleles; positive → avoid associated ASM

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Active metabolite of carbamazepine; may be elevated when total level appears therapeutic (especially with inhibitors like valproate); correlates with toxicity
Rare/Specialized.target: <9 mcg/mL; elevated → toxicity even with normal carbamazepine level

Rare/Specialized.rationale: If new seizure semiology, cognitive decline, or refractory seizures in previously controlled patient; autoimmune etiology
If infection, autoimmune encephalitis, or CNS malignancy suspected as new cause
If genetic cause suspected (family history, syndromic features, drug-resistant epilepsy); may guide ASM selection
Rare/Specialized.target: Specific mutations (SCN1A, SCN2A, KCNQ2, etc.) may inform treatment choices (e.g., avoid sodium channel blockers in Dravet syndrome)

Lumbar Puncture.timing: NOT routinely indicated for uncomplicated breakthrough seizure; **INDICATED if:** Suspected meningitis/encephalitis (fever, meningismus, altered mentation beyond typical post-ictal); suspected autoimmune encephalitis; immunocompromised patient with seizure
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal in uncomplicated breakthrough; pleocytosis → infection or autoimmune; elevated protein; specific antibodies
Lumbar Puncture.contraindications: Mass lesion with mass effect; coagulopathy

Essential/First-line.timing: **NOT routinely needed** for uncomplicated breakthrough seizure in known epilepsy with return to baseline; **INDICATED if:** Head trauma (fall during seizure), prolonged post-ictal state (>30 min), focal neurologic deficit, new seizure semiology, anticoagulation, fever + seizure, first seizure at this facility
Essential/First-line.target: Acute hemorrhage; mass lesion; edema; hydrocephalus; prior surgical changes
Essential/First-line.contraindications: None (for non-contrast); pregnancy (benefit outweighs minimal risk)

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast
Essential/First-line.timing: **NOT acutely needed** if stable known epilepsy with unchanged seizures; **INDICATED if:** Change in seizure semiology, increased seizure frequency without clear precipitant, new focal deficit, concern for progressive lesion, presurgical evaluation
Essential/First-line.target: Tumor; mesial temporal sclerosis; cortical dysplasia; vascular malformation; new structural cause
Essential/First-line.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; VNS devices (check MRI compatibility of specific device)

Essential/First-line.timing: Post-ictal arrhythmia; syncope vs. seizure; QTc prolongation (some ASMs); baseline for ASM changes
Essential/First-line.target: Normal; arrhythmia may indicate cardiac cause; prolonged QTc (avoid QT-prolonging ASMs)

Extended.timing: Within 24-48h if possible (higher yield closer to seizure); characterize epileptiform activity; confirm epileptic vs. non-epileptic; guide ASM choice; localization
Extended.target: Epileptiform discharges (spikes, sharp waves); focal vs. generalized; specific epilepsy syndrome features

Extended.timing: **INDICATED if:** Prolonged or fluctuating alteration of consciousness; concern for nonconvulsive status epilepticus (NCSE); ICU patient with unexplained encephalopathy; frequent seizures
Extended.target: Ictal patterns; NCSE; interictal epileptiform activity; quantify seizure burden

Extended.timing: Capture typical events if infrequent; home monitoring for 24-72h or longer
Extended.target: Ictal events; interictal discharges; seizure frequency

Extended.timing: Characterize events if diagnostic uncertainty (epileptic vs. PNES); presurgical evaluation; medication taper for surgery
Extended.target: Ictal semiology; EEG correlation; localization for surgery

Extended.timing: Aspiration pneumonia (common post-ictal complication); ETT position if intubated

Rare/Specialized.timing: High-resolution imaging for epileptogenic lesion identification; 3T preferred; includes thin-cut coronal T2/FLAIR through temporal lobes
Rare/Specialized.target: Mesial temporal sclerosis; focal cortical dysplasia; cavernous malformation; low-grade tumor

Rare/Specialized.timing: Presurgical localization; hypometabolism (interictal PET) or hyperperfusion (ictal SPECT) at seizure focus
Presurgical localization; dipole source analysis; specialized centers
Presurgical evaluation; cognitive baseline; localization (memory lateralization for temporal lobe epilepsy)
Rare/Specialized.target: Lateralized deficits; cognitive baseline for surgery comparison

dosing.instructions: **Lorazepam** 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg), may repeat x1 in 5 min; **OR Midazolam** 10 mg IM (if no IV access); **OR Diazepam** 0.2 mg/kg IV (max 10 mg); **Intranasal midazolam** 5-10 mg if no IV; **Rectal diazepam** 0.2-0.5 mg/kg (home rescue)

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: First-line for acute seizure termination; lorazepam preferred IV (longer CNS duration); follow status epilepticus protocol if seizure continues >5 min

dosing.instructions: Clear environment of hazards; DO NOT restrain or put anything in mouth; turn on side (recovery position) when safe; suction secretions; monitor airway; time the seizure

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Prevent injury; prepare for airway management if prolonged

dosing.instructions: Recovery position; monitor airway (aspiration risk); supplemental O2 if SpO2 <92%; assess for injuries (tongue laceration, shoulder dislocation, vertebral fracture); reassurance; reorientation

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Post-ictal period is self-limited (typically 5-30 min); prolonged alteration → consider NCSE, repeat seizure, or alternative diagnosis

dosing.instructions: If patient missed doses → give maintenance ASM immediately; if patient does not have medication with them → administer from ED/hospital supply

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Non-adherence is most common cause of breakthrough seizure; restoring therapeutic levels is priority

dosing.instructions: **Phenytoin/Fosphenytoin:** 15-20 mg PE/kg IV (if level very low); **Valproate:** 20-30 mg/kg IV (if level very low); **Levetiracetam:** 1000-1500 mg IV (if not on levetiracetam — can be added); **Note:** Loading the same drug patient is already taking risks toxicity → use cautiously

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: For significantly subtherapeutic levels or if need rapid therapeutic concentration; adjust for partial levels

dosing.instructions: **Infection:** Antibiotics for UTI, pneumonia; **Electrolyte abnormality:** Correct (hyponatremia slowly); **Drug/alcohol withdrawal:** Appropriate protocol; **Sleep deprivation:** Education, sleep hygiene

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Treating the precipitant may be more important than adjusting ASMs

ASM Adjustment Strategies.item: Resume current regimen at prescribed doses
ASM Adjustment Strategies.rationale: Non-adherence is #1 cause; restoring regimen usually sufficient

ASM Adjustment Strategies.item: Increase current ASM OR add second ASM
ASM Adjustment Strategies.rationale: Some patients require levels above "therapeutic range" for control

ASM Adjustment Strategies.item: Add second ASM OR optimize current ASM timing
ASM Adjustment Strategies.rationale: Breakthrough at therapeutic levels may require adjunctive therapy

ASM Adjustment Strategies.item: Remove interacting drug OR increase ASM dose OR switch ASM
ASM Adjustment Strategies.rationale: Enzyme inducers and inhibitors significantly affect ASM levels
Seizure risk to mother and fetus outweighs small ASM risk; maintain control
Change in control pattern requires investigation for new etiology

dosing.orderSentence: **Illicit drugs (cocaine, amphetamines, synthetic cathinones)** - - - see dosing

Imaging
Pharmacy consultation

Psychology / Psychiatry
Epilepsy nurse educator

Ketogenic diet referral
