differential.features: Key Distinguishing Features
differential.tests: Evaluation

differential.features: Typical semiology for patient; post-ictal state; EEG correlation; identifiable precipitant or subtherapeutic level
differential.tests: ASM levels; EEG; precipitant search

differential.features: Variable semiology; prolonged duration (>2 min); preserved awareness with bilateral movements; eyes closed; pelvic thrusting; ictal crying; side-to-side head movements; no post-ictal confusion (or prolonged pseudo-post-ictal); normal prolactin; normal EEG during event
differential.tests: Video-EEG (gold standard); prolactin (not elevated); clinical features; psychology evaluation

differential.features: Triggered by standing, hot environment, vagal stimulus; brief LOC (<1 min); myoclonic jerks are common during syncope (not true seizure); rapid recovery; pale before event
differential.tests: ECG; orthostatics; tilt table test; echocardiogram; cardiac history

differential.features: Sudden LOC without warning or with palpitations; rapid recovery; history of cardiac disease
differential.tests: ECG; Holter/event monitor; echocardiogram; electrophysiology study

differential.features: Hypoglycemia; hyponatremia; hypocalcemia; uremia; hepatic encephalopathy; drug intoxication/withdrawal
differential.tests: Glucose; electrolytes; renal/hepatic function; drug screen; specific toxin levels

differential.features: Negative symptoms (weakness, numbness, aphasia) vs. positive symptoms (convulsion); typically no LOC; vascular risk factors
differential.tests: MRI with DWI; MRA; vascular risk factor assessment

differential.features: REM sleep behavior disorder; parasomnias; cataplexy (narcolepsy)
differential.tests: Sleep history; PSG; MSL

differential.features: Dystonia; chorea; myoclonus (non-epileptic); paroxysmal dyskinesia
differential.tests: Preserved awareness; stereotyped movements; neurologic exam; movement disorder evaluation

differential.features: Visual, sensory, or motor aura preceding headache; duration 20-60 min; no LOC
differential.tests: Headache history; migraine features; may have EEG abnormalities but distinct from seizure

evidence.recommendation: Practice Guideline Update: Efficacy and Tolerability of ASMs

evidence.evidenceLevel: 47% of newly diagnosed epilepsy patients became seizure-free on first ASM; 13% on second; 4% on third; after failure of 2 appropriate ASMs, chance of seizure freedom with additional ASMs is <5%
evidence.source: Defined drug-resistant epilepsy; established rationale for early surgery referral

evidence.evidenceLevel: Lamotrigine best for focal epilepsy; valproate best for generalized/unclassified (but teratogenic); levetiracetam non-inferior to lamotrigine for focal
evidence.source: Guide first-line ASM selection by seizure type

evidence.recommendation: Standard and New Antiepileptic Drugs (SNAED) Trial
evidence.evidenceLevel: Levetiracetam and zonisamide non-inferior to lamotrigine for focal epilepsy
Early surgery superior to continued medical therapy for drug-resistant temporal lobe epilepsy; 73% vs. 0% seizure-free at 2 years
evidence.source: Surgery is highly effective; early referral improves outcomes

evidence.evidenceLevel: Convulsive seizures, especially nocturnal; living alone; poor seizure control
evidence.source: Counsel patients; nocturnal monitoring devices; optimize seizure control

monitoring.frequency: q15 min until resolved; q1h thereafter
monitoring.action: Prolonged: consider NCSE → EEG; imaging; extended evaluation

monitoring.frequency: q15-30 min initially; q1h once stable

monitoring.action: Repeat seizure: give benzodiazepine; consider additional ASM load; SE protocol if >5 min

monitoring.target: Patent airway; no aspiration; adequate ventilation
monitoring.action: Position; suction; O2 if needed; intubation if compromised

disposition.criteria: Criteria
Status epilepticus; cluster seizures requiring continuous infusion; severe injuries; need for continuous EEG monitoring; airway compromise; hemodynamic instability
Prolonged post-ictal state; multiple seizures in ED; significantly subtherapeutic levels requiring monitoring during adjustment; uncertain diagnosis; new focal deficit; complicating medical illness

Single uncomplicated breakthrough seizure; returned to baseline; identifiable/correctable precipitant; therapeutic or corrected ASM level; no injuries requiring admission; safe home environment; reliable follow-up

Cauda Equina Syndrome.title: Cauda Equina Syndrome
icd10: G95.89 (Other specified diseases of spinal cord)
Cauda Equina Syndrome.scope: ** Emergency evaluation and management of cauda equina syndrome in adults. Covers urgent recognition of incomplete vs. complete CES, emergent MRI, surgical decompression timing, etiologic workup (disc herniation, tumor, abscess, hematoma), bladder management, and functional prognostication. Excludes conus medullaris syndrome (partially overlaps — key distinguishing features addressed), malignant epidural spinal cord compression above the conus (separate template), and chronic lumbar stenosis without CES features.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Infection (epidural abscess); baseline for surgery; leukocytosis; anemia assessment
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; leukocytosis → consider abscess; thrombocytopenia affects surgical candidacy

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Electrolytes; renal function (contrast, NSAIDs); glucose; hepatic function (anesthetic risk)
Coagulopathy; anticoagulation status; surgical clearance; epidural hematoma etiology
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; INR <1.5 for surgery; prolonged → consider epidural hematoma

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Epidural abscess differential (ESR >20 mm/hr: 94% sensitivity for spinal abscess); discitis; malignancy
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; markedly elevated (ESR >30-50, CRP >10) → strongly consider abscess or infection

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Epidural abscess; bacteremia; source identification if infectious etiology suspected
Essential/Core Labs.target: Negative; positive → epidural abscess or hematogenous source

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; anesthetic risk; diabetic patients at increased disc herniation and infection risk
Surgical candidacy; blood product availability for emergency decompression
UTI (common comorbidity and mimicker of urinary symptoms); neurogenic bladder assessment; baseline
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; UTI may coexist — treat but do NOT attribute bladder dysfunction solely to UTI if CES features present

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: MRI and anesthetic planning; pregnancy may exacerbate disc herniation (increased lordosis/weight)
Essential/Core Labs.target: Negative; if positive → MRI still indicated (no gadolinium needed for CES diagnosis)

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Bacterial infection differential (more specific than CRP); if abscess suspected

Extended Workup.rationale: Diabetes assessment (risk factor for disc herniation, infection, neuropathy); post-operative wound healing
If imaging suggests neoplastic etiology rather than disc herniation
Multiple myeloma presenting as cauda equina compression
Immunocompromised → infection risk; primary CNS lymphoma differential
Pre-existing UTI; post-catheterization planning; differentiate neurogenic bladder from UTI
Extended Workup.target: Negative; if positive → treat but continue CES workup

Extended Workup.rationale: KEY DIAGNOSTIC TEST: bladder retention is hallmark of CES; PVR >200 mL is highly concerning; >500 mL strongly suggestive of neurogenic retention
Extended Workup.target: PVR <100 mL (normal); PVR >200 mL → significant retention; >500 mL → almost certainly neurogenic

Rare/Specialized.item: CSF analysis (only at surgery or LP if needed)
Rare/Specialized.rationale: If inflammatory/infectious etiology suspected (GBS affecting cauda equina = rare); leptomeningeal carcinomatosis
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal; elevated protein → GBS, tumor; malignant cells → leptomeningeal disease

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Atypical CES without structural cause; paraneoplastic cauda equina neuritis (anti-CRMP5/CV2, anti-amphiphysin)
GBS variant affecting cauda equina roots (rare); if imaging shows nerve root enhancement without structural compression
Rare/Specialized.target: Negative; positive → GBS/CIDP affecting cauda equina

Rare/Specialized.rationale: If conus medullaris lesion rather than cauda equina compression; NMOSD can affect conus
Neurosarcoidosis affecting cauda equina (nerve root inflammation/enhancement without structural lesion); elevated ACE
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal ACE; chest CT: no hilar lymphadenopathy; if positive → neurosarcoidosis

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Chronic or atypical CES; differentiate from peripheral neuropathy, plexopathy; establish nerve root involvement pattern; prognostic (denervation = poor recovery)
Rare/Specialized.target: Abnormal: acute denervation (fibrillations, positive sharp waves) in L4-S4 myotomes bilaterally; absent H-reflex bilaterally; abnormal pudendal nerve conduction

Lumbar Puncture.timing: LP is NOT required for diagnosis of typical CES (disc herniation, tumor, abscess seen on MRI); ONLY if inflammatory/infectious etiology without clear structural cause; OR CT myelogram if MRI impossible
Lumbar Puncture.target: CSF protein elevation (GBS, tumor); pleocytosis (infection, inflammation); malignant cells (leptomeningeal disease); albuminocytologic dissociation (GBS)
Lumbar Puncture.contraindications: Do NOT perform LP if large disc herniation compressing cauda equina (could theoretically worsen by altering pressure dynamics — proceed to surgery instead); coagulopathy; abscess at LP site

Essential/First-line.timing: **Within 4 hours of ED arrival — SURGICAL EMERGENCY; ideally within 1 hour**; extends to thoracolumbar junction (T10-sacrum) to include conus medullaris
Essential/First-line.target: Large disc herniation (most common — 45% of CES cases) compressing cauda equina; canal compromise; level of compression; number of roots compressed; disc fragment migration; tumor, abscess, or hematoma as alternative cause; conus medullaris location and signal
Essential/First-line.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; severe claustrophobia (sedate — do NOT delay MRI for anxiety); GFR <30 for contrast (but contrast NOT required for disc herniation diagnosis — obtain non-contrast first)

Essential/First-line.timing: Add contrast if: suspected abscess, tumor, or inflammatory etiology; ring-enhancing epidural collection = abscess; homogeneous enhancement = tumor; nerve root enhancement = inflammatory/neoplastic
Essential/First-line.target: Epidural abscess (ring enhancement, restricted diffusion); tumor (enhancing mass); nerve root enhancement (inflammatory, leptomeningeal disease); distinguish from disc herniation (which does NOT enhance)
Essential/First-line.contraindications: GFR <30 (gadolinium risk — benefit outweighs risk in emergency); gadolinium allergy (premedicate)

Essential/First-line.timing: **Before MRI if possible — critical triage tool**; have patient attempt to void → immediate bladder ultrasound for PVR
Essential/First-line.target: PVR >200 mL = significant retention → HIGH probability of CES; PVR >500 mL = almost certain neurogenic retention; normal PVR does NOT exclude early/incomplete CES

Essential/First-line.timing: While awaiting MRI; identifies vertebral collapse, spondylolisthesis, fracture, alignment; limited value but rapid triage tool
Essential/First-line.target: Disc space narrowing; spondylolisthesis; fracture; alignment abnormality; NOTE: X-rays CANNOT diagnose disc herniation — MRI is required

Extended.timing: If MRI not available or contraindicated; inferior to MRI for soft tissue but shows bone and canal narrowing; CT myelogram if MRI impossible
Extended.target: Disc herniation (seen as soft tissue density in canal); bone fragments; canal diameter; fracture; spondylolisthesis
Extended.contraindications: CT alone has limited sensitivity for disc herniation vs. MRI; myelogram adds invasive risk

Extended.timing: If MRI absolutely contraindicated (implant); intrathecal contrast via LP → CT; demonstrates level of block and root compression
Extended.target: Complete or partial block; compressed cauda equina roots; level and extent of compression; may miss small free fragments
Extended.contraindications: LP contraindicated if abscess suspected at LP site; coagulopathy; rare but important if MRI impossible

Extended.timing: If etiology unclear; evaluate for additional levels of disease; concurrent cord compression; tumor staging; multilevel disc disease
Extended.target: Additional sites of compression; intramedullary lesion (conus); multifocal disease

Extended.timing: Post-acute phase; quantify bladder dysfunction; detrusor areflexia (CES pattern); plan long-term bladder management
Extended.target: Detrusor areflexia (areflexic bladder) = cauda equina denervation; decreased bladder sensation; increased capacity; poor emptying
Extended.contraindications: Acute UTI; recent surgery (timing per surgeon)

Extended.timing: Quantify sphincter dysfunction; prognostic for recovery; pudendal nerve conduction
Extended.target: Reduced anal sphincter pressures; denervated pudendal nerve
Extended.contraindications: Patient tolerance; acute phase may not be appropriate

Extended.timing: 2-3 weeks post-onset (acute denervation takes 2-3 weeks to appear on EMG); prognosis; differentiate from peripheral neuropathy or plexopathy
Extended.target: Bilateral L4-S4 denervation; reduced CMAP amplitudes in bilateral L5/S1 distribution; absent H-reflexes bilaterally; bilateral pudendal neuropathy
Extended.contraindications: Too early in acute phase (<2 weeks = may be false negative for denervation); patient tolerance

Rare/Specialized.timing: If vascular malformation suspected (spinal dural AV fistula causing venous hypertension → CES symptoms); progressive myelopathy/CES with dilated serpiginous vessels on MRI
Rare/Specialized.target: Spinal AV fistula; AVM; arteriovenous malformation feeding vessels

Rare/Specialized.timing: Definitive diagnosis and treatment of spinal dural AV fistula; also pre-operative embolization for vascular tumors
If malignancy causing CES — staging; unknown primary identification
Formal bladder function assessment; post-decompression recovery monitoring; long-term bladder management planning
Rare/Specialized.target: Bladder compliance; detrusor function; capacity; sensation thresholds

dosing.instructions: **THIS IS A SURGICAL EMERGENCY — TIME IS NERVE**; Emergent neurosurgery/spine surgery consultation; posterior lumbar laminectomy with discectomy (most common procedure); **Timing:** Within 24h of symptom onset — ideally within 24h but outcome improves the sooner surgery is performed; <24h clearly better than >48h; some evidence supports <12h for best outcomes; **Complete CES (CES-R with retention):** Truly emergent — surgery as soon as possible (within hours); **Incomplete CES (CES-I):** Urgent — surgery within 24h; risk of progressing to complete

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Ahn et al. (2000): Decompression <48h = significantly better outcomes for bladder recovery (70% vs. 30%); Todd (2005) meta-analysis: Earlier surgery = better outcomes, but exact time threshold debated; DeBois et al. (2019): <24h optimal, <48h acceptable; Srikandarajah et al. (2020): Urgent surgery (<24h) associated with better functional outcomes

dosing.instructions: **Bladder scan (PVR) STAT on arrival** — do NOT wait for MRI; if PVR >200 mL → Foley catheter placement; if PVR >500 mL → Foley + strict I&O monitoring; avoid overdistension (>600 mL causes detrusor damage — may become irreversible); document voiding pattern; post-operative: trial of void at 24-48h with PVR checks; CIC (clean intermittent catheterization) teaching if retention persists

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Bladder overdistension causes detrusor muscle damage → irreversible areflexic bladder; early catheterization prevents secondary damage; bladder recovery is the MOST SENSITIVE indicator of CES recovery and the MOST COMMON persistent deficit

dosing.instructions: Back pain and radicular pain often severe; acetaminophen 650-1000 mg q6h (scheduled) + opioids (morphine 2-4 mg IV q3h PRN or hydromorphone 0.5-1 mg IV q3h PRN); NSAIDs: ketorolac 15-30 mg IV q6h (short-term, if no surgical contraindication and normal renal function — pre-op use is surgeon-dependent); neuropathic: gabapentin 300 mg TID (start if radicular pain prominent); avoid excessive sedation that obscures neurologic exam

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Adequate analgesia essential for patient assessment and MRI tolerance; balance with need for neurologic monitoring

dosing.instructions: **Disc herniation CES:** Steroids NOT routinely indicated (no evidence of benefit; some centers use short course); **Tumor-related CES:** Dexamethasone 10 mg IV bolus → 4 mg q6h (same as MSCC protocol); **Abscess-related CES:** Dexamethasone controversial (may impair immune response) — use only if severe edema with rapid neurologic decline

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: No RCT evidence supporting steroids for disc-related CES; tumor CES: Sorensen et al. (1994) supports steroids; abscess: prioritize antibiotics + surgical drainage

dosing.instructions: **Epidural abscess causing CES:** Empiric: Vancomycin 25-30 mg/kg IV load + ceftriaxone 2g IV q12h (or cefepime 2g IV q8h); adjust to culture/sensitivity; MRSA coverage essential; **Duration:** Typically 6-8 weeks IV antibiotics for epidural abscess; **Timing:** Start AFTER blood cultures drawn but do NOT delay if patient is deteriorating

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: S. aureus (including MRSA) is most common organism in epidural abscess (60-70%); gram-negative coverage for UTI/abdominal source; streptococci, anaerobes less common

dosing.instructions: SCDs immediately; pharmacologic prophylaxis: enoxaparin 40 mg SQ daily starting post-operatively (typically 12-24h after surgery per surgeon protocol); immobile CES patients at high VTE risk

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Immobility + lower extremity weakness = high DVT risk; mechanical prophylaxis pre-operatively; early pharmacologic prophylaxis post-operatively

dosing.instructions: Assess rectal tone (digital rectal exam — absent/reduced in CES); bowel regimen: docusate 100 mg BID + senna 2 tabs HS; bisacodyl suppository daily if no BM in 48h; monitor for fecal incontinence vs. constipation (both occur in CES); opioid-related constipation compounds the issue

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Bowel dysfunction common in CES; S2-S4 denervation affects external anal sphincter and rectal sensation; proactive management prevents complications

dosing.instructions: **Most common surgery:** Posterior approach; laminectomy at affected level(s); remove herniated disc fragment; decompress cauda equina; **Approach:** Midline; may require bilateral laminotomy or hemi-laminectomy for lateralized discs; large central herniations often require bilateral approach; **Key:** Ensure COMPLETE decompression — incomplete decompression leads to persistent deficit; intraoperative confirmation with direct visualization of free cauda equina nerve roots
dosing.orderSentence: **Lumbar laminectomy + discectomy (disc herniation CES)** - - - see dosing

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Gold standard for disc-related CES; no RCT comparing surgery vs. non-operative (would be unethical to randomize given natural history); observational data uniformly supports early surgical decompression

dosing.instructions: Minimally invasive approach; appropriate for contained disc herniations without significant canal stenosis; faster recovery; less tissue disruption; may not provide adequate decompression for massive central disc herniation

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Smaller incision, less muscle disruption; but surgeon must ensure adequate decompression — do NOT compromise canal visualization for a smaller incision in CES

dosing.instructions: Posterior approach; laminectomy; drain abscess; culture material; irrigate; leave wound open or with drain; may require multi-level decompression; **Combined with:** IV antibiotics 6-8 weeks; follow with serial MRI and inflammatory markers
dosing.orderSentence: **Surgical drainage + decompression (epidural abscess)** - IV - see dosing

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Epidural abscess with CES = surgical emergency; medical management alone (antibiotics without surgery) only if: no neurologic deficit AND very high surgical risk; most CES presentations require surgery

dosing.instructions: If tumor-related CES (e.g., schwannoma, ependymoma, metastasis); posterior decompression ± en bloc or piecemeal tumor resection; send pathology; may need subsequent radiation/chemotherapy

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Intradural-extramedullary tumors (schwannoma, meningioma, myxopapillary ependymoma) are potentially curable with complete resection; metastatic CES → decompression + radiation

dosing.instructions: Epidural hematoma causing CES (spontaneous on anticoagulation, post-procedural, or post-traumatic); emergent laminectomy with hematoma evacuation; reverse anticoagulation STAT

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Spontaneous spinal epidural hematoma: Groen & Ponssen (1990): better outcomes with surgery <12h of onset; anticoagulation reversal essential (4F-PCC for warfarin, idarucizumab for dabigatran, andexanet for Xa inhibitors)

dosing.instructions: **ONLY appropriate if:** (1) Imaging does NOT show significant structural compression, (2) Symptoms are improving spontaneously, (3) Patient refuses surgery (document informed refusal thoroughly), (4) Medically inoperable (extremely high surgical risk); **Requires:** Close monitoring with serial neuro exams q2-4h; repeat MRI if worsening; immediate surgery if any progression

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Non-operative management is NOT standard of care for CES with structural compression; delayed surgery has worse outcomes; informed consent must document risks of non-operative management (permanent bladder/bowel/sexual dysfunction, progressive weakness)

dosing.instructions: If bladder function does not recover by 48-72h post-surgery; teach patient CIC q4-6h; target PVR <100 mL before discontinuing CIC; may take weeks to months to recover

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: CIC is preferred over indwelling Foley for long-term bladder management (lower UTI risk); most patients can learn self-catheterization; bladder recovery may take 6-12 months

dosing.instructions: Gabapentin 300 mg PO TID → titrate to 600-900 mg TID over 1-2 weeks; OR pregabalin 75 mg BID → 150-300 mg BID; duloxetine 30 mg daily → 60 mg daily; amitriptyline 10-25 mg HS (caution: urinary retention may worsen); topical lidocaine 5% patches for localized radicular pain

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Neuropathic pain (burning, tingling, electric shocks in perineum, legs) is common and debilitating after CES; may persist chronically; multimodal approach needed

dosing.instructions: PT evaluation within 24h post-operatively; early mobilization; lower extremity strengthening; gait training; core stabilization; progressive activity as tolerated; pelvic floor PT for bladder/bowel recovery

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Early rehabilitation improves functional outcomes; pelvic floor rehabilitation is evidence-based for bladder/bowel recovery after CES

dosing.instructions: ADL assessment; adaptive equipment; if lower extremity weakness impairs function; bathroom modifications; return-to-work planning

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Functional independence optimization

dosing.instructions: Specialized pelvic floor PT; biofeedback for bladder and bowel retraining; Kegel exercises (if able); electrical stimulation of pelvic floor; sacral neuromodulation evaluation if persistent dysfunction >12 months

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Evidence supports pelvic floor PT for bladder and bowel recovery after CES; biofeedback improves outcomes

dosing.instructions: CES has devastating psychosocial impact (sexual dysfunction, incontinence, chronic pain, disability in often-young patients); depression screening (PHQ-9); anxiety screening; sexual health counseling; support groups; consider psychiatry referral

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Depression affects 30-60% of CES patients long-term; sexual dysfunction is profoundly distressing; early psychological intervention improves coping and recovery

dosing.instructions: Docusate 100 mg BID + senna 2 tabs HS; bisacodyl suppository PRN; digital stimulation for areflexic bowel; timed bowel program; fiber supplementation; adequate hydration

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Neurogenic bowel management reduces complications (impaction, incontinence); establish routine bowel program early

dosing.orderSentence: Anticholinergics (oxybutynin, tolterodine — for urgency) - - - see dosing
Alpha-blockers (tamsulosin, silodosin) — without urologic guidance - - - see dosing

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.item: Epidural steroid injection (as treatment for CES)

dosing.orderSentence: Epidural steroid injection (as treatment for CES) - - - see dosing
Excessive IV fluids (post-operatively) - IV - see dosing

Referrals & Consults.item: Transfer to surgical center (if no spine surgeon)

Patient Instructions.item: Urology consultation
PM&R / Rehabilitation consultation
Pain management consultation
Sexual health counseling
Colorectal surgery / GI consultation
Social work / case management
Medicolegal documentation

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Revision surgery
Sacral neuromodulation
Intrathecal baclofen pump
Chronic pain management program
Psychiatric referral
Legal documentation review

differential.features: Key Differentiating Features
differential.tests: Distinguishing Studies

differential.features: Upper motor neuron AND lower motor neuron signs; bilateral and symmetric; early bladder/bowel dysfunction; back pain less prominent than radicular pain; reflexes may be hyperactive (UMN) or absent (LMN); typically at T12-L2 level; more symmetric than CES
differential.tests: MRI: lesion at T12-L2 level (conus); cord signal change (T2 hyperintensity); CES lesion is below L1-L2 (cauda equina roots only); conus lesion → Babinski may be present (CES → absent or flexor)

differential.features: Neurogenic claudication (walking-induced symptoms relieved by sitting/flexion); chronic progressive course; bilateral leg pain/weakness with walking; no bladder/bowel dysfunction (unless severe CES from stenosis); intermittent symptoms
differential.tests: MRI: multilevel stenosis; trefoil canal shape; ligamentum flavum hypertrophy; NO acute disc herniation; symptoms are exercise-induced, not constant; PVR normal

differential.features: Unilateral radiculopathy; no bilateral symptoms; no saddle anesthesia; no bladder/bowel dysfunction; straight leg raise positive; single dermatomal pattern
differential.tests: MRI: lateral or posterolateral disc herniation compressing single root; NO cauda equina compression; normal PVR; normal rectal tone

differential.features: Fever (50-66%); IVDU, immunocompromised, recent procedure; rapidly progressive; ESR >20 (94% sensitivity); severe spinal tenderness; leukocytosis; can cause CES if lumbar location
differential.tests: MRI: ring-enhancing epidural collection with restricted diffusion; blood cultures positive (60%); ESR/CRP markedly elevated; clinical triad: back pain → radiculopathy → weakness (classic but only 10-15% present with full triad)

differential.features: Acute onset; anticoagulation or post-procedural (epidural injection, spinal surgery, LP); severe back pain → rapid progressive weakness; coagulopathy history
differential.tests: MRI: epidural collection with blood signal (T1 bright in subacute); coagulation studies abnormal; anticoagulation history; post-procedural temporal relationship

differential.features: Ascending symmetric weakness; areflexia; post-infectious (Campylobacter, CMV, EBV); sensory symptoms but often mild; facial weakness may be present; no saddle anesthesia typically; CSF: albuminocytologic dissociation
differential.tests: MRI spine: may show nerve root enhancement BUT no structural compression; CSF: elevated protein, normal cells; NCS: demyelinating pattern or AMAN pattern; anti-ganglioside antibodies

differential.features: Chronic course; distal > proximal; length-dependent pattern; diabetes, alcohol; stocking-glove distribution; gradual onset; reflexes may be reduced distally; NO saddle anesthesia; NO acute bladder retention
differential.tests: EMG/NCS: diffuse length-dependent neuropathy; MRI: no structural compression; HbA1c; B12; SPEP; gradual course distinguishes from acute CES

differential.features: Unilateral (usually); painful; diabetic amyotrophy; radiation-induced; tumor infiltration; asymmetric weakness/sensory loss in lumbosacral plexus distribution; typically NO bladder dysfunction (unless bilateral)
differential.tests: MRI pelvis: plexus enhancement or mass; EMG: plexus distribution denervation; CT abdomen/pelvis: retroperitoneal mass; HbA1c; typically unilateral

differential.features: Inconsistent exam findings; Hoover's sign positive; non-anatomical sensory pattern; normal imaging; normal PVR; no objective sphincter dysfunction; give-way weakness; history of psychological stressors
differential.tests: MRI: normal; PVR: normal; rectal tone: normal; neurophysiology: normal; psychiatric history; clinical inconsistency (e.g., inability to lift leg on command but normal gait observed); NOTE: FND is a diagnosis of exclusion in CES — always obtain MRI first

evidence.recommendation: Cauda Equina Syndrome Standards of Care
evidence.evidenceLevel: British Association of Spine Surgeons (BASS) / Society of British Neurological Surgeons (SBNS)

evidence.recommendation: AANS/CNS Guidelines on Lumbar Disc Herniation
evidence.evidenceLevel: AANS/CNS Joint Section on Disorders of the Spine and Peripheral Nerves
Systematic review: Decompression <48h of CES onset → 70% bladder recovery vs. 30% if >48h; motor outcomes also significantly better with early surgery
evidence.source: Established 48h as important threshold; but sooner is always better

evidence.evidenceLevel: 42 studies: Earlier decompression consistently associated with better outcomes across motor, bladder, and bowel domains; no clear cutoff but <24h is optimal
evidence.source: Confirmed urgency of CES surgical decompression; surgical timing is KEY modifiable factor

evidence.evidenceLevel: UK Cohort: Urgent surgery (<24h) vs. delayed (>24h): better bladder outcomes (OR 2.1) and motor outcomes (OR 1.6) with urgent surgery
evidence.source: Modern evidence supporting <24h surgical timing; NHS pathway development

evidence.evidenceLevel: Timing analysis: <12h, 12-24h, 24-48h, >48h: progressive decline in outcomes with each delay interval; <12h had best bladder recovery
evidence.source: Supports as-soon-as-possible approach; <12h may be ideal

evidence.evidenceLevel: CES-I vs. CES-R outcomes: CES-I (incomplete) with early surgery → 95% good bladder outcome; CES-R (retention) with early surgery → 53% good bladder outcome; CES-R with delayed surgery → 27% good outcome
evidence.source: Established CES-I vs. CES-R classification; demonstrated that retention onset is critical prognostic marker

evidence.evidenceLevel: Spinal epidural hematoma: better outcomes with surgery <12h of onset; anticoagulation most common cause
evidence.source: Established surgical urgency for hematoma-related CES

evidence.evidenceLevel: Classic paper on CES natural history: untreated CES from disc herniation → permanent bladder dysfunction in >90%, persistent weakness in >70%, chronic pain in >80%
evidence.source: Established that CES without surgical treatment leads to devastating permanent deficits

evidence.evidenceLevel: Medicolegal analysis: CES is the most litigated condition in spinal surgery; delayed diagnosis is the most common reason for successful claims; failure to perform timely MRI and delayed surgery are key factors
evidence.source: Documentation of timeline is CRITICAL; standardized CES pathways reduce medicolegal risk
Bilateral leg pain/weakness; bilateral sensory changes; NO urinary symptoms; normal PVR
Difficulty initiating stream; reduced sensation of voiding; urgency; partial retention (PVR 200-500 mL); reduced but present perineal sensation; reduced anal tone

evidence.evidenceLevel: Painless urinary retention WITH overflow incontinence
evidence.source: Painless retention (PVR >500 mL); overflow incontinence; absent perineal sensation; absent anal tone; often absent bulbocavernosus reflex
Ankle dorsiflexion (TA), great toe extension (EHL), hip abduction
Lateral leg, dorsum of foot, first web space

monitoring.item: Neurologic examination (lower extremity strength, sensation, reflexes)
monitoring.action: Pre-op worsening: escalate surgical urgency; post-op worsening: STAT MRI (hematoma, residual compression, re-herniation)

monitoring.frequency: q4h (at minimum with each neuro check)
Continuous monitoring via Foley with hourly I&O pre/post-op; Trial of void at 24-48h post-op with PVR check
monitoring.target: PVR <100 mL to discontinue catheter; voiding spontaneously
monitoring.action: PVR >200 mL after trial of void → replace Foley; begin CIC teaching; urology consult
Escalate analgesics; add neuropathic agents; new/worsening pain post-op → concern for hematoma/complication
Wound complication → surgical team notification; drain output monitoring
Bowel regimen intensification; abdominal X-ray if distended; rectal exam
Fever: wound infection, UTI (Foley-associated), DVT, abscess; cultures and imaging as indicated
Bilateral lower extremity duplex US if symptoms; therapeutic anticoagulation if confirmed

disposition.criteria: Criteria

Post-operative monitoring (surgeon-dependent — many post-laminectomies go to floor); bilateral lower extremity paralysis with hemodynamic concerns; epidural abscess with sepsis; significant comorbidities affecting anesthetic recovery; autonomic dysfunction

ALL CES patients require admission; pre-operative CES awaiting surgical decompression; post-operative monitoring; pain management; bladder/bowel monitoring; PT/OT initiation; epidural abscess requiring IV antibiotics

CES is NEVER an observation diagnosis — all suspected CES patients require emergent MRI and admission for surgical evaluation; even if MRI is negative for structural compression, admission for monitoring is prudent if clinical suspicion is high

Spinal Cord Compression (Malignant).title: Spinal Cord Compression (Malignant)
icd10: C79.49 (Secondary malignant neoplasm of other parts of nervous system)
M49.50 (Collapsed vertebra in diseases classified elsewhere)
Spinal Cord Compression (Malignant).scope: ** Emergency evaluation and management of malignant (metastatic) spinal cord compression in adults. Covers dexamethasone protocols, emergent imaging, surgical decompression criteria (Patchell criteria), radiation therapy, vertebral body assessment, functional prognostication, and disposition. Excludes non-malignant compressive myelopathy (disc herniation, epidural abscess — separate templates), primary spinal cord tumors (intramedullary), and cauda equina syndrome from malignancy (partially overlaps — see separate template for CES).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; surgical candidacy; chemotherapy effects; infection (epidural abscess differential)
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; leukocytosis may suggest infection; thrombocytopenia affects surgical/procedural candidacy

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Renal function (contrast, medications); electrolytes (hypercalcemia of malignancy); hepatic function (chemotherapy dosing, metastatic disease)
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; calcium >10.5 mg/dL → assess for hypercalcemia of malignancy

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Coagulopathy assessment; surgical candidacy; anticoagulation reversal if emergent surgery needed
Epidural abscess differential (highly elevated ESR >30-50 typically); inflammatory markers for malignancy
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal-mildly elevated in malignancy; markedly elevated ESR/CRP → strongly consider abscess

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Epidural abscess differential; bacteremia if febrile
Essential/Core Labs.target: Negative; positive → epidural abscess more likely than tumor

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline before high-dose dexamethasone; steroid hyperglycemia
Essential/Core Labs.target: <180 mg/dL; anticipate significant hyperglycemia with high-dose steroids

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Surgical candidacy; blood product availability
Hypercalcemia of malignancy (present in 10-30% of cancer patients); can cause confusion, weakness mimicking cord compression progression
Essential/Core Labs.target: Corrected Ca <10.5 mg/dL; if elevated → IV fluids, calcitonin, bisphosphonate

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Tumor burden marker; lymphoma (very high LDH); prognostic
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; very high → lymphoma, aggressive malignancy

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Urinary retention (neurogenic bladder from cord compression); UTI (fever differential); baseline renal function
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; retention with high post-void residual expected in cord compression

Extended Workup.item: Tumor markers (PSA, CEA, CA 19-9, CA 125, CA 15-3, AFP, β-hCG)
Extended Workup.rationale: Unknown primary cancer; PSA (prostate — most common spinal metastasis), CEA (GI, lung), CA 15-3 (breast), etc.
Multiple myeloma (common cause of vertebral compression/cord compression); M-protein, light chains
Extended Workup.target: No monoclonal protein; if present → myeloma workup

Extended Workup.rationale: Osteoblastic metastases (prostate, breast); Paget's disease differential
Tumor lysis syndrome risk (lymphoma, rapidly proliferating tumors); pre-treatment assessment
If infection/abscess differential is high; more specific than CRP for bacterial infection
Thyroid cancer metastases (follicular thyroid cancer has bony tropism)
Bone health; pathologic fracture risk; supplement if deficient

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Lymphoma/leukemia presenting as epidural mass
Myeloma; lymphoma; unknown primary with bone marrow involvement
If myelopathy features atypical for compression (e.g., subacute progressive without clear structural compression)
Rare/Specialized.target: Negative; positive changes diagnosis from compression to paraneoplastic myelopathy

Rare/Specialized.rationale: If imaging shows longitudinal intramedullary lesion rather than epidural compression → NMOSD differential
Rare/Specialized.target: Negative; positive → NMOSD not metastatic compression

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Unknown primary; tissue diagnosis needed before treatment; lymphoma requires tissue for definitive diagnosis (sensitive to steroids — obtain tissue BEFORE steroids if possible in suspected lymphoma)

Lumbar Puncture.timing: LP is NOT routinely indicated in MSCC; CSF cytology only if leptomeningeal disease suspected AND no complete block; CT myelogram if MRI not available (different indication)
Lumbar Puncture.target: N/A — LP is diagnostic adjunct only in specific situations
Lumbar Puncture.contraindications: CONTRAINDICATED with complete spinal block above LP level (risk of neurologic deterioration/coning); coagulopathy; local infection

Essential/First-line.item: MRI entire spine with and without contrast (gadolinium)
Essential/First-line.timing: **Within 4 hours of presentation (24h max)**; GOLD STANDARD; must image ENTIRE spine (multifocal metastases in 30-40%)
Essential/First-line.target: Epidural mass with cord compression; level(s) of compression; Bilsky grade (0-3); vertebral body involvement; number of levels; intramedullary vs. extramedullary-intradural vs. epidural; cord signal change (T2 hyperintensity = edema/myelopathy — poor prognostic sign); paraspinal soft tissue extension
Essential/First-line.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; severe claustrophobia (sedate); GFR <30 (gadolinium risk — benefit outweighs risk in emergency)

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate while awaiting MRI; identifies vertebral collapse, pathologic fracture, alignment; 70% sensitivity for vertebral metastases (30% miss rate)
Essential/First-line.target: Vertebral body collapse; pedicle erosion ("winking owl sign" on AP); pathologic fracture; kyphosis; alignment

Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24-48h; staging; primary identification; lung is most common primary
Essential/First-line.target: Primary tumor; staging of metastatic disease; lymphadenopathy; visceral metastases

Essential/First-line.timing: If MRI contraindicated or unavailable; pre-operative planning for bone assessment; vertebral body stability (SINS score); CT myelogram if MRI not possible
Essential/First-line.target: Bone destruction pattern (lytic vs. blastic vs. mixed); posterior element involvement; fracture; canal compromise; vertebral body collapse >50%

Extended.timing: If MRI contraindicated (pacemaker, implant); intrathecal contrast via LP → CT; demonstrates level of block
Extended.target: Complete or partial subarachnoid block; level of compression; multiple levels of disease
Extended.contraindications: LP contraindicated if complete block above puncture site (risk of neurologic deterioration); coagulopathy

Extended.timing: Staging; primary identification; assessing treatment response; distinguishing active tumor from treated/necrotic bone
Extended.target: Active metastatic disease; primary tumor identification

Extended.timing: Skeletal staging; identifies additional osseous metastases; blastic > lytic sensitivity; useful for prostate, breast
Extended.target: Additional bone metastases; may miss purely lytic lesions (renal, thyroid, myeloma)

Extended.timing: If lung primary or melanoma (high brain metastasis risk); symptoms suggesting intracranial disease
Extended.target: Brain metastases (concurrent in 10-30% of patients with MSCC)

Extended.timing: Tissue diagnosis if unknown primary; CRITICAL for suspected lymphoma (radiosensitive — may not need surgery); obtain BEFORE steroids if lymphoma suspected (steroids can render biopsy non-diagnostic)
Baseline bone density if prolonged steroids anticipated; osteoporosis risk

Rare/Specialized.timing: If highly vascular tumor suspected (RCC, thyroid) — pre-operative embolization to reduce surgical bleeding
Rare/Specialized.target: Tumor vascularity; feeding vessels; embolization candidacy

Rare/Specialized.timing: Highly vascular metastases (RCC, thyroid); 24-48h before surgery to reduce intraoperative blood loss
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Contrast allergy; tumor supplying anterior spinal artery (risk of cord infarction)

Rare/Specialized.timing: Post-treatment stability assessment; if clinical instability suspected
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Acute cord compression (do NOT flex/extend if acute neurologic deficit)

Rare/Specialized.timing: If thyroid primary suspected (follicular thyroid cancer has high bone tropism)

dosing.instructions: **Standard loading dose:** 10 mg IV bolus STAT; **Then:** 4 mg IV/PO q6h (16 mg/day); **High-dose (severe deficits or rapidly progressive):** 96 mg IV bolus (controversial — see evidence) → 24 mg q6h x 3 days → rapid taper; **Moderate deficits / ambulatory:** 10 mg IV → 4 mg q6h; **Begin taper after definitive treatment initiated;** GI prophylaxis: PPI while on steroids; Monitor glucose q6h

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Sorensen et al. (1994): Dexamethasone + radiation vs. radiation alone → 81% vs. 63% ambulatory at treatment end; High-dose (96 mg) vs. standard (10 mg): Vecht et al. (1989) — higher response rate at 1 week but more side effects; MOST centers now use moderate dose (10 mg load → 16 mg/day); Begin within 6h of diagnosis

dosing.instructions: Strict log-roll precautions; flat bed transport; cervical collar if cervical spine involved; thoracolumbar brace (TLSO) if thoracolumbar; avoid flexion/extension; transfer on spine board if unstable fracture suspected

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Unstable pathologic fracture may worsen cord compression with movement; SINS score guides instability assessment

dosing.instructions: Assess for urinary retention (cord compression causes neurogenic bladder); straight catheterize if retention → place Foley if residual >200 mL or ongoing retention; monitor I&O strictly

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Urinary retention is a common presenting feature and may be the first sign of cord compression; bladder function correlates with motor recovery prognosis

dosing.instructions: SCDs immediately; pharmacologic prophylaxis (enoxaparin 40 mg SQ daily) within 24-48h unless surgery imminent; spinal cord compression patients have VERY HIGH VTE risk (up to 25-50% without prophylaxis)

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Cancer + immobility + spinal cord injury = extremely high VTE risk; mechanical prophylaxis alone insufficient

dosing.instructions: Back pain often severe; acetaminophen 650-1000 mg q6h scheduled + opioids PRN (morphine 2-4 mg IV q3h PRN or oxycodone 5-10 mg PO q4h PRN); NSAIDs cautiously (renal function, bleeding risk); dexamethasone itself reduces pain from edema/inflammation; neuropathic pain: gabapentin 300 mg TID (titrate) or pregabalin 75 mg BID

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Pain is the presenting symptom in 83-95% of patients; median 7 weeks before diagnosis; adequate analgesia essential for function and quality of life

dosing.instructions: Neurogenic bowel from cord compression + opioid constipation; docusate 100 mg BID + senna 2 tabs HS; bisacodyl suppository PRN; monitor for ileus

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Bowel dysfunction common; proactive management prevents complications

dosing.instructions: Fingerstick q6h on high-dose dexamethasone; insulin sliding scale → basal-bolus if persistent >180; anticipate glucose will rise significantly within hours of steroid initiation

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: High-dose dexamethasone causes severe hyperglycemia in majority of patients

dosing.instructions: **Indications (Patchell criteria + expanded):** (1) Single site of compression, (2) Paraplegia ≤48h, (3) Not radiosensitive tumor (not lymphoma, myeloma, SCLC, germ cell), (4) Life expectancy >3 months, (5) ECOG ≤2 / able to tolerate surgery, (6) Mechanical instability (SINS ≥7), (7) Neurologic deterioration during radiation; **Approach:** Posterior decompressive laminectomy ± instrumented stabilization; anterior corpectomy with cage/cement for anterior compression with instability; **Timing:** Within 24h of presentation (ideally <12h); Followed by radiation within 2-4 weeks post-op

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: **Patchell et al. (2005) — LANDMARK:** Surgery + radiation vs. radiation alone: ambulatory rate 84% vs. 57% (p=0.001); maintained ambulation longer (122 vs. 13 days); more patients regained ambulation (62% vs. 19%); surgery retained continence longer; survival trend (126 vs. 100 days)

dosing.instructions: **Primary modality if:** Radiosensitive tumor (lymphoma, myeloma, SCLC, seminoma), surgical contraindication, multiple noncontiguous levels, life expectancy <3 months, poor surgical candidate; **Standard:** 30 Gy in 10 fractions (2 weeks) or 20 Gy in 5 fractions (1 week); **Short course (poor prognosis):** 8 Gy single fraction; **Begin within 24h of diagnosis**; Can start same day as dexamethasone; Radiation field covers 1-2 vertebral bodies above and below involved segment

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Rades et al. (2008): No significant difference between 30 Gy/10 vs. 20 Gy/5 for motor function recovery or local control; 8 Gy single fraction appropriate for poor prognosis (life expectancy <6 months)

dosing.instructions: **Indications:** Previously irradiated segment (re-irradiation); radioresistant histology (RCC, melanoma, sarcoma); oligometastatic disease; post-operative; **Dose:** 16-24 Gy single fraction or 24-30 Gy in 3 fractions; **Requires:** Spinal cord dose constraints (max cord dose 10-14 Gy single fraction); MRI-based planning; **Timing:** As soon as technically feasible
dosing.orderSentence: **Stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT) / Spine SRS** - - - see dosing

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: RTOG 0631 and multiple institutional series: High local control (85-95%) for radioresistant histologies; superior to conventional EBRT for RCC, melanoma; separation surgery + SBRT emerging as preferred approach for radioresistant tumors

dosing.instructions: **Indication:** Epidural tumor compressing cord from radioresistant primary (RCC, melanoma, sarcoma); goal is NOT gross total resection — goal is to decompress cord and create ≥2mm separation between tumor and cord to enable safe SBRT delivery; Followed by SBRT within 2-4 weeks

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Laufer et al. (2013): Separation surgery + SBRT: 90% local control at 1 year for radioresistant tumors; allows definitive radiation dose to tumor while respecting cord tolerance

dosing.instructions: **Indications:** Painful pathologic compression fracture; vertebral body instability; post-radiation pain; NO epidural extension compressing cord (cement leak risk into canal); **SINS 7-12 (indeterminate stability):** Consider as adjunct; **Procedure:** Percutaneous PMMA cement injection into vertebral body

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Pain relief in 70-90% within 24-48h; structural support; does NOT address epidural disease; risk of cement leak into epidural space (1-5%)

dosing.instructions: **Radiosensitive tumors as primary/adjunct therapy:** Lymphoma (R-CHOP or equivalent); myeloma (bortezomib-based); SCLC (cisplatin/etoposide); germ cell (BEP); **Other primaries:** Per disease-specific guidelines after stabilization; coordinate with medical oncology

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Chemosensitive tumors (lymphoma, myeloma, germ cell, SCLC) may respond rapidly to systemic therapy; may be used as primary treatment with radiation or as consolidation post-radiation

dosing.instructions: Prostate cancer: ADT (LHRH agonist/antagonist) + enzalutamide/abiraterone/darolutamide; Breast cancer: anti-estrogen/AI per receptor status; Thyroid: levothyroxine suppression + RAI (spine metastases do NOT concentrate RAI well — external radiation preferred)

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Prostate and breast cancer spinal metastases may respond to hormonal manipulation; adjunct to radiation

dosing.instructions: Begin taper once definitive treatment (surgery/radiation) initiated and neurologic status stable/improving; **Taper schedule:** Reduce by 2-4 mg every 3-5 days; typical: 16→12→8→6→4→2→off over 2-3 weeks; slower taper if symptoms recur; monitor for adrenal insufficiency if >2-3 weeks of steroids

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Prolonged high-dose steroids cause significant morbidity; steroid myopathy (proximal weakness — may mimic neurologic progression); PJP risk; hyperglycemia; GI bleed

dosing.instructions: Omeprazole 20 mg daily or pantoprazole 40 mg daily while on dexamethasone

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Steroid + critical illness increases GI bleed risk

dosing.instructions: Calcium 1000-1200 mg + Vitamin D 800-1000 IU daily during steroid course and beyond (bone health in cancer patients)

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Steroid-induced osteoporosis prevention; already compromised bone integrity

dosing.instructions: Zoledronic acid 4 mg IV q4 weeks OR denosumab 120 mg SQ q4 weeks; reduces skeletal-related events (SRE); dental clearance before starting (ONJ risk); renal adjustment for zoledronic acid (hold if GFR <35)

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Zoledronic acid: Rosen et al. (2003) — reduced SRE by 48% in bone metastases; denosumab: Fizazi et al. (2011) — superior to zoledronic acid for SRE reduction in bone metastases (prostate trial)

dosing.instructions: Gabapentin 300 mg TID → titrate to 600-900 mg TID; OR pregabalin 75 mg BID → titrate to 150-300 mg BID; duloxetine 30-60 mg daily as alternative; amitriptyline 10-25 mg HS (anticholinergic caution with urinary retention)

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Radicular and central neuropathic pain common in cord compression; adjuvant analgesics reduce opioid requirements

dosing.instructions: PT/OT evaluation within 24h of admission; early mobilization when cleared by spine surgery; adaptive equipment; wheelchair assessment if paraparetic/paraplegic; ROM exercises; strengthening; transfer training

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Early rehabilitation improves functional outcomes; cancer rehabilitation is evidence-based; patients with MSCC benefit from structured rehab programs

dosing.instructions: Turn q2h; pressure-reducing mattress; heel protectors; skin assessment with Braden scale; nutrition optimization
dosing.orderSentence: **Skin care / pressure ulcer prevention** - - - see dosing

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Immobile patients with cord compression at very high risk for pressure injuries; prevention is critical

dosing.orderSentence: Methotrexate (high-dose, with spinal radiation) - - - see dosing
Intrathecal chemotherapy (with spinal block) - IT - see dosing
Steroids in suspected lymphoma (BEFORE biopsy) - - - see dosing
Bisphosphonates (if GFR <35 for zoledronic acid) - - - see dosing

Patient Instructions.item: Interventional radiology consultation
Orthotics / bracing
Wound care (post-operative)
Nutrition / dietitian
Psychology / psychiatry
Urology consultation
Home health referral

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Re-irradiation (spine)
Repeat surgery
Intrathecal drug delivery
Cement augmentation (post-radiation)
Hospice referral
Clinical trial enrollment

differential.features: Key Differentiating Features
differential.tests: Distinguishing Studies

differential.features: Fever (present in 50-66%); IV drug use, recent procedure, immunosuppression; rapidly progressive; ESR >20 (sensitivity 94%); CRP markedly elevated; ring-enhancing epidural collection on MRI; restricted diffusion in abscess; spine pain with percussion tenderness; leukocytosis
differential.tests: MRI: T2-hyperintense epidural collection with rim enhancement; restricted diffusion (DWI bright, ADC dark) within abscess; blood cultures (positive in 60%); ESR/CRP markedly elevated; procalcitonin >0.5

differential.features: Chronic progressive symptoms; myelopathic signs insidious onset; no cancer history; disc/osteophyte complex on imaging; NO destructive bone lesion; congenital canal narrowing
differential.tests: MRI: disc-osteophyte complex; ligamentum flavum hypertrophy; NO bone destruction; NO contrast enhancement of epidural mass; chronic degenerative changes

differential.features: Intramedullary (within cord parenchyma); ependymoma, astrocytoma; cord expansion with central lesion; no vertebral body destruction; slow progression; syrinx may be present
differential.tests: MRI: cord expansion with intramedullary enhancing lesion; no epidural mass; no vertebral body involvement; ependymoma: central location, hemosiderin cap; astrocytoma: eccentric, irregular

differential.features: No cancer history; older patient with osteoporosis; acute back pain after minor trauma/lifting; no neurologic deficits (usually); vertebral body collapsed but NO epidural mass; NO posterior element involvement
differential.tests: MRI: vertebral body edema (T1 low, STIR high) WITHOUT epidural mass or posterior element involvement; CT: no bone destruction beyond fracture; DEXA: osteoporosis; if ambiguous → biopsy

differential.features: Older adult; bone pain; anemia, renal insufficiency, hypercalcemia ("CRAB"); diffuse lytic lesions; monoclonal protein on SPEP; punched-out skull lesions; responsive to chemotherapy AND radiation
differential.tests: SPEP: M-protein; UPEP: Bence Jones protein; free light chains: abnormal ratio; bone marrow biopsy: >10% plasma cells; CT/MRI: multiple lytic lesions; biopsy: plasmacytoma; KEY: myeloma is RADIOSENSITIVE — radiation first-line

differential.features: May present as isolated epidural mass; radiosensitive; responds dramatically to steroids (may "melt" before biopsy); younger patients; constitutional symptoms (B symptoms); elevated LDH
differential.tests: MRI: epidural mass; homogeneous enhancement; may be paraspinal; CT: lymphadenopathy; LDH elevated; flow cytometry; KEY: obtain biopsy BEFORE steroids if possible; radiation is primary treatment

differential.features: Intramedullary T2 lesion on MRI (NOT epidural mass); autoimmune history; AQP4/MOG antibodies; longitudinally extensive (≥3 segments in NMOSD); responds to IV steroids/PLEX; no bone lesion
differential.tests: MRI: intramedullary T2 hyperintensity, NOT epidural mass; AQP4-IgG or MOG-IgG positive; CSF: pleocytosis; no vertebral body destruction

differential.features: Acute onset, often on anticoagulation; post-procedural (LP, epidural injection); acute neurogenic deficit; hyperacute T1 signal on MRI (blood)
differential.tests: MRI: epidural collection with blood signal characteristics (T1 hyperintense in subacute phase); history of anticoagulation or procedure; coagulation studies abnormal; neurosurgical emergency

evidence.evidenceLevel: Direct decompressive surgery + radiation vs. radiation alone for MSCC: ambulatory 84% vs. 57% (p=0.001); regained ambulation 62% vs. 19%; maintained ambulation 122 vs. 13 days; maintained continence longer
evidence.source: LANDMARK study establishing surgery + radiation as superior to radiation alone for single-level MSCC in non-radiosensitive tumors with life expectancy >3 months

evidence.evidenceLevel: Dexamethasone + radiation vs. radiation alone: ambulation 81% vs. 63% at end of treatment; 59% vs. 33% at 3 months
evidence.source: Established dexamethasone as standard adjunct to radiation in MSCC

evidence.evidenceLevel: High-dose (96 mg) vs. standard (10 mg) dexamethasone: faster initial response with high-dose but similar outcomes at 1 week; more side effects with high-dose
evidence.source: Most centers now use moderate dose (10 mg load → 16 mg/day) due to side effect profile

evidence.evidenceLevel: Short-course (20 Gy/5 fractions) vs. standard (30 Gy/10 fractions): no significant difference in motor function improvement for patients with poor prognosis
evidence.source: Short-course radiation appropriate for patients with limited life expectancy

evidence.evidenceLevel: Separation surgery + SBRT for radioresistant MSCC: 90% local control at 1 year; enabled delivery of effective radiation doses to previously radioresistant tumors
evidence.source: Established separation surgery + SBRT paradigm for RCC, melanoma, sarcoma spinal metastases

evidence.evidenceLevel: Zoledronic acid reduced skeletal-related events by 48% compared to placebo in bone metastases from breast cancer and myeloma
evidence.source: Standard bone-modifying therapy for cancer-related bone disease

evidence.evidenceLevel: Denosumab superior to zoledronic acid in reducing SRE in prostate cancer bone metastases (HR 0.82, p=0.008)
evidence.source: Denosumab as alternative/preferred bone-modifying agent; no renal adjustment needed

evidence.evidenceLevel: Lung, osteosarcoma, stomach, bladder, esophagus, pancreas

evidence.source: Palliative or excisional surgery depending on factors

evidence.evidenceLevel: Degree of cord compression (Bilsky grade); functional status; myelopathy
evidence.source: High-grade compression (Bilsky 2-3) → surgical decompression; low-grade → radiation alone may suffice

evidence.evidenceLevel: Radiosensitivity; expected tumor response to radiation
evidence.source: Radiosensitive (lymphoma, myeloma, SCLC) → radiation primary; Radioresistant (RCC, melanoma, sarcoma) → surgery + SBRT

evidence.evidenceLevel: Extent of metastatic burden; medical comorbidities; life expectancy
evidence.source: Widespread disease, poor prognosis → palliative approach; oligometastatic → aggressive local treatment

monitoring.item: Neurologic examination (motor strength, sensory level, rectal tone, reflexes)
monitoring.target: Stable or improving motor function; stable sensory level; preserved rectal tone
monitoring.action: If declining: STAT MRI; escalate dexamethasone to 24 mg/day; emergent neurosurgery
Sliding scale → basal-bolus insulin; endocrine consult if refractory
Escalate analgesics; add neuropathic agents; palliative care consultation
IV fluids; vasopressors if neurogenic shock; avoid excessive hypertension (post-operative bleeding risk)
Foley if retention; intermittent catheterization if PVR 200-500
Aggressive bowel regimen; rectal exam; abdominal X-ray if distended
Turn q2h; specialty mattress; heel protectors; wound care if injury develops
If febrile: blood cultures, UA, chest imaging; consider abscess vs. tumor fever
If FVC declining: ICU transfer; prepare for intubation; consider phrenic nerve involvement

disposition.criteria: Criteria

Neurogenic shock (hypotension + bradycardia from spinal cord injury); respiratory compromise from high cervical lesion; post-operative monitoring (first 24h after major spine surgery); acute paraplegia/quadriplegia requiring close monitoring; hemodynamic instability

New MSCC diagnosis requiring workup and treatment planning; surgical candidate awaiting decompression; radiation therapy initiation; motor deficits requiring monitoring and rehabilitation; pain management; high-dose steroid initiation
Known metastatic disease with new pain but preserved neurologic function; MRI showing compression without cord signal change; stable neurologic exam
